text: ﻿CHAPTER I.
label: neutral

text:
You don’t know about me without you have read a book by the name of The
Adventures of Tom Sawyer; but that ain’t no matter.
label: neutral

text:
That book was made
by Mr. Mark Twain, and he told the truth, mainly.
label: neutral

text:
There was things
which he stretched, but mainly he told the truth.
label: neutral

text: That is nothing.
label: neutral

text:
I
never seen anybody but lied one time or another, without it was Aunt
Polly, or the widow, or maybe Mary.
label: neutral

text:
Aunt Polly—Tom’s Aunt Polly, she
is—and Mary, and the Widow Douglas is all told about in that book,
which is mostly a true book, with some stretchers, as I said before.
label: neutral

text:
Now the way that the book winds up is this: Tom and me found the money
that the robbers hid in the cave, and it made us rich.
label: neutral

text:
We got six
thousand dollars apiece—all gold.
label: neutral

text:
It was an awful sight of money when
it was piled up.
label: disgust

text:
Well, Judge Thatcher he took it and put it out at
interest, and it fetched us a dollar a day apiece all the year
round—more than a body could tell what to do with.
label: neutral

text:
The Widow Douglas
she took me for her son, and allowed she would sivilize me; but it was
rough living in the house all the time, considering how dismal regular
and decent the widow was in all her ways; and so when I couldn’t stand
it no longer I lit out.
label: sadness

text:
I got into my old rags and my sugar-hogshead
again, and was free and satisfied.
label: joy

text:
But Tom Sawyer he hunted me up and
said he was going to start a band of robbers, and I might join if I
would go back to the widow and be respectable.
label: fear

text: So I went back.
label: neutral

text:
The widow she cried over me, and called me a poor lost lamb, and she
called me a lot of other names, too, but she never meant no harm by it.
label: disgust

text:
She put me in them new clothes again, and I couldn’t do nothing but
sweat and sweat, and feel all cramped up.
label: sadness

text:
Well, then, the old thing
commenced again.
label: neutral

text:
The widow rung a bell for supper, and you had to come
to time.
label: neutral

text:
When you got to the table you couldn’t go right to eating, but
you had to wait for the widow to tuck down her head and grumble a
little over the victuals, though there warn’t really anything the
matter with them,—that is, nothing only everything was cooked by
itself.
label: neutral

text:
In a barrel of odds and ends it is different; things get mixed
up, and the juice kind of swaps around, and the things go better.
label: neutral

text:
After supper she got out her book and learned me about Moses and the
Bulrushers, and I was in a sweat to find out all about him; but
by-and-by she let it out that Moses had been dead a considerable long
time; so then I didn’t care no more about him, because I don’t take no
stock in dead people.
label: neutral

text: Pretty soon I wanted to smoke, and asked the widow to let me.
label: disgust

text:
But she
wouldn’t.
label: neutral

text:
She said it was a mean practice and wasn’t clean, and I must
try to not do it any more.
label: anger

text: That is just the way with some people.
label: neutral

text:
They
get down on a thing when they don’t know nothing about it.
label: disgust

text:
Here she was
a-bothering about Moses, which was no kin to her, and no use to
anybody, being gone, you see, yet finding a power of fault with me for
doing a thing that had some good in it.
label: anger

text:
And she took snuff, too; of
course that was all right, because she done it herself.
label: neutral

text:
Her sister, Miss Watson, a tolerable slim old maid, with goggles on,
had just come to live with her, and took a set at me now with a
spelling-book.
label: neutral

text:
She worked me middling hard for about an hour, and then
the widow made her ease up.
label: neutral

text: I couldn’t stood it much longer.
label: disgust

text:
Then for
an hour it was deadly dull, and I was fidgety.
label: sadness

text:
Miss Watson would say,
“Don’t put your feet up there, Huckleberry;” and “Don’t scrunch up like
that, Huckleberry—set up straight;” and pretty soon she would say,
“Don’t gap and stretch like that, Huckleberry—why don’t you try to
behave?” Then she told me all about the bad place, and I said I wished
I was there.
label: neutral

text: She got mad then, but I didn’t mean no harm.
label: anger

text:
All I wanted
was to go somewheres; all I wanted was a change, I warn’t particular.
label: neutral

text:
She said it was wicked to say what I said; said she wouldn’t say it for
the whole world; she was going to live so as to go to the good place.
label: neutral

text:
Well, I couldn’t see no advantage in going where she was going, so I
made up my mind I wouldn’t try for it.
label: neutral

text:
But I never said so, because it
would only make trouble, and wouldn’t do no good.
label: neutral

text:
Now she had got a start, and she went on and told me all about the good
place.
label: neutral

text:
She said all a body would have to do there was to go around all
day long with a harp and sing, forever and ever.
label: neutral

text:
So I didn’t think much
of it.
label: surprise

text: But I never said so.
label: neutral

text:
I asked her if she reckoned Tom Sawyer
would go there, and she said not by a considerable sight.
label: surprise

text:
I was glad
about that, because I wanted him and me to be together.
label: joy

text: Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome.
label: disgust

text:
By-and-by they fetched the niggers in and had prayers, and then
everybody was off to bed.
label: neutral

text:
I went up to my room with a piece of candle,
and put it on the table.
label: disgust

text:
Then I set down in a chair by the window and
tried to think of something cheerful, but it warn’t no use.
label: sadness

text:
I felt so
lonesome I most wished I was dead.
label: sadness

text:
The stars were shining, and the
leaves rustled in the woods ever so mournful; and I heard an owl, away
off, who-whooing about somebody that was dead, and a whippowill and a
dog crying about somebody that was going to die; and the wind was
trying to whisper something to me, and I couldn’t make out what it was,
and so it made the cold shivers run over me.
label: sadness

text:
Then away out in the woods
I heard that kind of a sound that a ghost makes when it wants to tell
about something that’s on its mind and can’t make itself understood,
and so can’t rest easy in its grave, and has to go about that way every
night grieving.
label: fear

text:
I got so down-hearted and scared I did wish I had some
company.
label: fear

text:
Pretty soon a spider went crawling up my shoulder, and I
flipped it off and it lit in the candle; and before I could budge it
was all shriveled up.
label: sadness

text:
I didn’t need anybody to tell me that that was an
awful bad sign and would fetch me some bad luck, so I was scared and
most shook the clothes off of me.
label: fear

text:
I got up and turned around in my
tracks three times and crossed my breast every time; and then I tied up
a little lock of my hair with a thread to keep witches away.
label: neutral

text:
But I
hadn’t no confidence.
label: fear

text:
You do that when you’ve lost a horseshoe that
you’ve found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadn’t ever
heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when you’d killed
a spider.
label: neutral
fear

text:
Well, after a long time I heard the clock away off in the town go
boom—boom—boom—twelve licks; and all still again—stiller than ever.
label: surprise

text:
Pretty soon I heard a twig snap down in the dark amongst the
trees—something was a stirring.
label: fear

text: I set still and listened.
label: neutral

text:
Directly I
could just barely hear a “_me-yow!
label: surprise

text: me-yow!_” down there.
label: neutral

text: That was good!
label: joy

text: Says I, “_me-yow!
label: joy

text:
me-yow!_” as soft as I could, and then I put out the
light and scrambled out of the window on to the shed.
label: neutral

text:
Then I slipped
down to the ground and crawled in among the trees, and, sure enough,
there was Tom Sawyer waiting for me.
label: fear

text: CHAPTER II.
label: neutral

text:
We went tiptoeing along a path amongst the trees back towards the end
of the widow’s garden, stooping down so as the branches wouldn’t scrape
our heads.
label: neutral

text:
When we was passing by the kitchen I fell over a root and
made a noise.
label: fear

text: We scrouched down and laid still.
label: fear

text:
Miss Watson’s big
nigger, named Jim, was setting in the kitchen door; we could see him
pretty clear, because there was a light behind him.
label: disgust

text:
He got up and
stretched his neck out about a minute, listening.
label: disgust

text: Then he says:
label: neutral

text: “Who dah?”
label: surprise

text:
He listened some more; then he come tiptoeing down and stood right
between us; we could a touched him, nearly.
label: surprise

text:
Well, likely it was minutes
and minutes that there warn’t a sound, and we all there so close
together.
label: neutral

text:
There was a place on my ankle that got to itching, but I
dasn’t scratch it; and then my ear begun to itch; and next my back,
right between my shoulders.
label: neutral

text: Seemed like I’d die if I couldn’t scratch.
label: fear

text: Well, I’ve noticed that thing plenty times since.
label: neutral

text:
If you are with the
quality, or at a funeral, or trying to go to sleep when you ain’t
sleepy—if you are anywheres where it won’t do for you to scratch, why
you will itch all over in upwards of a thousand places.
label: neutral

text:
Pretty soon Jim
says:
label: neutral

text: “Say, who is you?
label: surprise

text: Whar is you?
label: surprise

text: Dog my cats ef I didn’ hear sumf’n.
label: disgust

text:
Well, I know what I’s gwyne to do: I’s gwyne to set down here and
listen tell I hears it agin.”
label: neutral

text: So he set down on the ground betwixt me and Tom.
label: disgust

text:
He leaned his back up
against a tree, and stretched his legs out till one of them most
touched one of mine.
label: disgust

text: My nose begun to itch.
label: disgust

text:
It itched till the tears
come into my eyes.
label: sadness

text: But I dasn’t scratch.
label: neutral

text:
Then it begun to itch on the
inside.
label: disgust

text: Next I got to itching underneath.
label: neutral

text:
I didn’t know how I was going
to set still.
label: surprise

text:
This miserableness went on as much as six or seven
minutes; but it seemed a sight longer than that.
label: neutral

text:
I was itching in
eleven different places now.
label: neutral

text:
I reckoned I couldn’t stand it more’n a
minute longer, but I set my teeth hard and got ready to try.
label: disgust

text:
Just then
Jim begun to breathe heavy; next he begun to snore—and then I was
pretty soon comfortable again.
label: fear

text:
Tom he made a sign to me—kind of a little noise with his mouth—and we
went creeping away on our hands and knees.
label: fear

text:
When we was ten foot off Tom
whispered to me, and wanted to tie Jim to the tree for fun.
label: disgust

text:
But I said
no; he might wake and make a disturbance, and then they’d find out I
warn’t in.
label: neutral

text:
Then Tom said he hadn’t got candles enough, and he would
slip in the kitchen and get some more.
label: neutral

text: I didn’t want him to try.
label: anger

text:
I said
Jim might wake up and come.
label: neutral

text:
But Tom wanted to resk it; so we slid in
there and got three candles, and Tom laid five cents on the table for
pay.
label: neutral

text:
Then we got out, and I was in a sweat to get away; but nothing
would do Tom but he must crawl to where Jim was, on his hands and
knees, and play something on him.
label: neutral

text:
I waited, and it seemed a good while,
everything was so still and lonesome.
label: neutral

text:
As soon as Tom was back we cut along the path, around the garden fence,
and by-and-by fetched up on the steep top of the hill the other side of
the house.
label: fear

text:
Tom said he slipped Jim’s hat off of his head and hung it on
a limb right over him, and Jim stirred a little, but he didn’t wake.
label: neutral

text:
Afterwards Jim said the witches bewitched him and put him in a trance,
and rode him all over the State, and then set him under the trees
again, and hung his hat on a limb to show who done it.
label: neutral

text:
And next time
Jim told it he said they rode him down to New Orleans; and, after that,
every time he told it he spread it more and more, till by-and-by he
said they rode him all over the world, and tired him most to death, and
his back was all over saddle-boils.
label: neutral

text:
Jim was monstrous proud about it,
and he got so he wouldn’t hardly notice the other niggers.
label: disgust

text:
Niggers
would come miles to hear Jim tell about it, and he was more looked up
to than any nigger in that country.
label: neutral

text:
Strange niggers would stand with
their mouths open and look him all over, same as if he was a wonder.
label: surprise

text:
Niggers is always talking about witches in the dark by the kitchen
fire; but whenever one was talking and letting on to know all about
such things, Jim would happen in and say, “Hm!
label: disgust

text:
What you know ’bout
witches?” and that nigger was corked up and had to take a back seat.
label: disgust

text:
Jim always kept that five-center piece round his neck with a string,
and said it was a charm the devil give to him with his own hands, and
told him he could cure anybody with it and fetch witches whenever he
wanted to just by saying something to it; but he never told what it was
he said to it.
label: neutral

text:
Niggers would come from all around there and give Jim
anything they had, just for a sight of that five-center piece; but they
wouldn’t touch it, because the devil had had his hands on it.
label: disgust

text:
Jim was
most ruined for a servant, because he got stuck up on account of having
seen the devil and been rode by witches.
label: sadness

text:
Well, when Tom and me got to the edge of the hilltop we looked away
down into the village and could see three or four lights twinkling,
where there was sick folks, maybe; and the stars over us was sparkling
ever so fine; and down by the village was the river, a whole mile
broad, and awful still and grand.
label: fear

text:
We went down the hill and found Jo
Harper and Ben Rogers, and two or three more of the boys, hid in the
old tanyard.
label: neutral

text:
So we unhitched a skiff and pulled down the river two mile
and a half, to the big scar on the hillside, and went ashore.
label: fear

text:
We went to a clump of bushes, and Tom made everybody swear to keep the
secret, and then showed them a hole in the hill, right in the thickest
part of the bushes.
label: disgust

text:
Then we lit the candles, and crawled in on our
hands and knees.
label: disgust

text:
We went about two hundred yards, and then the cave
opened up.
label: neutral

text:
Tom poked about amongst the passages, and pretty soon ducked
under a wall where you wouldn’t a noticed that there was a hole.
label: surprise

text:
We
went along a narrow place and got into a kind of room, all damp and
sweaty and cold, and there we stopped.
label: fear

text: Tom says:
label: neutral

text: “Now, we’ll start this band of robbers and call it Tom Sawyer’s Gang.
label: neutral

text:
Everybody that wants to join has got to take an oath, and write his
name in blood.”
label: neutral

text: Everybody was willing.
label: neutral

text:
So Tom got out a sheet of paper that he had
wrote the oath on, and read it.
label: neutral

text:
It swore every boy to stick to the
band, and never tell any of the secrets; and if anybody done anything
to any boy in the band, whichever boy was ordered to kill that person
and his family must do it, and he mustn’t eat and he mustn’t sleep till
he had killed them and hacked a cross in their breasts, which was the
sign of the band.
label: anger

text:
And nobody that didn’t belong to the band could use
that mark, and if he did he must be sued; and if he done it again he
must be killed.
label: anger

text:
And if anybody that belonged to the band told the
secrets, he must have his throat cut, and then have his carcass burnt
up and the ashes scattered all around, and his name blotted off of the
list with blood and never mentioned again by the gang, but have a curse
put on it and be forgot forever.
label: disgust

text:
Everybody said it was a real beautiful oath, and asked Tom if he got it
out of his own head.
label: neutral

text:
He said, some of it, but the rest was out of
pirate-books and robber-books, and every gang that was high-toned had
it.
label: neutral

text:
Some thought it would be good to kill the _families_ of boys that told
the secrets.
label: anger

text:
Tom said it was a good idea, so he took a pencil and wrote
it in.
label: neutral

text: Then Ben Rogers says:
label: neutral

text:
“Here’s Huck Finn, he hain’t got no family; what you going to do ’bout
him?”
label: anger

text: “Well, hain’t he got a father?” says Tom Sawyer.
label: neutral

text: “Yes, he’s got a father, but you can’t never find him these days.
label: neutral

text:
He
used to lay drunk with the hogs in the tanyard, but he hain’t been seen
in these parts for a year or more.”
label: disgust

text:
They talked it over, and they was going to rule me out, because they
said every boy must have a family or somebody to kill, or else it
wouldn’t be fair and square for the others.
label: neutral

text:
Well, nobody could think of
anything to do—everybody was stumped, and set still.
label: neutral

text:
I was most ready
to cry; but all at once I thought of a way, and so I offered them Miss
Watson—they could kill her.
label: fear

text: Everybody said:
label: neutral

text: “Oh, she’ll do.
label: neutral

text: That’s all right.
label: neutral

text: Huck can come in.”
label: disgust

text:
Then they all stuck a pin in their fingers to get blood to sign with,
and I made my mark on the paper.
label: neutral

text: “Now,” says Ben Rogers, “what’s the line of business of this Gang?”
label: neutral

text: “Nothing only robbery and murder,” Tom said.
label: anger

text: “But who are we going to rob?—houses, or cattle, or—”
label: fear

text: “Stuff!
label: anger

text:
stealing cattle and such things ain’t robbery; it’s burglary,”
says Tom Sawyer.
label: neutral

text: “We ain’t burglars.
label: neutral

text: That ain’t no sort of style.
label: neutral

text:
We
are highwaymen.
label: neutral

text:
We stop stages and carriages on the road, with masks
on, and kill the people and take their watches and money.”
label: anger

text: “Must we always kill the people?”
label: anger

text: “Oh, certainly.
label: neutral

text: It’s best.
label: neutral

text:
Some authorities think different, but mostly
it’s considered best to kill them—except some that you bring to the
cave here, and keep them till they’re ransomed.”
label: neutral

text: “Ransomed?
label: surprise

text: What’s that?”
label: surprise

text: “I don’t know.
label: surprise

text: But that’s what they do.
label: neutral

text:
I’ve seen it in books; and so
of course that’s what we’ve got to do.”
label: neutral

text: “But how can we do it if we don’t know what it is?”
label: neutral

text: “Why, blame it all, we’ve _got_ to do it.
label: anger

text:
Don’t I tell you it’s in the
books?
label: surprise

text:
Do you want to go to doing different from what’s in the books,
and get things all muddled up?”
label: neutral

text:
“Oh, that’s all very fine to _say_, Tom Sawyer, but how in the nation
are these fellows going to be ransomed if we don’t know how to do it to
them?—that’s the thing _I_ want to get at.
label: neutral

text:
Now, what do you _reckon_ it
is?”
label: anger

text: “Well, I don’t know.
label: neutral

text:
But per’aps if we keep them till they’re ransomed,
it means that we keep them till they’re dead.”
label: neutral

text: “Now, that’s something _like_.
label: neutral

text: That’ll answer.
label: neutral

text:
Why couldn’t you said
that before?
label: surprise

text:
We’ll keep them till they’re ransomed to death; and a
bothersome lot they’ll be, too—eating up everything, and always trying
to get loose.”
label: neutral

text: “How you talk, Ben Rogers.
label: neutral

text:
How can they get loose when there’s a guard
over them, ready to shoot them down if they move a peg?”
label: neutral

text: “A guard!
label: surprise

text: Well, that _is_ good.
label: joy

text:
So somebody’s got to set up all night
and never get any sleep, just so as to watch them.
label: neutral

text:
I think that’s
foolishness.
label: neutral

text:
Why can’t a body take a club and ransom them as soon as
they get here?”
label: anger

text: “Because it ain’t in the books so—that’s why.
label: neutral

text:
Now, Ben Rogers, do you
want to do things regular, or don’t you?—that’s the idea.
label: neutral

text:
Don’t you
reckon that the people that made the books knows what’s the correct
thing to do?
label: anger

text: Do you reckon _you_ can learn ’em anything?
label: neutral

text:
Not by a good
deal.
label: sadness

text: No, sir, we’ll just go on and ransom them in the regular way.”
label: neutral

text: “All right.
label: neutral

text: I don’t mind; but I say it’s a fool way, anyhow.
label: anger

text:
Say, do we
kill the women, too?”
label: anger

text: “Well, Ben Rogers, if I was as ignorant as you I wouldn’t let on.
label: neutral

text:
Kill
the women?
label: anger

text: No; nobody ever saw anything in the books like that.
label: disgust

text:
You
fetch them to the cave, and you’re always as polite as pie to them; and
by-and-by they fall in love with you, and never want to go home any
more.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, if that’s the way I’m agreed, but I don’t take no stock in it.
label: neutral

text:
Mighty soon we’ll have the cave so cluttered up with women, and fellows
waiting to be ransomed, that there won’t be no place for the robbers.
label: neutral

text: But go ahead, I ain’t got nothing to say.”
label: anger

text:
Little Tommy Barnes was asleep now, and when they waked him up he was
scared, and cried, and said he wanted to go home to his ma, and didn’t
want to be a robber any more.
label: fear

text:
So they all made fun of him, and called him cry-baby, and that made him
mad, and he said he would go straight and tell all the secrets.
label: anger

text:
But Tom
give him five cents to keep quiet, and said we would all go home and
meet next week, and rob somebody and kill some people.
label: anger

text:
Ben Rogers said he couldn’t get out much, only Sundays, and so he
wanted to begin next Sunday; but all the boys said it would be wicked
to do it on Sunday, and that settled the thing.
label: neutral

text:
They agreed to get
together and fix a day as soon as they could, and then we elected Tom
Sawyer first captain and Jo Harper second captain of the Gang, and so
started home.
label: neutral

text:
I clumb up the shed and crept into my window just before day was
breaking.
label: fear

text:
My new clothes was all greased up and clayey, and I was
dog-tired.
label: neutral

text: CHAPTER III.
label: neutral

text:
Well, I got a good going-over in the morning from old Miss Watson on
account of my clothes; but the widow she didn’t scold, but only cleaned
off the grease and clay, and looked so sorry that I thought I would
behave a while if I could.
label: sadness

text:
Then Miss Watson she took me in the closet
and prayed, but nothing come of it.
label: sadness

text:
She told me to pray every day, and
whatever I asked for I would get it.
label: neutral

text: But it warn’t so.
label: neutral

text: I tried it.
label: neutral

text:
Once
I got a fish-line, but no hooks.
label: neutral

text:
It warn’t any good to me without
hooks.
label: neutral

text:
I tried for the hooks three or four times, but somehow I
couldn’t make it work.
label: sadness

text:
By-and-by, one day, I asked Miss Watson to try
for me, but she said I was a fool.
label: anger

text:
She never told me why, and I
couldn’t make it out no way.
label: surprise

text: I set down one time back in the woods, and had a long think about it.
label: fear

text:
I
says to myself, if a body can get anything they pray for, why don’t
Deacon Winn get back the money he lost on pork?
label: neutral

text:
Why can’t the widow get
back her silver snuffbox that was stole?
label: anger

text: Why can’t Miss Watson fat up?
label: surprise

text: No, says I to myself, there ain’t nothing in it.
label: neutral

text:
I went and told the
widow about it, and she said the thing a body could get by praying for
it was “spiritual gifts.” This was too many for me, but she told me
what she meant—I must help other people, and do everything I could for
other people, and look out for them all the time, and never think about
myself.
label: neutral

text: This was including Miss Watson, as I took it.
label: neutral

text:
I went out in the
woods and turned it over in my mind a long time, but I couldn’t see no
advantage about it—except for the other people; so at last I reckoned I
wouldn’t worry about it any more, but just let it go.
label: neutral

text:
Sometimes the
widow would take me one side and talk about Providence in a way to make
a body’s mouth water; but maybe next day Miss Watson would take hold
and knock it all down again.
label: neutral

text:
I judged I could see that there was two
Providences, and a poor chap would stand considerable show with the
widow’s Providence, but if Miss Watson’s got him there warn’t no help
for him any more.
label: sadness

text:
I thought it all out, and reckoned I would belong to
the widow’s if he wanted me, though I couldn’t make out how he was
a-going to be any better off then than what he was before, seeing I was
so ignorant, and so kind of low-down and ornery.
label: neutral

text:
Pap he hadn’t been seen for more than a year, and that was comfortable
for me; I didn’t want to see him no more.
label: sadness

text:
He used to always whale me
when he was sober and could get his hands on me; though I used to take
to the woods most of the time when he was around.
label: disgust

text:
Well, about this time
he was found in the river drownded, about twelve mile above town, so
people said.
label: neutral

text:
They judged it was him, anyway; said this drownded man was
just his size, and was ragged, and had uncommon long hair, which was
all like pap; but they couldn’t make nothing out of the face, because
it had been in the water so long it warn’t much like a face at all.
label: neutral

text: They said he was floating on his back in the water.
label: disgust

text:
They took him and
buried him on the bank.
label: anger

text:
But I warn’t comfortable long, because I
happened to think of something.
label: fear

text:
I knowed mighty well that a drownded
man don’t float on his back, but on his face.
label: neutral

text:
So I knowed, then, that
this warn’t pap, but a woman dressed up in a man’s clothes.
label: disgust

text:
So I was
uncomfortable again.
label: fear

text:
I judged the old man would turn up again
by-and-by, though I wished he wouldn’t.
label: neutral

text: We played robber now and then about a month, and then I resigned.
label: neutral

text:
All
the boys did.
label: neutral

text:
We hadn’t robbed nobody, hadn’t killed any people, but
only just pretended.
label: neutral

text:
We used to hop out of the woods and go charging
down on hog-drivers and women in carts taking garden stuff to market,
but we never hived any of them.
label: disgust

text:
Tom Sawyer called the hogs “ingots,”
and he called the turnips and stuff “julery,” and we would go to the
cave and powwow over what we had done, and how many people we had
killed and marked.
label: disgust

text: But I couldn’t see no profit in it.
label: disgust

text:
One time Tom
sent a boy to run about town with a blazing stick, which he called a
slogan (which was the sign for the Gang to get together), and then he
said he had got secret news by his spies that next day a whole parcel
of Spanish merchants and rich A-rabs was going to camp in Cave Hollow
with two hundred elephants, and six hundred camels, and over a thousand
“sumter” mules, all loaded down with di’monds, and they didn’t have
only a guard of four hundred soldiers, and so we would lay in
ambuscade, as he called it, and kill the lot and scoop the things.
label: neutral

text:
He
said we must slick up our swords and guns, and get ready.
label: neutral

text:
He never
could go after even a turnip-cart but he must have the swords and guns
all scoured up for it, though they was only lath and broomsticks, and
you might scour at them till you rotted, and then they warn’t worth a
mouthful of ashes more than what they was before.
label: neutral

text:
I didn’t believe we
could lick such a crowd of Spaniards and A-rabs, but I wanted to see
the camels and elephants, so I was on hand next day, Saturday, in the
ambuscade; and when we got the word we rushed out of the woods and down
the hill.
label: fear

text:
But there warn’t no Spaniards and A-rabs, and there warn’t no
camels nor no elephants.
label: neutral

text:
It warn’t anything but a Sunday-school picnic,
and only a primer-class at that.
label: neutral

text:
We busted it up, and chased the
children up the hollow; but we never got anything but some doughnuts
and jam, though Ben Rogers got a rag doll, and Jo Harper got a
hymn-book and a tract; and then the teacher charged in, and made us
drop everything and cut.
label: disgust

text: I didn’t see no di’monds, and I told Tom Sawyer so.
label: neutral

text:
He said there was
loads of them there, anyway; and he said there was A-rabs there, too,
and elephants and things.
label: neutral

text: I said, why couldn’t we see them, then?
label: surprise

text:
He

text: He said it was all done by enchantment.

text:

text:
I said, all right; then the thing for us to do was to go for the

text: Tom Sawyer said I was a numskull.
label: neutral

text:
“Why,” said he, “a magician could call up a lot of genies, and they

text:
They
are as tall as a tree and as big around as a church.”
label: neutral

text:
“Well,” I says, “s’pose we got some genies to help _us_—can’t we lick
the other crowd then?”
label: neutral

text: “How you going to get them?”
label: anger

text: “I don’t know.
label: surprise

text: How do _they_ get them?”
label: neutral

text:
“Why, they rub an old tin lamp or an iron ring, and then the genies

text:
They don’t think nothing of pulling a shot-tower up by the roots,

label: neutral

text: “Who makes them tear around so?”
label: neutral

text: “Why, whoever rubs the lamp or the ring.
label: neutral

text:

text:
If he

label: neutral

text:
And more: they’ve got to
waltz that palace around over the country wherever you want it, you

label: neutral

text:
“Well,” says I, “I think they are a pack of flat-heads for not keeping

label: neutral

text:
And what’s
more—if I was one of them I would see a man in Jericho before I would

label: neutral

text: “How you talk, Huck Finn.
label: neutral

text:
Why, you’d _have_ to come when he rubbed it,

label: neutral

text: “What!
label: surprise

text: and I as high as a tree and as big as a church?
label: surprise
neutral

text: “Shucks, it ain’t no use to talk to you, Huck Finn.
label: disgust

text:
You don’t seem to
know anything, somehow—perfect saphead.”
label: neutral

text:
I thought all this over for two or three days, and then I reckoned I
would see if there was anything in it.
label: neutral

text:
I got an old tin lamp and an
iron ring, and went out in the woods and rubbed and rubbed till I sweat
like an Injun, calculating to build a palace and sell it; but it warn’t

label: neutral

text:
So then I judged that all that stuff
was only just one of Tom Sawyer’s lies.

text:
I reckoned he believed in the
A-rabs and the elephants, but as for me I think different.

text:
It had all
the marks of a Sunday-school.

text: CHAPTER IV.
label: neutral

text:
Well, three or four months run along, and it was well into the winter
now.
label: neutral

text:
I had been to school most all the time and could spell and read
and write just a little, and could say the multiplication table up to
six times seven is thirty-five, and I don’t reckon I could ever get any
further than that if I was to live forever.
label: neutral

text:
I don’t take no stock in
mathematics, anyway.
label: neutral

text: At first I hated the school, but by-and-by I got so I could stand it.
label: disgust

text:
Whenever I got uncommon tired I played hookey, and the hiding I got
next day done me good and cheered me up.
label: joy

text:
So the longer I went to school
the easier it got to be.
label: joy

text:
I was getting sort of used to the widow’s
ways, too, and they warn’t so raspy on me.
label: neutral

text:
Living in a house and
sleeping in a bed pulled on me pretty tight mostly, but before the cold
weather I used to slide out and sleep in the woods sometimes, and so
that was a rest to me.
label: neutral

text:
I liked the old ways best, but I was getting so
I liked the new ones, too, a little bit.
label: joy

text:
The widow said I was coming
along slow but sure, and doing very satisfactory.
label: neutral

text:
She said she warn’t
ashamed of me.
label: fear

text: One morning I happened to turn over the salt-cellar at breakfast.
label: disgust

text:
I
reached for some of it as quick as I could to throw over my left
shoulder and keep off the bad luck, but Miss Watson was in ahead of me,
and crossed me off.
label: neutral

text:
She says, “Take your hands away, Huckleberry; what
a mess you are always making!” The widow put in a good word for me, but
that warn’t going to keep off the bad luck, I knowed that well enough.
label: neutral

text:
I started out, after breakfast, feeling worried and shaky, and
wondering where it was going to fall on me, and what it was going to
be.
label: fear

text:
There is ways to keep off some kinds of bad luck, but this wasn’t
one of them kind; so I never tried to do anything, but just poked along
low-spirited and on the watch-out.
label: neutral

text:
I went down to the front garden and clumb over the stile where you go
through the high board fence.
label: neutral

text:
There was an inch of new snow on the
ground, and I seen somebody’s tracks.
label: surprise

text:
They had come up from the quarry
and stood around the stile a while, and then went on around the garden
fence.
label: disgust

text: It was funny they hadn’t come in, after standing around so.
label: surprise

text:
I
couldn’t make it out.
label: sadness

text: It was very curious, somehow.
label: surprise

text:
I was going to
follow around, but I stooped down to look at the tracks first.
label: fear

text:
I didn’t
notice anything at first, but next I did.
label: surprise

text:
There was a cross in the left
boot-heel made with big nails, to keep off the devil.

text: I was up in a second and shinning down the hill.
label: fear

text:
I looked over my
shoulder every now and then, but I didn’t see nobody.
label: fear

text:
I was at Judge
Thatcher’s as quick as I could get there.
label: surprise

text: He said:
label: neutral

text: “Why, my boy, you are all out of breath.
label: surprise

text:
Did you come for your
interest?”
label: surprise

text: “No, sir,” I says; “is there some for me?”
label: neutral

text:
“Oh, yes, a half-yearly is in, last night—over a hundred and fifty

label: surprise

text: Quite a fortune for you.
label: joy

text:
You had better let me invest it along
with your six thousand, because if you take it you’ll spend it.”

text: “No, sir,” I says, “I don’t want to spend it.
label: fear

text:
I don’t want it at

label: anger

text:
I want you to take it; I want to give
it to you—the six thousand and all.”

text: He looked surprised.
label: surprise

label: surprise

text: He says:
label: neutral

label: surprise

text: I says, “Don’t you ask me no questions about it, please.
label: fear

text:
You’ll take

label: anger

text: He says:
label: neutral

label: surprise

text: Is something the matter?”
label: neutral

text:
“Please take it,” says I, “and don’t ask me nothing—then I won’t have

text: He studied a while, and then he says:

label: surprise

label: surprise

You want to _sell_ all your property to me—not

text:
“There; you see it says ‘for a consideration.’ That means I have bought

text:
Now you sign
it.”
label: anger

text: So I signed it, and left.

text:
Miss Watson’s nigger, Jim, had a hair-ball as big as your fist, which
had been took out of the fourth stomach of an ox, and he used to do
magic with it.
label: neutral

text:
He said there was a spirit inside of it, and it knowed
everything.
label: neutral

text:
So I went to him that night and told him pap was here
again, for I found his tracks in the snow.
label: neutral

text:
What I wanted to know was,
what he was going to do, and was he going to stay?

text:
Jim got out his
hair-ball and said something over it, and then he held it up and
dropped it on the floor.
label: neutral

text:
It fell pretty solid, and only rolled about an
inch.
label: neutral

text:
Jim tried it again, and then another time, and it acted just the

label: neutral

text:
Jim got down on his knees, and put his ear against it and

text:
He said

text:
I told him I had an old slick
counterfeit quarter that warn’t no good because the brass showed

would tell on it every time.
label: neutral

text:
(I reckoned I wouldn’t say nothing about

text:
I said it was pretty bad money, but

text:
Jim smelt it and bit it and rubbed it, and said he would

text:
He said he would split

label: neutral

text:
Well, I knowed a potato would do that

text:
Jim put the quarter under the hair-ball, and got down and listened

So the

text:
Sometimes he

text:
When I lit my candle and went up to my room that night there sat pap

text: CHAPTER V.
label: neutral

text: I had shut the door to.

text: Then I turned around and there he was.
label: surprise

text:
I used

text:
I reckoned I

label: fear

text: He was most fifty, and he looked it.
label: neutral

text:
His hair was long and tangled and

text:
It was all black, no gray; so was his long,

text:
There warn’t no color in his face, where his face

text:
He had

text:
His

I stood a-looking at him; he set there a-looking at me, with his chair

Next day he was drunk, and he went to Judge Thatcher’s and bullyragged
