text:
The judge and the widow went to law to get the court to take me away
from him and let one of them be my guardian; but it was a new judge
that had just come, and he didn’t know the old man; so he said courts
mustn’t interfere and separate families if they could help it; said
he’d druther not take a child away from its father.
label: neutral

text:
So Judge Thatcher
and the widow had to quit on the business.
label: sadness

text: That pleased the old man till he couldn’t rest.
label: joy

text:
He said he’d cowhide me
till I was black and blue if I didn’t raise some money for him.
label: anger

text:
I
borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher, and pap took it and got
drunk, and went a-blowing around and cussing and whooping and carrying
on; and he kept it up all over town, with a tin pan, till most
midnight; then they jailed him, and next day they had him before court,
and jailed him again for a week.
label: neutral

text:
But he said _he_ was satisfied; said
he was boss of his son, and he’d make it warm for _him_.
label: neutral

text: When he got out the new judge said he was a-going to make a man of him.
label: disgust

text:
So he took him to his own house, and dressed him up clean and nice, and
had him to breakfast and dinner and supper with the family, and was
just old pie to him, so to speak.
label: neutral

text:
And after supper he talked to him
about temperance and such things till the old man cried, and said he’d
been a fool, and fooled away his life; but now he was a-going to turn
over a new leaf and be a man nobody wouldn’t be ashamed of, and he
hoped the judge would help him and not look down on him.
label: neutral

text:
The judge said
he could hug him for them words; so _he_ cried, and his wife she cried
again; pap said he’d been a man that had always been misunderstood
before, and the judge said he believed it.
label: neutral

text:
The old man said that what a
man wanted that was down was sympathy, and the judge said it was so; so
they cried again.
label: sadness

text:
And when it was bedtime the old man rose up and held
out his hand, and says:
label: neutral

text: “Look at it, gentlemen and ladies all; take a-hold of it; shake it.
label: fear
neutral

text: You mark them words—don’t forget I said them.
label: neutral

text: It’s a clean hand now; shake it—don’t be afeard.”
label: fear

text: So they shook it, one after the other, all around, and cried.
label: neutral

text:
The
judge’s wife she kissed it.
label: disgust

text:
Then the old man he signed a pledge—made
his mark.
label: neutral

text:
The judge said it was the holiest time on record, or
something like that.
label: neutral

text:
Then they tucked the old man into a beautiful
room, which was the spare room, and in the night some time he got
powerful thirsty and clumb out on to the porch-roof and slid down a
stanchion and traded his new coat for a jug of forty-rod, and clumb
back again and had a good old time; and towards daylight he crawled out
again, drunk as a fiddler, and rolled off the porch and broke his left
arm in two places, and was most froze to death when somebody found him
after sun-up.
label: neutral

text:
And when they come to look at that spare room they had to
take soundings before they could navigate it.
label: neutral

text: The judge he felt kind of sore.
label: disgust

text:
He said he reckoned a body could reform
the old man with a shotgun, maybe, but he didn’t know no other way.
label: neutral

text: CHAPTER VI.
label: neutral

text:
Well, pretty soon the old man was up and around again, and then he went
for Judge Thatcher in the courts to make him give up that money, and he
went for me, too, for not stopping school.
label: neutral

text:
He catched me a couple of
times and thrashed me, but I went to school just the same, and dodged
him or outrun him most of the time.
label: anger

text:
I didn’t want to go to school much
before, but I reckoned I’d go now to spite pap.
label: anger

text:
That law trial was a
slow business—appeared like they warn’t ever going to get started on
it; so every now and then I’d borrow two or three dollars off of the
judge for him, to keep from getting a cowhiding.
label: neutral

text:
Every time he got
money he got drunk; and every time he got drunk he raised Cain around
town; and every time he raised Cain he got jailed.
label: anger

text:
He was just
suited—this kind of thing was right in his line.
label: disgust

text:
He got to hanging around the widow’s too much and so she told him at
last that if he didn’t quit using around there she would make trouble
for him.
label: neutral

text: Well, _wasn’t_ he mad?
label: neutral

text:
He said he would show who was Huck
Finn’s boss.
label: neutral

text:
So he watched out for me one day in the spring, and
catched me, and took me up the river about three mile in a skiff, and
crossed over to the Illinois shore where it was woody and there warn’t
no houses but an old log hut in a place where the timber was so thick
you couldn’t find it if you didn’t know where it was.
label: surprise

text: He kept me with him all the time, and I never got a chance to run off.
label: anger

text:
We lived in that old cabin, and he always locked the door and put the
key under his head nights.
label: neutral

text:
He had a gun which he had stole, I reckon,
and we fished and hunted, and that was what we lived on.
label: disgust

text:
Every little
while he locked me in and went down to the store, three miles, to the
ferry, and traded fish and game for whisky, and fetched it home and got
drunk and had a good time, and licked me.
label: neutral

text:
The widow she found out where
I was by-and-by, and she sent a man over to try to get hold of me; but
pap drove him off with the gun, and it warn’t long after that till I
was used to being where I was, and liked it—all but the cowhide part.
label: anger

text:
It was kind of lazy and jolly, laying off comfortable all day, smoking
and fishing, and no books nor study.
label: joy

text:
Two months or more run along, and
my clothes got to be all rags and dirt, and I didn’t see how I’d ever
got to like it so well at the widow’s, where you had to wash, and eat
on a plate, and comb up, and go to bed and get up regular, and be
forever bothering over a book, and have old Miss Watson pecking at you
all the time.
label: neutral

text: I didn’t want to go back no more.
label: sadness

text:
I had stopped cussing,
because the widow didn’t like it; but now I took to it again because
pap hadn’t no objections.
label: anger

text:
It was pretty good times up in the woods
there, take it all around.
label: joy

text:
But by-and-by pap got too handy with his hick’ry, and I couldn’t stand
it.
label: sadness

text: I was all over welts.
label: disgust

text:
He got to going away so much, too, and
locking me in.
label: disgust

text: Once he locked me in and was gone three days.
label: anger

text:
It was
dreadful lonesome.
label: sadness

text:
I judged he had got drownded, and I wasn’t ever
going to get out any more.
label: anger

text: I was scared.
label: fear

text:
I made up my mind I would fix
up some way to leave there.
label: neutral

text:
I had tried to get out of that cabin many a
time, but I couldn’t find no way.
label: sadness

text:
There warn’t a window to it big
enough for a dog to get through.
label: neutral

text:
I couldn’t get up the chimbly; it was
too narrow.
label: sadness

text: The door was thick, solid oak slabs.
label: disgust

text:
Pap was pretty careful
not to leave a knife or anything in the cabin when he was away; I
reckon I had hunted the place over as much as a hundred times; well, I
was most all the time at it, because it was about the only way to put
in the time.
label: neutral

text:
But this time I found something at last; I found an old
rusty wood-saw without any handle; it was laid in between a rafter and
the clapboards of the roof.
label: neutral

text: I greased it up and went to work.
label: neutral

text:
There was
an old horse-blanket nailed against the logs at the far end of the
cabin behind the table, to keep the wind from blowing through the
chinks and putting the candle out.
label: neutral

text:
I got under the table and raised the
blanket, and went to work to saw a section of the big bottom log
out—big enough to let me through.
label: surprise

text:
Well, it was a good long job, but I
was getting towards the end of it when I heard pap’s gun in the woods.
label: fear

text:
I got rid of the signs of my work, and dropped the blanket and hid my
saw, and pretty soon pap come in.
label: surprise

text: Pap warn’t in a good humor—so he was his natural self.
label: neutral

text:
He said he was
down town, and everything was going wrong.
label: fear

text:
His lawyer said he reckoned
he would win his lawsuit and get the money if they ever got started on
the trial; but then there was ways to put it off a long time, and Judge
Thatcher knowed how to do it.
label: neutral

text:
And he said people allowed there’d be
another trial to get me away from him and give me to the widow for my
guardian, and they guessed it would win this time.
label: neutral

text:
This shook me up
considerable, because I didn’t want to go back to the widow’s any more
and be so cramped up and sivilized, as they called it.
label: anger

text:
Then the old man
got to cussing, and cussed everything and everybody he could think of,
and then cussed them all over again to make sure he hadn’t skipped any,
and after that he polished off with a kind of a general cuss all round,
including a considerable parcel of people which he didn’t know the
names of, and so called them what’s-his-name when he got to them, and
went right along with his cussing.
label: neutral

text: He said he would like to see the widow get me.
label: sadness

text:
He said he would watch
out, and if they tried to come any such game on him he knowed of a
place six or seven mile off to stow me in, where they might hunt till
they dropped and they couldn’t find me.
label: neutral

text:
That made me pretty uneasy
again, but only for a minute; I reckoned I wouldn’t stay on hand till
he got that chance.
label: fear

text: The old man made me go to the skiff and fetch the things he had got.
label: disgust

text:
There was a fifty-pound sack of corn meal, and a side of bacon,
ammunition, and a four-gallon jug of whisky, and an old book and two
newspapers for wadding, besides some tow.
label: neutral

text:
I toted up a load, and went
back and set down on the bow of the skiff to rest.
label: neutral

text:
I thought it all
over, and I reckoned I would walk off with the gun and some lines, and
take to the woods when I run away.
label: fear

text:
I guessed I wouldn’t stay in one
place, but just tramp right across the country, mostly night times, and
hunt and fish to keep alive, and so get so far away that the old man
nor the widow couldn’t ever find me any more.
label: neutral

text:
I judged I would saw out
and leave that night if pap got drunk enough, and I reckoned he would.
label: neutral

text:
I got so full of it I didn’t notice how long I was staying till the old
man hollered and asked me whether I was asleep or drownded.
label: neutral

text: I got the things all up to the cabin, and then it was about dark.
label: surprise

text:
While
I was cooking supper the old man took a swig or two and got sort of
warmed up, and went to ripping again.
label: disgust

text:
He had been drunk over in town,
and laid in the gutter all night, and he was a sight to look at.
label: disgust

text:
A body
would a thought he was Adam—he was just all mud.
label: disgust

text:
Whenever his liquor
begun to work he most always went for the govment, this time he says:
label: neutral

text: “Call this a govment!
label: anger

text: why, just look at it and see what it’s like.
label: neutral

text:
Here’s the law a-standing ready to take a man’s son away from him—a
man’s own son, which he has had all the trouble and all the anxiety and
all the expense of raising.
label: neutral

text:
Yes, just as that man has got that son
raised at last, and ready to go to work and begin to do suthin’ for
_him_ and give him a rest, the law up and goes for him.
label: neutral

text:
And they call
_that_ govment!
label: surprise

text: That ain’t all, nuther.
label: neutral

text:
The law backs that old Judge
Thatcher up and helps him to keep me out o’ my property.
label: neutral

text:
Here’s what
the law does: The law takes a man worth six thousand dollars and
up’ards, and jams him into an old trap of a cabin like this, and lets
him go round in clothes that ain’t fitten for a hog.
label: neutral

text:
They call that
govment!
label: surprise

text: A man can’t get his rights in a govment like this.
label: disgust

text:
Sometimes
I’ve a mighty notion to just leave the country for good and all.
label: neutral

text:
Yes,
and I _told_ ’em so; I told old Thatcher so to his face.
label: neutral

text:
Lots of ’em
heard me, and can tell what I said.
label: neutral

text:
Says I, for two cents I’d leave the
blamed country and never come a-near it agin.
label: neutral

text: Them’s the very words.
label: neutral

text:
I
says look at my hat—if you call it a hat—but the lid raises up and the
rest of it goes down till it’s below my chin, and then it ain’t rightly
a hat at all, but more like my head was shoved up through a jint o’
stove-pipe.
label: neutral

text:
Look at it, says I—such a hat for me to wear—one of the
wealthiest men in this town if I could git my rights.
label: anger

text: “Oh, yes, this is a wonderful govment, wonderful.
label: joy

text: Why, looky here.
label: surprise

text:
There was a free nigger there from Ohio—a mulatter, most as white as a
white man.
label: disgust

text:
He had the whitest shirt on you ever see, too, and the
shiniest hat; and there ain’t a man in that town that’s got as fine
clothes as what he had; and he had a gold watch and chain, and a
silver-headed cane—the awfulest old gray-headed nabob in the State.
label: disgust

text:
And
what do you think?
label: surprise

text:
They said he was a p’fessor in a college, and could
talk all kinds of languages, and knowed everything.
label: neutral

text:
And that ain’t the
wust.
label: disgust

text: They said he could _vote_ when he was at home.
label: neutral

text:
Well, that let me
out.
label: neutral

text: Thinks I, what is the country a-coming to?
label: surprise

text:
It was ’lection day,
and I was just about to go and vote myself if I warn’t too drunk to get
there; but when they told me there was a State in this country where
they’d let that nigger vote, I drawed out.
label: neutral

text: I says I’ll never vote agin.
label: neutral

text:
Them’s the very words I said; they all heard me; and the country may
rot for all me—I’ll never vote agin as long as I live.
label: neutral

text:
And to see the
cool way of that nigger—why, he wouldn’t a give me the road if I hadn’t
shoved him out o’ the way.
label: neutral

text:
I says to the people, why ain’t this nigger
put up at auction and sold?—that’s what I want to know.
label: neutral

text:
And what do you
reckon they said?
label: surprise

text:
Why, they said he couldn’t be sold till he’d been in
the State six months, and he hadn’t been there that long yet.
label: neutral

text:
There,
now—that’s a specimen.
label: neutral

text:
They call that a govment that can’t sell a free
nigger till he’s been in the State six months.
label: neutral

text:
Here’s a govment that
calls itself a govment, and lets on to be a govment, and thinks it is a
govment, and yet’s got to set stock-still for six whole months before
it can take a hold of a prowling, thieving, infernal, white-shirted
free nigger, and—”
label: neutral

text:
Pap was agoing on so he never noticed where his old limber legs was
taking him to, so he went head over heels over the tub of salt pork and
barked both shins, and the rest of his speech was all the hottest kind
of language—mostly hove at the nigger and the govment, though he give
the tub some, too, all along, here and there.
label: neutral

text:
He hopped around the
cabin considerable, first on one leg and then on the other, holding
first one shin and then the other one, and at last he let out with his
left foot all of a sudden and fetched the tub a rattling kick.
label: fear

text:
But it
warn’t good judgment, because that was the boot that had a couple of
his toes leaking out of the front end of it; so now he raised a howl
that fairly made a body’s hair raise, and down he went in the dirt, and
rolled there, and held his toes; and the cussing he done then laid over
anything he had ever done previous.
label: neutral

text: He said so his own self afterwards.
label: neutral

text:
He had heard old Sowberry Hagan in his best days, and he said it laid
over him, too; but I reckon that was sort of piling it on, maybe.
label: neutral

text:
After supper pap took the jug, and said he had enough whisky there for
two drunks and one delirium tremens.
label: fear

text: That was always his word.
label: neutral

text:
I judged
he would be blind drunk in about an hour, and then I would steal the
key, or saw myself out, one or t’other.
label: disgust

text:
He drank and drank, and tumbled
down on his blankets by-and-by; but luck didn’t run my way.
label: disgust

text:
He didn’t
go sound asleep, but was uneasy.
label: fear

text:
He groaned and moaned and thrashed
around this way and that for a long time.
label: disgust

text:
At last I got so sleepy I
couldn’t keep my eyes open all I could do, and so before I knowed what
I was about I was sound asleep, and the candle burning.
label: anger

text:
I don’t know how long I was asleep, but all of a sudden there was an
awful scream and I was up.
label: fear

text:
There was pap looking wild, and skipping
around every which way and yelling about snakes.
label: disgust

text:
He said they was
crawling up his legs; and then he would give a jump and scream, and say
one had bit him on the cheek—but I couldn’t see no snakes.
label: neutral

text:
He started
and run round and round the cabin, hollering “Take him off!
label: anger

text:
take him
off!
label: anger

text:
he’s biting me on the neck!” I never see a man look so wild in the
eyes.
label: fear

text:
Pretty soon he was all fagged out, and fell down panting; then he
rolled over and over wonderful fast, kicking things every which way,
and striking and grabbing at the air with his hands, and screaming and
saying there was devils a-hold of him.
label: anger

text:
He wore out by-and-by, and laid
still a while, moaning.
label: sadness

text: Then he laid stiller, and didn’t make a sound.
label: disgust

text:
I could hear the owls and the wolves away off in the woods, and it
seemed terrible still.
label: fear

text: He was laying over by the corner.
label: disgust

text:
By-and-by he
raised up part way and listened, with his head to one side.
label: neutral

text:
He says,
very low:
label: neutral

text:
“Tramp—tramp—tramp; that’s the dead; tramp—tramp—tramp; they’re coming
after me; but I won’t go.
label: sadness

text: Oh, they’re here!
label: surprise

text: don’t touch me—don’t!
label: fear

text:
hands
off—they’re cold; let go.
label: anger

text: Oh, let a poor devil alone!”
label: anger

text:
Then he went down on all fours and crawled off, begging them to let him
alone, and he rolled himself up in his blanket and wallowed in under
the old pine table, still a-begging; and then he went to crying.
label: neutral

text:
I
could hear him through the blanket.
label: disgust

text:
By-and-by he rolled out and jumped up on his feet looking wild, and he
see me and went for me.
label: fear

text:
He chased me round and round the place with a
clasp-knife, calling me the Angel of Death, and saying he would kill
me, and then I couldn’t come for him no more.
label: anger

text:
I begged, and told him I
was only Huck; but he laughed _such_ a screechy laugh, and roared and
cussed, and kept on chasing me up.
label: anger

text:
Once when I turned short and dodged
under his arm he made a grab and got me by the jacket between my
shoulders, and I thought I was gone; but I slid out of the jacket quick
as lightning, and saved myself.
label: fear

text:
Pretty soon he was all tired out, and
dropped down with his back against the door, and said he would rest a
minute and then kill me.
label: anger

text:
He put his knife under him, and said he would
sleep and get strong, and then he would see who was who.
label: neutral

text: So he dozed off pretty soon.
label: neutral

text:
By-and-by I got the old split-bottom chair
and clumb up as easy as I could, not to make any noise, and got down
the gun.
label: fear

text:
I slipped the ramrod down it to make sure it was loaded, then
I laid it across the turnip barrel, pointing towards pap, and set down
behind it to wait for him to stir.
label: neutral

text:
And how slow and still the time did
drag along.
label: surprise

text: CHAPTER VII.
label: neutral

text: “Git up!
label: anger

text: What you ’bout?”
label: anger

text: I opened my eyes and looked around, trying to make out where I was.
label: fear

text:
It
was after sun-up, and I had been sound asleep.
label: neutral

text:
Pap was standing over me
looking sour and sick, too.
label: disgust

text: He says:
label: neutral

text: “What you doin’ with this gun?”
label: anger

text:
I judged he didn’t know nothing about what he had been doing, so I
says:
label: disgust

text: “Somebody tried to get in, so I was laying for him.”
label: anger

text: “Why didn’t you roust me out?”
label: anger

text: “Well, I tried to, but I couldn’t; I couldn’t budge you.”
label: fear

text: “Well, all right.
label: neutral

text:
Don’t stand there palavering all day, but out with
you and see if there’s a fish on the lines for breakfast.
label: neutral

text:
I’ll be along
in a minute.”
label: neutral

text: He unlocked the door, and I cleared out up the river-bank.
label: neutral

text:
I noticed
some pieces of limbs and such things floating down, and a sprinkling of
bark; so I knowed the river had begun to rise.
label: disgust

text:
I reckoned I would have
great times now if I was over at the town.
label: neutral

text:
The June rise used to be
always luck for me; because as soon as that rise begins here comes
cordwood floating down, and pieces of log rafts—sometimes a dozen logs
together; so all you have to do is to catch them and sell them to the
wood-yards and the sawmill.
label: neutral

text:
I went along up the bank with one eye out for pap and t’other one out
for what the rise might fetch along.
label: neutral

text:
Well, all at once here comes a
canoe; just a beauty, too, about thirteen or fourteen foot long, riding
high like a duck.
label: neutral

text:
I shot head-first off of the bank like a frog,
clothes and all on, and struck out for the canoe.
label: fear

text:
I just expected
there’d be somebody laying down in it, because people often done that
to fool folks, and when a chap had pulled a skiff out most to it they’d
raise up and laugh at him.
label: neutral

text: But it warn’t so this time.
label: neutral

text:
It was a
drift-canoe sure enough, and I clumb in and paddled her ashore.
label: neutral

text:
Thinks
I, the old man will be glad when he sees this—she’s worth ten dollars.
label: joy

text:
But when I got to shore pap wasn’t in sight yet, and as I was running
her into a little creek like a gully, all hung over with vines and
willows, I struck another idea: I judged I’d hide her good, and then,
’stead of taking to the woods when I run off, I’d go down the river
about fifty mile and camp in one place for good, and not have such a
rough time tramping on foot.
label: fear

text:
It was pretty close to the shanty, and I thought I heard the old man
coming all the time; but I got her hid; and then I out and looked
around a bunch of willows, and there was the old man down the path a
piece just drawing a bead on a bird with his gun.
label: surprise

text:
So he hadn’t seen
anything.
label: neutral

text: When he got along I was hard at it taking up a “trot” line.
label: neutral

text:
He abused
me a little for being so slow; but I told him I fell in the river, and
that was what made me so long.
label: disgust

text:
I knowed he would see I was wet, and
then he would be asking questions.
label: neutral

text:
We got five catfish off the lines
and went home.
label: neutral

text:
While we laid off after breakfast to sleep up, both of us being about
wore out, I got to thinking that if I could fix up some way to keep pap
and the widow from trying to follow me, it would be a certainer thing
than trusting to luck to get far enough off before they missed me; you
see, all kinds of things might happen.
label: neutral

text:
Well, I didn’t see no way for a
while, but by-and-by pap raised up a minute to drink another barrel of
water, and he says:
label: neutral

text:
“Another time a man comes a-prowling round here you roust me out, you
hear?
label: anger

text: That man warn’t here for no good.
label: neutral

text: I’d a shot him.
label: fear

text:
Next time you
roust me out, you hear?”
label: neutral

text:
Then he dropped down and went to sleep again; but what he had been
saying give me the very idea I wanted.
label: neutral

text:
I says to myself, I can fix it
now so nobody won’t think of following me.
label: neutral

text: About twelve o’clock we turned out and went along up the bank.
label: neutral

text:
The
river was coming up pretty fast, and lots of driftwood going by on the
rise.
label: surprise

text: By-and-by along comes part of a log raft—nine logs fast together.
label: neutral

text: We went out with the skiff and towed it ashore.
label: fear

text: Then we had dinner.
label: neutral

text:
Anybody but pap would a waited and seen the day through, so as to catch
more stuff; but that warn’t pap’s style.
label: neutral

text:
Nine logs was enough for one
time; he must shove right over to town and sell.
label: neutral

text:
So he locked me in and
took the skiff, and started off towing the raft about half-past three.
label: neutral

text: I judged he wouldn’t come back that night.
label: neutral

text:
I waited till I reckoned he
had got a good start; then I out with my saw, and went to work on that
log again.
label: neutral

text:
Before he was t’other side of the river I was out of the
hole; him and his raft was just a speck on the water away off yonder.
label: fear

text:
I took the sack of corn meal and took it to where the canoe was hid,
and shoved the vines and branches apart and put it in; then I done the
same with the side of bacon; then the whisky-jug.
label: neutral

text:
I took all the coffee
and sugar there was, and all the ammunition; I took the wadding; I took
the bucket and gourd; I took a dipper and a tin cup, and my old saw and
two blankets, and the skillet and the coffee-pot.
label: neutral

text:
I took fish-lines and
matches and other things—everything that was worth a cent.
label: neutral

text:
I cleaned
out the place.
label: disgust

text:
I wanted an axe, but there wasn’t any, only the one out
at the woodpile, and I knowed why I was going to leave that.
label: surprise

text:
I fetched
out the gun, and now I was done.
label: surprise

text:
I had wore the ground a good deal crawling out of the hole and dragging
out so many things.
label: neutral

text:
So I fixed that as good as I could from the outside
by scattering dust on the place, which covered up the smoothness and
the sawdust.
label: disgust

text:
Then I fixed the piece of log back into its place, and put
two rocks under it and one against it to hold it there, for it was bent
up at that place and didn’t quite touch ground.
label: neutral

text:
If you stood four or
five foot away and didn’t know it was sawed, you wouldn’t never notice
it; and besides, this was the back of the cabin, and it warn’t likely
anybody would go fooling around there.
label: neutral

text: It was all grass clear to the canoe, so I hadn’t left a track.
label: neutral

text:
I
followed around to see.
label: neutral

text:
I stood on the bank and looked out over the
river.
label: fear

text: All safe.
label: neutral

text:
So I took the gun and went up a piece into the woods,
and was hunting around for some birds when I see a wild pig; hogs soon
went wild in them bottoms after they had got away from the prairie
farms.
label: fear

text: I shot this fellow and took him into camp.
label: anger

text: I took the axe and smashed in the door.
label: anger

text:
I beat it and hacked it
considerable a-doing it.
label: anger

text:
I fetched the pig in, and took him back nearly
to the table and hacked into his throat with the axe, and laid him down
on the ground to bleed; I say ground because it _was_ ground—hard
packed, and no boards.
label: sadness

text:
Well, next I took an old sack and put a lot of
big rocks in it—all I could drag—and I started it from the pig, and
dragged it to the door and through the woods down to the river and
dumped it in, and down it sunk, out of sight.
label: fear

text:
You could easy see that
something had been dragged over the ground.
label: disgust

text:
I did wish Tom Sawyer was
there; I knowed he would take an interest in this kind of business, and
throw in the fancy touches.
label: neutral

text:
Nobody could spread himself like Tom Sawyer
in such a thing as that.
label: neutral

text:
Well, last I pulled out some of my hair, and blooded the axe good, and
stuck it on the back side, and slung the axe in the corner.
label: anger

text:
Then I took
up the pig and held him to my breast with my jacket (so he couldn’t
drip) till I got a good piece below the house and then dumped him into
the river.
label: fear

text: Now I thought of something else.
label: neutral

text:
So I went and got the bag
of meal and my old saw out of the canoe, and fetched them to the house.
label: neutral

text:
I took the bag to where it used to stand, and ripped a hole in the
bottom of it with the saw, for there warn’t no knives and forks on the
place—pap done everything with his clasp-knife about the cooking.
label: neutral

text:
Then
I carried the sack about a hundred yards across the grass and through
the willows east of the house, to a shallow lake that was five mile
wide and full of rushes—and ducks too, you might say, in the season.
label: neutral

text:
There was a slough or a creek leading out of it on the other side that
went miles away, I don’t know where, but it didn’t go to the river.
label: neutral

text:
The
meal sifted out and made a little track all the way to the lake.
label: neutral

text:
I
dropped pap’s whetstone there too, so as to look like it had been done
by accident.
label: neutral

text:
Then I tied up the rip in the meal sack with a string, so
it wouldn’t leak no more, and took it and my saw to the canoe again.
label: neutral

text:
It was about dark now; so I dropped the canoe down the river under some
willows that hung over the bank, and waited for the moon to rise.
label: fear

text:
I
made fast to a willow; then I took a bite to eat, and by-and-by laid
down in the canoe to smoke a pipe and lay out a plan.
label: disgust

text:
I says to myself,
they’ll follow the track of that sackful of rocks to the shore and then
drag the river for me.
label: neutral

text:
And they’ll follow that meal track to the lake
and go browsing down the creek that leads out of it to find the robbers
that killed me and took the things.
label: neutral

text:
They won’t ever hunt the river for
anything but my dead carcass.
label: disgust

text:
They’ll soon get tired of that, and won’t
bother no more about me.
label: neutral

text: All right; I can stop anywhere I want to.
label: anger

text:
Jackson’s Island is good enough for me; I know that island pretty well,
and nobody ever comes there.
label: neutral

text:
And then I can paddle over to town nights,
and slink around and pick up things I want.
label: neutral

text:
Jackson’s Island’s the
place.
label: neutral

text: I was pretty tired, and the first thing I knowed I was asleep.
label: surprise

text:
When I
woke up I didn’t know where I was for a minute.
label: surprise

text:
I set up and looked
around, a little scared.
label: fear

text: Then I remembered.
label: surprise

text:
The river looked miles and
miles across.
label: fear

text:
The moon was so bright I could a counted the drift logs
that went a-slipping along, black and still, hundreds of yards out from
shore.
label: neutral

text: Everything was dead quiet, and it looked late, and _smelt_ late.
label: sadness

text: You know what I mean—I don’t know the words to put it in.
label: surprise

text:
I took a good gap and a stretch, and was just going to unhitch and
start when I heard a sound away over the water.
label: fear

text: I listened.
label: neutral

text:
Pretty soon
I made it out.
label: joy

text:
It was that dull kind of a regular sound that comes from
oars working in rowlocks when it’s a still night.
label: sadness

text:
I peeped out through
the willow branches, and there it was—a skiff, away across the water.
label: fear

text:
I
couldn’t tell how many was in it.
label: surprise

text:
It kept a-coming, and when it was
abreast of me I see there warn’t but one man in it.
label: fear

text:
Think’s I, maybe
it’s pap, though I warn’t expecting him.
label: neutral

text:
He dropped below me with the
current, and by-and-by he came a-swinging up shore in the easy water,
and he went by so close I could a reached out the gun and touched him.
label: fear

text:
Well, it _was_ pap, sure enough—and sober, too, by the way he laid his
oars.
label: neutral

text: I didn’t lose no time.
label: neutral

text:
The next minute I was a-spinning down stream
soft but quick in the shade of the bank.
label: surprise

text:
I made two mile and a half,
and then struck out a quarter of a mile or more towards the middle of
the river, because pretty soon I would be passing the ferry landing,
and people might see me and hail me.
label: fear

text:
I got out amongst the driftwood,
and then laid down in the bottom of the canoe and let her float.
label: fear

text:
I laid there, and had a good rest and a smoke out of my pipe, looking
away into the sky; not a cloud in it.
label: disgust

text:
The sky looks ever so deep when
you lay down on your back in the moonshine; I never knowed it before.
label: fear

text: And how far a body can hear on the water such nights!
label: surprise

text:
I heard people
talking at the ferry landing.
label: disgust

text:
I heard what they said, too—every word of
it.
label: neutral

text:
One man said it was getting towards the long days and the short
nights now.
label: neutral

text:
T’other one said _this_ warn’t one of the short ones, he
reckoned—and then they laughed, and he said it over again, and they
laughed again; then they waked up another fellow and told him, and
laughed, but he didn’t laugh; he ripped out something brisk, and said
let him alone.
label: neutral

text:
The first fellow said he ’lowed to tell it to his old
woman—she would think it was pretty good; but he said that warn’t
nothing to some things he had said in his time.
label: neutral

text:
I heard one man say it
was nearly three o’clock, and he hoped daylight wouldn’t wait more than
about a week longer.
label: neutral

text:
After that the talk got further and further away,
and I couldn’t make out the words any more; but I could hear the
mumble, and now and then a laugh, too, but it seemed a long ways off.
label: neutral

text: I was away below the ferry now.
label: fear

text:
I rose up, and there was Jackson’s
Island, about two mile and a half down stream, heavy timbered and
standing up out of the middle of the river, big and dark and solid,
like a steamboat without any lights.
label: fear

text:
There warn’t any signs of the bar
at the head—it was all under water now.
label: neutral

text: It didn’t take me long to get there.
label: neutral

text:
I shot past the head at a ripping
rate, the current was so swift, and then I got into the dead water and
landed on the side towards the Illinois shore.
label: fear

text:
I run the canoe into a
deep dent in the bank that I knowed about; I had to part the willow
branches to get in; and when I made fast nobody could a seen the canoe
from the outside.
label: fear

text:
I went up and set down on a log at the head of the island, and looked
out on the big river and the black driftwood and away over to the town,
three mile away, where there was three or four lights twinkling.
label: fear

text:
A
monstrous big lumber-raft was about a mile up stream, coming along
down, with a lantern in the middle of it.
label: fear

text:
I watched it come creeping
down, and when it was most abreast of where I stood I heard a man say,
“Stern oars, there!
label: fear

text:
heave her head to stabboard!” I heard that just as
plain as if the man was by my side.
label: disgust

text:
There was a little gray in the sky now; so I stepped into the woods,
and laid down for a nap before breakfast.
label: fear

text: CHAPTER VIII.
label: neutral

text:
The sun was up so high when I waked that I judged it was after eight
o’clock.
label: neutral

text:
I laid there in the grass and the cool shade thinking about
things, and feeling rested and ruther comfortable and satisfied.
label: joy

text:
I
could see the sun out at one or two holes, but mostly it was big trees
all about, and gloomy in there amongst them.
label: sadness

text:
There was freckled places
on the ground where the light sifted down through the leaves, and the
freckled places swapped about a little, showing there was a little
breeze up there.
label: neutral

text:
A couple of squirrels set on a limb and jabbered at me
very friendly.
label: disgust

text:
I was powerful lazy and comfortable—didn’t want to get up and cook
breakfast.
label: sadness

text:
Well, I was dozing off again when I thinks I hears a deep
sound of “boom!” away up the river.
label: fear

text:
I rouses up, and rests on my elbow
and listens; pretty soon I hears it again.
label: surprise

text:
I hopped up, and went and
looked out at a hole in the leaves, and I see a bunch of smoke laying
on the water a long ways up—about abreast the ferry.
label: fear

text:
And there was the
ferry-boat full of people floating along down.
label: surprise

text:
I knowed what was the
matter now.
label: neutral

text:
“Boom!” I see the white smoke squirt out of the ferry-boat’s
side.
label: disgust

text:
You see, they was firing cannon over the water, trying to make my
carcass come to the top.
label: disgust

text:
I was pretty hungry, but it warn’t going to do for me to start a fire,
because they might see the smoke.
label: fear

text:
So I set there and watched the
cannon-smoke and listened to the boom.
label: neutral

text:
The river was a mile wide there,
and it always looks pretty on a summer morning—so I was having a good
enough time seeing them hunt for my remainders if I only had a bite to
eat.
label: neutral

text:
Well, then I happened to think how they always put quicksilver in
loaves of bread and float them off, because they always go right to the
drownded carcass and stop there.
label: neutral

text:
So, says I, I’ll keep a lookout, and
if any of them’s floating around after me I’ll give them a show.
label: neutral

text:
I
changed to the Illinois edge of the island to see what luck I could
have, and I warn’t disappointed.
label: sadness

text:
A big double loaf come along, and I
most got it with a long stick, but my foot slipped and she floated out
further.
label: neutral

text:
Of course I was where the current set in the closest to the
shore—I knowed enough for that.
label: neutral

text:
But by-and-by along comes another one,
and this time I won.
label: surprise

text:
I took out the plug and shook out the little dab
of quicksilver, and set my teeth in.
label: disgust

text:
It was “baker’s bread”—what the
quality eat; none of your low-down corn-pone.
label: neutral

text:
I got a good place amongst the leaves, and set there on a log, munching
the bread and watching the ferry-boat, and very well satisfied.
label: joy

text:
And
then something struck me.
label: fear

text:
I says, now I reckon the widow or the parson
or somebody prayed that this bread would find me, and here it has gone
and done it.
label: surprise

text:
So there ain’t no doubt but there is something in that
thing—that is, there’s something in it when a body like the widow or
the parson prays, but it don’t work for me, and I reckon it don’t work
for only just the right kind.
label: neutral

text: I lit a pipe and had a good long smoke, and went on watching.
label: disgust

text:
The
ferry-boat was floating with the current, and I allowed I’d have a
chance to see who was aboard when she come along, because she would
come in close, where the bread did.
label: neutral

text:
When she’d got pretty well along
down towards me, I put out my pipe and went to where I fished out the
bread, and laid down behind a log on the bank in a little open place.
label: neutral

text: Where the log forked I could peep through.
label: fear

text:
By-and-by she come along, and she drifted in so close that they could a
run out a plank and walked ashore.
label: fear

text: Most everybody was on the boat.
label: neutral

text:
Pap,
and Judge Thatcher, and Bessie Thatcher, and Jo Harper, and Tom Sawyer,
and his old Aunt Polly, and Sid and Mary, and plenty more.
label: neutral

text:
Everybody
was talking about the murder, but the captain broke in and says:
label: anger

text:
“Look sharp, now; the current sets in the closest here, and maybe he’s
washed ashore and got tangled amongst the brush at the water’s edge.
label: neutral

text:
I
hope so, anyway.”
label: neutral

text: I didn’t hope so.
label: neutral

text:
They all crowded up and leaned over the rails, nearly
in my face, and kept still, watching with all their might.
label: anger

text:
I could see
them first-rate, but they couldn’t see me.
label: fear

text: Then the captain sung out:
label: neutral

text:
“Stand away!” and the cannon let off such a blast right before me that
it made me deef with the noise and pretty near blind with the smoke,
and I judged I was gone.
label: fear

text:
If they’d a had some bullets in, I reckon
they’d a got the corpse they was after.
label: neutral

text:
Well, I see I warn’t hurt,
thanks to goodness.
label: neutral

text:
The boat floated on and went out of sight around
the shoulder of the island.
label: fear

text:
I could hear the booming now and then,
further and further off, and by-and-by, after an hour, I didn’t hear it
no more.
label: surprise

text: The island was three mile long.
label: neutral

text:
I judged they had got to the
foot, and was giving it up.
label: neutral

text: But they didn’t yet a while.
label: neutral

text:
They turned
around the foot of the island and started up the channel on the
Missouri side, under steam, and booming once in a while as they went.
label: neutral

text:
I
crossed over to that side and watched them.
label: neutral

text:
When they got abreast the
head of the island they quit shooting and dropped over to the Missouri
shore and went home to the town.
label: neutral

text: I knowed I was all right now.
label: neutral

text:
Nobody else would come a-hunting after
me.
label: neutral

text:
I got my traps out of the canoe and made me a nice camp in the
thick woods.
label: neutral

text:
I made a kind of a tent out of my blankets to put my
things under so the rain couldn’t get at them.
label: neutral

text:
I catched a catfish and
haggled him open with my saw, and towards sundown I started my camp
fire and had supper.
label: disgust

text:
Then I set out a line to catch some fish for
breakfast.
label: neutral

text:
When it was dark I set by my camp fire smoking, and feeling pretty well
satisfied; but by-and-by it got sort of lonesome, and so I went and set
on the bank and listened to the current swashing along, and counted the
stars and drift logs and rafts that come down, and then went to bed;
there ain’t no better way to put in time when you are lonesome; you
can’t stay so, you soon get over it.
label: joy

text: And so for three days and nights.
label: neutral

text: No difference—just the same thing.
label: neutral

text: But the next day I went exploring around down through the island.
label: fear

text:
I was
boss of it; it all belonged to me, so to say, and I wanted to know all
about it; but mainly I wanted to put in the time.
label: neutral

text:
I found plenty
strawberries, ripe and prime; and green summer grapes, and green
razberries; and the green blackberries was just beginning to show.
label: neutral

text:
They
would all come handy by-and-by, I judged.
label: neutral

text:
Well, I went fooling along in the deep woods till I judged I warn’t far
from the foot of the island.
label: fear

text:
I had my gun along, but I hadn’t shot
nothing; it was for protection; thought I would kill some game nigh
home.
label: fear

text:
About this time I mighty near stepped on a good-sized snake, and
it went sliding off through the grass and flowers, and I after it,
trying to get a shot at it.
label: neutral

text:
I clipped along, and all of a sudden I
bounded right on to the ashes of a camp fire that was still smoking.
label: surprise

text: My heart jumped up amongst my lungs.
label: fear

text:
I never waited for to look
further, but uncocked my gun and went sneaking back on my tiptoes as
fast as ever I could.
label: fear

text:
Every now and then I stopped a second amongst the
thick leaves and listened, but my breath come so hard I couldn’t hear
nothing else.
label: fear

text:
I slunk along another piece further, then listened again;
and so on, and so on.
label: neutral

text:
If I see a stump, I took it for a man; if I trod
on a stick and broke it, it made me feel like a person had cut one of
my breaths in two and I only got half, and the short half, too.
label: disgust

text:
When I got to camp I warn’t feeling very brash, there warn’t much sand
in my craw; but I says, this ain’t no time to be fooling around.
label: fear

text:
So I
got all my traps into my canoe again so as to have them out of sight,
and I put out the fire and scattered the ashes around to look like an
old last year’s camp, and then clumb a tree.
label: neutral

text:
I reckon I was up in the tree two hours; but I didn’t see nothing, I
didn’t hear nothing—I only _thought_ I heard and seen as much as a
thousand things.
label: surprise

text:
Well, I couldn’t stay up there forever; so at last I
got down, but I kept in the thick woods and on the lookout all the
time.
label: fear

text:
All I could get to eat was berries and what was left over from
breakfast.
label: neutral

text: By the time it was night I was pretty hungry.
label: disgust

text:
So when it was good and
dark I slid out from shore before moonrise and paddled over to the
Illinois bank—about a quarter of a mile.
label: fear

text:
I went out in the woods and
cooked a supper, and I had about made up my mind I would stay there all
night when I hear a _plunkety-plunk, plunkety-plunk_, and says to
myself, horses coming; and next I hear people’s voices.
label: surprise

text:
I got
everything into the canoe as quick as I could, and then went creeping
through the woods to see what I could find out.
label: fear

text:
I hadn’t got far when I
hear a man say:
label: neutral

text:
“We better camp here if we can find a good place; the horses is about
beat out.
label: neutral

text: Let’s look around.”
label: neutral

text: I didn’t wait, but shoved out and paddled away easy.
label: anger

text:
I tied up in the
old place, and reckoned I would sleep in the canoe.
label: disgust

text: I didn’t sleep much.
label: sadness

text: I couldn’t, somehow, for thinking.
label: surprise

text:
And every time
I waked up I thought somebody had me by the neck.
label: fear

text:
So the sleep didn’t
do me no good.
label: sadness

text:
By-and-by I says to myself, I can’t live this way; I’m
a-going to find out who it is that’s here on the island with me; I’ll
find it out or bust.
label: neutral

text: Well, I felt better right off.
label: joy

text:
So I took my paddle and slid out from shore just a step or two, and
then let the canoe drop along down amongst the shadows.
label: fear

text:
The moon was
shining, and outside of the shadows it made it most as light as day.
label: neutral

text:
I
poked along well on to an hour, everything still as rocks and sound
asleep.
label: neutral

text: Well, by this time I was most down to the foot of the island.
label: neutral

text:
A
little ripply, cool breeze begun to blow, and that was as good as
saying the night was about done.
label: joy

text:
I give her a turn with the paddle and
brung her nose to shore; then I got my gun and slipped out and into the
edge of the woods.
label: fear

text:
I sat down there on a log, and looked out through
the leaves.
label: fear

text:
I see the moon go off watch, and the darkness begin to
blanket the river.
label: fear

text:
But in a little while I see a pale streak over the
treetops, and knowed the day was coming.
label: neutral

text:
So I took my gun and slipped
off towards where I had run across that camp fire, stopping every
minute or two to listen.
label: fear

text:
But I hadn’t no luck somehow; I couldn’t seem
to find the place.
label: surprise

text:
But by-and-by, sure enough, I catched a glimpse of
fire away through the trees.
label: fear

text: I went for it, cautious and slow.
label: fear

text:
By-and-by I was close enough to have a look, and there laid a man on
the ground.
label: fear

text: It most give me the fan-tods.
label: neutral

text:
He had a blanket around his
head, and his head was nearly in the fire.
label: fear

text:
I set there behind a clump
of bushes, in about six foot of him, and kept my eyes on him steady.
label: disgust

text:
It
was getting gray daylight now.
label: neutral

text:
Pretty soon he gapped and stretched
himself and hove off the blanket, and it was Miss Watson’s Jim!
label: surprise

text:
I bet I
was glad to see him.
label: joy

text: I says:
label: neutral

text: “Hello, Jim!” and skipped out.
label: sadness

text: He bounced up and stared at me wild.
label: anger

text:
Then he drops down on his knees,
and puts his hands together and says:
label: neutral

text: “Doan’ hurt me—don’t!
label: fear

text: I hain’t ever done no harm to a ghos’.
label: disgust

text:
I alwuz
liked dead people, en done all I could for ’em.
label: joy

text:

text: CHAPTER IX.
label: neutral

text:
I wanted to go and look at a place right about the middle of the island
that I’d found when I was exploring; so we started and soon got to it,
because the island was only three miles long and a quarter of a mile
wide.
label: neutral

text:
This place was a tolerable long, steep hill or ridge about forty foot
high.
label: neutral

text:
We had a rough time getting to the top, the sides was so steep
and the bushes so thick.
label: fear

text:
We tramped and clumb around all over it, and
by-and-by found a good big cavern in the rock, most up to the top on
the side towards Illinois.
label: disgust

text:
The cavern was as big as two or three rooms
bunched together, and Jim could stand up straight in it.
label: neutral

text:
It was cool in
there.
label: joy

text:
Jim was for putting our traps in there right away, but I said we
didn’t want to be climbing up and down there all the time.
label: neutral

text:
Jim said if we had the canoe hid in a good place, and had all the traps
in the cavern, we could rush there if anybody was to come to the
island, and they would never find us without dogs.
label: neutral

text:
And, besides, he
said them little birds had said it was going to rain, and did I want
the things to get wet?
label: neutral

text:
So we went back and got the canoe, and paddled up abreast the cavern,
and lugged all the traps up there.
label: neutral

text:
Then we hunted up a place close by
to hide the canoe in, amongst the thick willows.
label: fear

text:
We took some fish off
of the lines and set them again, and begun to get ready for dinner.
label: neutral

text:
The door of the cavern was big enough to roll a hogshead in, and on one
side of the door the floor stuck out a little bit, and was flat and a
good place to build a fire on.
label: disgust

text: So we built it there and cooked dinner.
label: neutral

text:
We spread the blankets inside for a carpet, and eat our dinner in
there.
label: neutral

text: We put all the other things handy at the back of the cavern.
label: neutral

text:
Pretty soon it darkened up, and begun to thunder and lighten; so the
birds was right about it.
label: neutral

text:
Directly it begun to rain, and it rained like
all fury, too, and I never see the wind blow so.
label: anger

text:
It was one of these
regular summer storms.
label: neutral

text:
It would get so dark that it looked all
blue-black outside, and lovely; and the rain would thrash along by so
thick that the trees off a little ways looked dim and spider-webby; and
here would come a blast of wind that would bend the trees down and turn
up the pale underside of the leaves; and then a perfect ripper of a
gust would follow along and set the branches to tossing their arms as
if they was just wild; and next, when it was just about the bluest and
blackest—_fst!_ it was as bright as glory, and you’d have a little
glimpse of tree-tops a-plunging about away off yonder in the storm,
hundreds of yards further than you could see before; dark as sin again
in a second, and now you’d hear the thunder let go with an awful crash,
and then go rumbling, grumbling, tumbling, down the sky towards the
under side of the world, like rolling empty barrels down stairs—where
it’s long stairs and they bounce a good deal, you know.
label: fear

text: “Jim, this is nice,” I says.
label: joy

text:
“I wouldn’t want to be nowhere else but
here.
label: neutral

text: Pass me along another hunk of fish and some hot corn-bread.”
label: disgust

text: “Well, you wouldn’t a ben here ’f it hadn’t a ben for Jim.
label: neutral
neutral

text:
Chickens knows when it’s gwyne to rain, en so do
de birds, chile.”
label: neutral

text:
The river went on raising and raising for ten or twelve days, till at
last it was over the banks.
label: fear

text:
The water was three or four foot deep on
the island in the low places and on the Illinois bottom.
label: fear

text:
On that side
it was a good many miles wide, but on the Missouri side it was the same
old distance across—a half a mile—because the Missouri shore was just a
wall of high bluffs.
label: neutral

text:
Daytimes we paddled all over the island in the canoe, It was mighty
cool and shady in the deep woods, even if the sun was blazing outside.
label: joy

text:
We went winding in and out amongst the trees, and sometimes the vines
hung so thick we had to back away and go some other way.
label: fear

text:
Well, on every
old broken-down tree you could see rabbits and snakes and such things;
and when the island had been overflowed a day or two they got so tame,
on account of being hungry, that you could paddle right up and put your
hand on them if you wanted to; but not the snakes and turtles—they
would slide off in the water.
label: neutral

text:
The ridge our cavern was in was full of
them.
label: fear

text: We could a had pets enough if we’d wanted them.
label: neutral

text:
One night we catched a little section of a lumber raft—nice pine
planks.
label: disgust

text:
It was twelve foot wide and about fifteen or sixteen foot long,
and the top stood above water six or seven inches—a solid, level floor.
label: fear

text:
We could see saw-logs go by in the daylight sometimes, but we let them
go; we didn’t show ourselves in daylight.
label: neutral

text:
Another night when we was up at the head of the island, just before
daylight, here comes a frame-house down, on the west side.
label: surprise

text:
She was a
two-story, and tilted over considerable.
label: surprise

text:
We paddled out and got
aboard—clumb in at an upstairs window.

text:
But it was too dark to see yet,
so we made the canoe fast and set in her to wait for daylight.
label: fear

text: The light begun to come before we got to the foot of the island.
label: fear

text:
Then
we looked in at the window.
label: fear

text:
We could make out a bed, and a table, and
two old chairs, and lots of things around about on the floor, and there
was clothes hanging against the wall.
label: neutral

text:
There was something laying on the
floor in the far corner that looked like a man.
label: disgust

text: So Jim says:
label: neutral

text: “Hello, you!”
label: neutral

text: But it didn’t budge.
label: anger

text: So I hollered again, and then Jim says:

text: “De man ain’t asleep—he’s dead.
label: disgust

text: You hold still—I’ll go en see.”
label: neutral

text: He went, and bent down and looked, and says:
label: neutral

text: “It’s a dead man.
label: disgust

text: Yes, indeedy; naked, too.
label: neutral

text: He’s ben shot in de back.
label: neutral

text:
I

label: sadness

text:
Come in, Huck, but doan’ look

label: neutral

text: I didn’t look at him at all.
label: disgust

text:
Jim throwed some old rags over him, but he

label: sadness

text:
There was heaps of old
greasy cards scattered around over the floor, and old whisky bottles,

label: disgust

text:
There was two old dirty calico dresses, and a sun-bonnet, and some

label: neutral

text: We put the lot into the canoe—it might come good.
label: joy

text:
There was a
boy’s old speckled straw hat on the floor; I took that, too.
label: disgust

text:
And there
was a bottle that had had milk in it, and it had a rag stopper for a

label: disgust

text: We would a took the bottle, but it was broke.
label: sadness

text:
There was a
seedy old chest, and an old hair trunk with the hinges broke.
label: disgust

text:
They
stood open, but there warn’t nothing left in them that was any account.
label: neutral

text:
The way things was scattered about we reckoned the people left in a
hurry, and warn’t fixed so as to carry off most of their stuff.
label: neutral

text:
We got an old tin lantern, and a butcher-knife without any handle, and
a bran-new Barlow knife worth two bits in any store, and a lot of
tallow candles, and a tin candlestick, and a gourd, and a tin cup, and
a ratty old bedquilt off the bed, and a reticule with needles and pins
and beeswax and buttons and thread and all such truck in it, and a
hatchet and some nails, and a fishline as thick as my little finger
with some monstrous hooks on it, and a roll of buckskin, and a leather
dog-collar, and a horseshoe, and some vials of medicine that didn’t
have no label on them; and just as we was leaving I found a tolerable
good curry-comb, and Jim he found a ratty old fiddle-bow, and a wooden
leg.
label: neutral

text:
