Elexander before you go, and then get out by saying it’s George
Elexander when I catch you.
label: neutral

text:
And don’t go about women in that old
calico.
label: anger

text: You do a girl tolerable poor, but you might fool men, maybe.
label: disgust

text:
Bless you, child, when you set out to thread a needle don’t hold the
thread still and fetch the needle up to it; hold the needle still and
poke the thread at it; that’s the way a woman most always does, but a
man always does t’other way.
label: neutral

text:
And when you throw at a rat or anything,
hitch yourself up a tiptoe and fetch your hand up over your head as
awkward as you can, and miss your rat about six or seven foot.
label: neutral

text:
Throw
stiff-armed from the shoulder, like there was a pivot there for it to
turn on, like a girl; not from the wrist and elbow, with your arm out
to one side, like a boy.
label: neutral

text:
And, mind you, when a girl tries to catch
anything in her lap she throws her knees apart; she don’t clap them
together, the way you did when you catched the lump of lead.
label: disgust

text:
Why, I
spotted you for a boy when you was threading the needle; and I
contrived the other things just to make certain.
label: neutral

text:
Now trot along to your
uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into
trouble you send word to Mrs. Judith Loftus, which is me, and I’ll do
what I can to get you out of it.
label: neutral

text:
Keep the river road all the way, and
next time you tramp take shoes and socks with you.
label: neutral

text:
The river road’s a
rocky one, and your feet’ll be in a condition when you get to Goshen, I
reckon.”
label: neutral

text:
I went up the bank about fifty yards, and then I doubled on my tracks
and slipped back to where my canoe was, a good piece below the house.
label: fear

text:
I
jumped in, and was off in a hurry.
label: surprise

text:
I went up-stream far enough to make
the head of the island, and then started across.
label: neutral

text:
I took off the
sun-bonnet, for I didn’t want no blinders on then.
label: neutral

text:
When I was about the
middle I heard the clock begin to strike, so I stops and listens; the
sound come faint over the water but clear—eleven.
label: fear

text:
When I struck the
head of the island I never waited to blow, though I was most winded,
but I shoved right into the timber where my old camp used to be, and
started a good fire there on a high and dry spot.
label: fear

text:
Then I jumped in the canoe and dug out for our place, a mile and a half
below, as hard as I could go.
label: fear

text:
I landed, and slopped through the timber
and up the ridge and into the cavern.
label: fear

text:
There Jim laid, sound asleep on
the ground.
label: sadness

text: I roused him out and says:
label: neutral

text: “Git up and hump yourself, Jim!
label: anger

text: There ain’t a minute to lose.
label: neutral

text:
They’re
after us!”
label: anger

text:
Jim never asked no questions, he never said a word; but the way he
worked for the next half an hour showed about how he was scared.
label: fear

text:
By
that time everything we had in the world was on our raft, and she was
ready to be shoved out from the willow cove where she was hid.
label: fear

text:
We put
out the camp fire at the cavern the first thing, and didn’t show a
candle outside after that.
label: neutral
sadness

text:
Then we got out the raft and slipped along down
in the shade, past the foot of the island dead still—never saying a
word.
label: fear

text: CHAPTER XII.
label: neutral

text:
It must a been close on to one o’clock when we got below the island at
last, and the raft did seem to go mighty slow.
label: neutral

text:
If a boat was to come
along we was going to take to the canoe and break for the Illinois
shore; and it was well a boat didn’t come, for we hadn’t ever thought
to put the gun in the canoe, or a fishing-line, or anything to eat.
label: fear

text:
We
was in ruther too much of a sweat to think of so many things.
label: neutral

text:
It warn’t
good judgment to put _everything_ on the raft.
label: neutral

text:
If the men went to the island I just expect they found the camp fire I
built, and watched it all night for Jim to come.
label: neutral

text:
Anyways, they stayed
away from us, and if my building the fire never fooled them it warn’t
no fault of mine.
label: neutral

text: I played it as low down on them as I could.
label: neutral

text:
When the first streak of day began to show we tied up to a tow-head in a
big bend on the Illinois side, and hacked off cottonwood branches with
the hatchet, and covered up the raft with them so she looked like there
had been a cave-in in the bank there.
label: fear

text:
A tow-head is a sandbar that has
cottonwoods on it as thick as harrow-teeth.
label: neutral

text:
We had mountains on the Missouri shore and heavy timber on the Illinois
side, and the channel was down the Missouri shore at that place, so we
warn’t afraid of anybody running across us.
label: fear

text:
We laid there all day, and
watched the rafts and steamboats spin down the Missouri shore, and
up-bound steamboats fight the big river in the middle.
label: fear

text:
I told Jim all
about the time I had jabbering with that woman; and Jim said she was a
smart one, and if she was to start after us herself _she_ wouldn’t set
down and watch a camp fire—no, sir, she’d fetch a dog.
label: neutral

text:
Well, then, I
said, why couldn’t she tell her husband to fetch a dog?
label: anger

text:
Jim said he bet
she did think of it by the time the men was ready to start, and he
believed they must a gone up-town to get a dog and so they lost all
that time, or else we wouldn’t be here on a tow-head sixteen or
seventeen mile below the village—no, indeedy, we would be in that same
old town again.
label: neutral

text:
So I said I didn’t care what was the reason they didn’t
get us as long as they didn’t.
label: neutral

text:
When it was beginning to come on dark we poked our heads out of the
cottonwood thicket, and looked up and down and across; nothing in
sight; so Jim took up some of the top planks of the raft and built a
snug wigwam to get under in blazing weather and rainy, and to keep the
things dry.
label: anger

text:
Jim made a floor for the wigwam, and raised it a foot or
more above the level of the raft, so now the blankets and all the traps
was out of reach of steamboat waves.
label: fear

text:
Right in the middle of the wigwam
we made a layer of dirt about five or six inches deep with a frame
around it for to hold it to its place; this was to build a fire on in
sloppy weather or chilly; the wigwam would keep it from being seen.
label: neutral

text:
We
made an extra steering-oar, too, because one of the others might get
broke on a snag or something.
label: neutral

text:
We fixed up a short forked stick to hang
the old lantern on, because we must always light the lantern whenever
we see a steamboat coming down-stream, to keep from getting run over;
but we wouldn’t have to light it for up-stream boats unless we see we
was in what they call a “crossing”; for the river was pretty high yet,
very low banks being still a little under water; so up-bound boats
didn’t always run the channel, but hunted easy water.
label: neutral

text:
This second night we run between seven and eight hours, with a current
that was making over four mile an hour.
label: neutral

text:
We catched fish and talked, and
we took a swim now and then to keep off sleepiness.
label: neutral

text:
It was kind of
solemn, drifting down the big, still river, laying on our backs looking
up at the stars, and we didn’t ever feel like talking loud, and it
warn’t often that we laughed—only a little kind of a low chuckle.
label: neutral

text:
We
had mighty good weather as a general thing, and nothing ever happened
to us at all—that night, nor the next, nor the next.
label: neutral

text:
Every night we passed towns, some of them away up on black hillsides,
nothing but just a shiny bed of lights; not a house could you see.
label: surprise

text:
The
fifth night we passed St. Louis, and it was like the whole world lit
up.
label: surprise

text:
In St. Petersburg they used to say there was twenty or thirty
thousand people in St. Louis, but I never believed it till I see that
wonderful spread of lights at two o’clock that still night.
label: surprise

text:
There
warn’t a sound there; everybody was asleep.
label: neutral

text:
Every night now I used to slip ashore towards ten o’clock at some
little village, and buy ten or fifteen cents’ worth of meal or bacon or
other stuff to eat; and sometimes I lifted a chicken that warn’t
roosting comfortable, and took him along.
label: neutral

text:
Pap always said, take a
chicken when you get a chance, because if you don’t want him yourself
you can easy find somebody that does, and a good deed ain’t ever
forgot.
label: neutral

text:
I never see pap when he didn’t want the chicken himself, but
that is what he used to say, anyway.
label: neutral

text:
Mornings before daylight I slipped into cornfields and borrowed a
watermelon, or a mushmelon, or a punkin, or some new corn, or things of
that kind.
label: neutral

text:
Pap always said it warn’t no harm to borrow things if you
was meaning to pay them back some time; but the widow said it warn’t
anything but a soft name for stealing, and no decent body would do it.
label: sadness

text:
Jim said he reckoned the widow was partly right and pap was partly
right; so the best way would be for us to pick out two or three things
from the list and say we wouldn’t borrow them any more—then he reckoned
it wouldn’t be no harm to borrow the others.
label: neutral

text:
So we talked it over all
one night, drifting along down the river, trying to make up our minds
whether to drop the watermelons, or the cantelopes, or the mushmelons,
or what.
label: neutral

text:
But towards daylight we got it all settled satisfactory, and
concluded to drop crabapples and p’simmons.
label: neutral

text:
We warn’t feeling just
right before that, but it was all comfortable now.
label: neutral

text:
I was glad the way
it come out, too, because crabapples ain’t ever good, and the p’simmons
wouldn’t be ripe for two or three months yet.
label: joy

text:
We shot a water-fowl, now and, then that got up too early in the morning
or didn’t go to bed early enough in the evening.
label: neutral

text:
Take it all round, we
lived pretty high.
label: neutral

text:
The fifth night below St. Louis we had a big storm after midnight, with
a power of thunder and lightning, and the rain poured down in a solid
sheet.
label: neutral

text: We stayed in the wigwam and let the raft take care of itself.
label: neutral

text:
When the lightning glared out we could see a big straight river ahead,
and high, rocky bluffs on both sides.
label: anger

text:
By-and-by says I, “Hel-_lo_, Jim,
looky yonder!” It was a steamboat that had killed herself on a rock.
label: surprise

text:
We
was drifting straight down for her.
label: neutral

text:
The lightning showed her very
distinct.
label: neutral

text:
She was leaning over, with part of her upper deck above
water, and you could see every little chimbly-guy clean and clear, and
a chair by the big bell, with an old slouch hat hanging on the back of
it, when the flashes come.
label: neutral

text:
Well, it being away in the night and stormy, and all so
mysterious-like, I felt just the way any other boy would a felt when I
see that wreck laying there so mournful and lonesome in the middle of
the river.
label: sadness

text:
I wanted to get aboard of her and slink around a little, and
see what there was there.
label: neutral

text: So I says:
label: neutral

text: “Le’s land on her, Jim.”
label: neutral

text: But Jim was dead against it at first.
label: disgust

text: He says:
label: neutral

text: “I doan’ want to go fool’n ’long er no wrack.
label: anger

text:
We’s doin’ blame’ well,
en we better let blame’ well alone, as de good book says.
label: neutral

text:
Like as not
dey’s a watchman on dat wrack.”
label: neutral

text:
“Watchman your grandmother,” I says; “there ain’t nothing to watch but
the texas and the pilot-house; and do you reckon anybody’s going to
resk his life for a texas and a pilot-house such a night as this, when
it’s likely to break up and wash off down the river any minute?” Jim
couldn’t say nothing to that, so he didn’t try.
label: fear

text:
“And besides,” I says,
“we might borrow something worth having out of the captain’s stateroom.
label: neutral

text: Seegars, _I_ bet you—and cost five cents apiece, solid cash.
label: neutral

text:
Steamboat
captains is always rich, and get sixty dollars a month, and _they_
don’t care a cent what a thing costs, you know, long as they want it.
label: neutral

text:
Stick a candle in your pocket; I can’t rest, Jim, till we give her a
rummaging.
label: anger

text: Do you reckon Tom Sawyer would ever go by this thing?
label: surprise

text:
Not
for pie, he wouldn’t.
label: neutral

text:
He’d call it an adventure—that’s what he’d call
it; and he’d land on that wreck if it was his last act.
label: neutral

text:
And wouldn’t he
throw style into it?—wouldn’t he spread himself, nor nothing?
label: anger

text:
Why,
you’d think it was Christopher C’lumbus discovering Kingdom-Come.
label: surprise

text:
I
wish Tom Sawyer _was_ here.”
label: sadness

text: Jim he grumbled a little, but give in.
label: anger

text:
He said we mustn’t talk any more
than we could help, and then talk mighty low.
label: neutral

text:
The lightning showed us
the wreck again just in time, and we fetched the stabboard derrick, and
made fast there.
label: neutral

text: The deck was high out here.
label: neutral

text:
We went sneaking down the slope of it to
labboard, in the dark, towards the texas, feeling our way slow with our
feet, and spreading our hands out to fend off the guys, for it was so
dark we couldn’t see no sign of them.
label: fear

text:
Pretty soon we struck the forward
end of the skylight, and clumb on to it; and the next step fetched us
in front of the captain’s door, which was open, and by Jimminy, away
down through the texas-hall we see a light!
label: surprise

text:
and all in the same second
we seem to hear low voices in yonder!
label: surprise

text:
Jim whispered and said he was feeling powerful sick, and told me to
come along.
label: fear

text:
I says, all right, and was going to start for the raft; but
just then I heard a voice wail out and say:
label: fear

text: “Oh, please don’t, boys; I swear I won’t ever tell!”
label: fear

text: Another voice said, pretty loud:
label: disgust

text: “It’s a lie, Jim Turner.
label: disgust

text: You’ve acted this way before.
label: neutral

text:
You always want
more’n your share of the truck, and you’ve always got it, too, because
you’ve swore ’t if you didn’t you’d tell.
label: neutral

text:
But this time you’ve said it
jest one time too many.
label: neutral

text:
You’re the meanest, treacherousest hound in
this country.”
label: disgust

text: By this time Jim was gone for the raft.
label: neutral

text:
I was just a-biling with
curiosity; and I says to myself, Tom Sawyer wouldn’t back out now, and
so I won’t either; I’m a-going to see what’s going on here.
label: neutral

text:
So I
dropped on my hands and knees in the little passage, and crept aft in
the dark till there warn’t but one stateroom betwixt me and the
cross-hall of the texas.
label: fear

text:
Then in there I see a man stretched on the
floor and tied hand and foot, and two men standing over him, and one of
them had a dim lantern in his hand, and the other one had a pistol.
label: disgust

text:
This one kept pointing the pistol at the man’s head on the floor, and
saying:
label: disgust

text: “I’d _like_ to!
label: joy

text: And I orter, too—a mean skunk!”
label: disgust

text:
The man on the floor would shrivel up and say, “Oh, please don’t, Bill;
I hain’t ever goin’ to tell.”
label: neutral

text:
And every time he said that the man with the lantern would laugh and
say:
label: joy

text:
“’Deed you _ain’t!_ You never said no truer thing ’n that, you bet
you.” And once he said: “Hear him beg!
label: anger

text:
and yit if we hadn’t got the
best of him and tied him he’d a killed us both.
label: anger

text:
And what _for?_ Jist
for noth’n.
label: surprise

text: Jist because we stood on our _rights_—that’s what for.
label: neutral

text:
But
I lay you ain’t a-goin’ to threaten nobody any more, Jim Turner.
label: fear

text:
Put
_up_ that pistol, Bill.”
label: neutral

text: Bill says:
label: neutral

text: “I don’t want to, Jake Packard.
label: fear

text:
I’m for killin’ him—and didn’t he kill
old Hatfield jist the same way—and don’t he deserve it?”
label: anger

text: “But I don’t _want_ him killed, and I’ve got my reasons for it.”
label: anger

text: “Bless yo’ heart for them words, Jake Packard!
label: neutral

text:
I’ll never forgit you
long’s I live!” says the man on the floor, sort of blubbering.
label: disgust

text:
Packard didn’t take no notice of that, but hung up his lantern on a
nail and started towards where I was there in the dark, and motioned
Bill to come.
label: neutral

text:
I crawfished as fast as I could about two yards, but the
boat slanted so that I couldn’t make very good time; so to keep from
getting run over and catched I crawled into a stateroom on the upper
side.
label: fear

text:
The man came a-pawing along in the dark, and when Packard got to
my stateroom, he says:
label: fear

text: “Here—come in here.”
label: neutral

text: And in he come, and Bill after him.
label: neutral

text:
But before they got in I was up in
the upper berth, cornered, and sorry I come.
label: fear

text:
Then they stood there,
with their hands on the ledge of the berth, and talked.
label: neutral

text:
I couldn’t see
them, but I could tell where they was by the whisky they’d been having.
label: neutral

text:
I was glad I didn’t drink whisky; but it wouldn’t made much difference
anyway, because most of the time they couldn’t a treed me because I
didn’t breathe.
label: sadness

text: I was too scared.
label: fear

text:
And, besides, a body _couldn’t_
breathe and hear such talk.
label: disgust

text: They talked low and earnest.
label: neutral

text:
Bill wanted to
kill Turner.
label: anger

text: He says:
label: neutral

text: “He’s said he’ll tell, and he will.
label: neutral

text:
If we was to give both our shares
to him _now_ it wouldn’t make no difference after the row and the way
we’ve served him.
label: neutral

text:
Shore’s you’re born, he’ll turn State’s evidence; now
you hear _me_.
label: neutral

text: I’m for putting him out of his troubles.”
label: joy

text: “So’m I,” says Packard, very quiet.
label: neutral

text: “Blame it, I’d sorter begun to think you wasn’t.
label: surprise

text:
Well, then, that’s all
right.
label: neutral

text: Le’s go and do it.”
label: anger

text: “Hold on a minute; I hain’t had my say yit.
label: neutral

text: You listen to me.
label: neutral

text:
Shooting’s good, but there’s quieter ways if the thing’s _got_ to be
done.
label: neutral

text:
But what _I_ say is this: it ain’t good sense to go court’n
around after a halter if you can git at what you’re up to in some way
that’s jist as good and at the same time don’t bring you into no resks.
label: neutral

text: Ain’t that so?”
label: surprise

text: “You bet it is.
label: neutral

text: But how you goin’ to manage it this time?”
label: neutral

text:
“Well, my idea is this: we’ll rustle around and gather up whatever
pickins we’ve overlooked in the staterooms, and shove for shore and
hide the truck.
label: neutral

text: Then we’ll wait.
label: neutral

text:
Now I say it ain’t a-goin’ to be
more’n two hours befo’ this wrack breaks up and washes off down the
river.
label: neutral

text: See?
label: surprise

text:
He’ll be drownded, and won’t have nobody to blame for it
but his own self.
label: anger

text:
I reckon that’s a considerble sight better ’n killin’
of him.
label: neutral

text:
I’m unfavorable to killin’ a man as long as you can git aroun’
it; it ain’t good sense, it ain’t good morals.
label: disgust

text: Ain’t I right?”
label: anger

text: “Yes, I reck’n you are.
label: neutral

text: But s’pose she _don’t_ break up and wash off?”
label: neutral

text: “Well, we can wait the two hours anyway and see, can’t we?”
label: neutral

text: “All right, then; come along.”
label: neutral

text:
So they started, and I lit out, all in a cold sweat, and scrambled
forward.
label: neutral

text:
It was dark as pitch there; but I said, in a kind of a coarse
whisper, “Jim!” and he answered up, right at my elbow, with a sort of a
moan, and I says:
label: disgust

text:
“Quick, Jim, it ain’t no time for fooling around and moaning; there’s a
gang of murderers in yonder, and if we don’t hunt up their boat and set
her drifting down the river so these fellows can’t get away from the
wreck there’s one of ’em going to be in a bad fix.
label: neutral

text:
But if we find their
boat we can put _all_ of ’em in a bad fix—for the Sheriff ’ll get ’em.
label: neutral

text: Quick—hurry!
label: fear

text: I’ll hunt the labboard side, you hunt the stabboard.
label: neutral

text:
You
start at the raft, and—”
label: fear

text: “Oh, my lordy, lordy!
label: surprise

text:
_Raf’?_ Dey ain’ no raf’ no mo’; she done broke
loose en gone I—en here we is!”
label: surprise

text: CHAPTER XIII.
label: neutral

text: Well, I catched my breath and most fainted.
label: sadness

text:
Shut up on a wreck with
such a gang as that!
label: anger

text: But it warn’t no time to be sentimentering.
label: neutral

text:
We’d
_got_ to find that boat now—had to have it for ourselves.
label: neutral

text:
So we went
a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was,
too—seemed a week before we got to the stern.
label: fear

text: No sign of a boat.
label: fear

text:
Jim
said he didn’t believe he could go any further—so scared he hadn’t
hardly any strength left, he said.
label: fear

text:
But I said, come on, if we get left
on this wreck we are in a fix, sure.
label: neutral

text: So on we prowled again.
label: neutral

text:
We struck
for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along
forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the
edge of the skylight was in the water.
label: fear

text:
When we got pretty close to the
cross-hall door, there was the skiff, sure enough!
label: surprise

text:
I could just barely
see her.
label: fear

text: I felt ever so thankful.
label: joy

text:
In another second I would a been
aboard of her, but just then the door opened.
label: surprise
surprise

text: “Heave that blame lantern out o’ sight, Bill!”
label: anger

text:
He flung a bag of something into the boat, and then got in himself and
set down.
label: disgust

text: It was Packard.
label: neutral

text: Then Bill _he_ come out and got in.
label: surprise

text:
Packard
says, in a low voice:
label: sadness

text: “All ready—shove off!”
label: fear

text: I couldn’t hardly hang on to the shutters, I was so weak.
label: fear

text:
But Bill
says:
label: neutral

text: “Hold on—’d you go through him?”
label: anger

text: “No.
label: neutral

text: Didn’t you?”
label: surprise

text: “No.
label: neutral

text: So he’s got his share o’ the cash yet.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, then, come along; no use to take truck and leave money.”
label: neutral

text: “Say, won’t he suspicion what we’re up to?”
label: fear

text: “Maybe he won’t.
label: neutral

text: But we got to have it anyway.
label: neutral

text: Come along.”
label: neutral

text: So they got out and went in.
label: neutral

text:
The door slammed to because it was on the careened side; and in a half
second I was in the boat, and Jim come tumbling after me.
label: fear

text:
I out with my
knife and cut the rope, and away we went!
label: anger

text:
We didn’t touch an oar, and we didn’t speak nor whisper, nor hardly
even breathe.
label: fear

text:
We went gliding swift along, dead silent, past the tip of
the paddle-box, and past the stern; then in a second or two more we was
a hundred yards below the wreck, and the darkness soaked her up, every
last sign of her, and we was safe, and knowed it.
label: fear

text:
When we was three or four hundred yards down-stream we see the lantern
show like a little spark at the texas door for a second, and we knowed
by that that the rascals had missed their boat, and was beginning to
understand that they was in just as much trouble now as Jim Turner was.
label: fear

text: Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft.
label: neutral

text:
Now was the
first time that I begun to worry about the men—I reckon I hadn’t had
time to before.
label: fear

text:
I begun to think how dreadful it was, even for
murderers, to be in such a fix.
label: fear

text:
I says to myself, there ain’t no
telling but I might come to be a murderer myself yet, and then how
would _I_ like it?
label: neutral

text: So says I to Jim:
label: neutral

text:
“The first light we see we’ll land a hundred yards below it or above
it, in a place where it’s a good hiding-place for you and the skiff,
and then I’ll go and fix up some kind of a yarn, and get somebody to go
for that gang and get them out of their scrape, so they can be hung
when their time comes.”
label: neutral

text:
But that idea was a failure; for pretty soon it begun to storm again,
and this time worse than ever.
label: disgust

text:
The rain poured down, and never a light
showed; everybody in bed, I reckon.
label: neutral

text:
We boomed along down the river,
watching for lights and watching for our raft.
label: fear

text:
After a long time the
rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering,
and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we
made for it.
label: neutral

text: It was the raft, and mighty glad was we to get aboard of it again.
label: joy

text:
We
seen a light now away down to the right, on shore.
label: surprise

text:
So I said I would go
for it.
label: neutral

text:
The skiff was half full of plunder which that gang had stole
there on the wreck.
label: disgust

text:
We hustled it on to the raft in a pile, and I told
Jim to float along down, and show a light when he judged he had gone
about two mile, and keep it burning till I come; then I manned my oars
and shoved for the light.
label: anger

text:
As I got down towards it, three or four more
showed—up on a hillside.
label: fear

text: It was a village.
label: neutral

text:
I closed in above the shore
light, and laid on my oars and floated.
label: fear

text:
As I went by, I see it was a
lantern hanging on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat.
label: surprise

text:
I skimmed
around for the watchman, a-wondering whereabouts he slept; and
by-and-by I found him roosting on the bitts, forward, with his head
down between his knees.
label: neutral

text:
I gave his shoulder two or three little shoves,
and begun to cry.
label: sadness

text:
He stirred up, in a kind of a startlish way; but when he see it was only
me, he took a good gap and stretch, and then he says:
label: neutral

text: “Hello, what’s up?
label: neutral

text: Don’t cry, bub.
label: sadness

text: What’s the trouble?”
label: neutral

text: I says:
label: neutral

text: “Pap, and mam, and sis, and—”
label: neutral

text: Then I broke down.
label: fear

text: He says:
label: neutral

text:
“Oh, dang it now, _don’t_ take on so; we all has to have our troubles,
and this’n ’ll come out all right.
label: neutral

text: What’s the matter with ’em?”
label: anger

text: “They’re—they’re—are you the watchman of the boat?”
label: neutral

text: “Yes,” he says, kind of pretty-well-satisfied like.
label: neutral

text:
“I’m the captain
and the owner and the mate and the pilot and watchman and head
deck-hand; and sometimes I’m the freight and passengers.
label: neutral

text:
I ain’t as
rich as old Jim Hornback, and I can’t be so blame’ generous and good to
Tom, Dick and Harry as what he is, and slam around money the way he
does; but I’ve told him a many a time ’t I wouldn’t trade places with
him; for, says I, a sailor’s life’s the life for me, and I’m derned if
_I’d_ live two mile out o’ town, where there ain’t nothing ever goin’
on, not for all his spondulicks and as much more on top of it.
label: neutral

text: Says I—”
label: neutral

text: I broke in and says:
label: fear

text: “They’re in an awful peck of trouble, and—”
label: disgust

text: “_Who_ is?”
label: neutral

text:
“Why, pap and mam and sis and Miss Hooker; and if you’d take your
ferry-boat and go up there—”
label: neutral

text: “Up where?
label: surprise

text: Where are they?”
label: neutral

text: “On the wreck.”
label: neutral

text: “What wreck?”
label: surprise

text: “Why, there ain’t but one.”
label: surprise

text: “What, you don’t mean the _Walter Scott?_”
label: surprise

text: “Yes.”
label: neutral

text: “Good land!
label: joy

text: what are they doin’ _there_, for gracious sakes?”
label: neutral

text: “Well, they didn’t go there a-purpose.”
label: neutral

text: “I bet they didn’t!
label: surprise

text:
Why, great goodness, there ain’t no chance for ’em
if they don’t git off mighty quick!
label: surprise

text:
Why, how in the nation did they
ever git into such a scrape?”
label: surprise

text: “Easy enough.
label: neutral

text: Miss Hooker was a-visiting up there to the town—”
label: neutral

text: “Yes, Booth’s Landing—go on.”
label: neutral

text:
“She was a-visiting there at Booth’s Landing, and just in the edge of
the evening she started over with her nigger woman in the horse-ferry
to stay all night at her friend’s house, Miss What-you-may-call-her I
disremember her name—and they lost their steering-oar, and swung around
and went a-floating down, stern first, about two mile, and
saddle-baggsed on the wreck, and the ferryman and the nigger woman and
the horses was all lost, but Miss Hooker she made a grab and got aboard
the wreck.
label: sadness

text:
Well, about an hour after dark we come along down in our
trading-scow, and it was so dark we didn’t notice the wreck till we was
right on it; and so _we_ saddle-baggsed; but all of us was saved but
Bill Whipple—and oh, he _was_ the best cretur!—I most wish’t it had
been me, I do.”
label: surprise

text: “My George!
label: surprise

text: It’s the beatenest thing I ever struck.
label: sadness

text:
And _then_ what did
you all do?”
label: surprise

text:
“Well, we hollered and took on, but it’s so wide there we couldn’t make
nobody hear.
label: neutral

text:
So pap said somebody got to get ashore and get help
somehow.
label: neutral

text:
I was the only one that could swim, so I made a dash for it,
and Miss Hooker she said if I didn’t strike help sooner, come here and
hunt up her uncle, and he’d fix the thing.
label: neutral

text:
I made the land about a mile
below, and been fooling along ever since, trying to get people to do
something, but they said, ‘What, in such a night and such a current?
label: surprise

text:
There ain’t no sense in it; go for the steam ferry.’ Now if you’ll go
and—”
label: anger

text:
“By Jackson, I’d _like_ to, and, blame it, I don’t know but I will; but
who in the dingnation’s a-going’ to _pay_ for it?
label: anger

text:
Do you reckon your
pap—”
label: anger

text: “Why _that’s_ all right.
label: neutral

text:
Miss Hooker she tole me, _particular_, that
her uncle Hornback—”
label: neutral

text: “Great guns!
label: joy

text: is _he_ her uncle?
label: surprise

text:
Looky here, you break for that light
over yonder-way, and turn out west when you git there, and about a
quarter of a mile out you’ll come to the tavern; tell ’em to dart you
out to Jim Hornback’s, and he’ll foot the bill.
label: neutral

text:
And don’t you fool
around any, because he’ll want to know the news.
label: anger

text:
Tell him I’ll have his
niece all safe before he can get to town.
label: neutral

text:
Hump yourself, now; I’m
a-going up around the corner here to roust out my engineer.”
label: anger

text:
I struck for the light, but as soon as he turned the corner I went back
and got into my skiff and bailed her out, and then pulled up shore in
the easy water about six hundred yards, and tucked myself in among some
woodboats; for I couldn’t rest easy till I could see the ferry-boat
start.
label: fear

text:
But take it all around, I was feeling ruther comfortable on
accounts of taking all this trouble for that gang, for not many would a
done it.
label: joy

text: I wished the widow knowed about it.
label: sadness

text:
I judged she would be
proud of me for helping these rapscallions, because rapscallions and
dead beats is the kind the widow and good people takes the most
interest in.
label: neutral

text:
Well, before long, here comes the wreck, dim and dusky, sliding along
down!
label: disgust

text:
A kind of cold shiver went through me, and then I struck out for
her.
label: fear

text:
She was very deep, and I see in a minute there warn’t much chance
for anybody being alive in her.
label: fear

text:
I pulled all around her and hollered a
little, but there wasn’t any answer; all dead still.
label: sadness

text:
I felt a little
bit heavy-hearted about the gang, but not much, for I reckoned if they
could stand it, I could.
label: sadness

text:
Then here comes the ferry-boat; so I shoved for the middle of the river
on a long down-stream slant; and when I judged I was out of eye-reach, I
laid on my oars, and looked back and see her go and smell around the
wreck for Miss Hooker’s remainders, because the captain would know her
uncle Hornback would want them; and then pretty soon the ferry-boat give
it up and went for the shore, and I laid into my work and went
a-booming down the river.
label: fear

text:
It did seem a powerful long time before Jim’s light showed up; and when
it did show, it looked like it was a thousand mile off.
label: surprise

text:
By the time I
got there the sky was beginning to get a little gray in the east; so we
struck for an island, and hid the raft, and sunk the skiff, and turned
in and slept like dead people.
label: fear

text: CHAPTER XIV.
label: neutral

text:
By-and-by, when we got up, we turned over the truck the gang had stole
off of the wreck, and found boots, and blankets, and clothes, and all
sorts of other things, and a lot of books, and a spyglass, and three
boxes of seegars.
label: neutral

text:
We hadn’t ever been this rich before in neither of
our lives.
label: neutral

text: The seegars was prime.
label: neutral

text:
We laid off all the afternoon in the
woods talking, and me reading the books, and having a general good
time.
label: joy

text:
I told Jim all about what happened inside the wreck and at the
ferry-boat, and I said these kinds of things was adventures; but he said
he didn’t want no more adventures.
label: neutral

text:
He said that when I went in the
texas and he crawled back to get on the raft and found her gone, he
nearly died; because he judged it was all up with _him_, anyway it could
be fixed; for if he didn’t get saved he would get drownded; and if he
did get saved, whoever saved him would send him back home so as to get
the reward, and then Miss Watson would sell him South, sure.
label: neutral

text:
Well, he
was right; he was most always right; he had an uncommon level head, for
a nigger.
label: disgust

text:
I read considerable to Jim about kings and dukes and earls and such,
and how gaudy they dressed, and how much style they put on, and called
each other your majesty, and your grace, and your lordship, and so on,
’stead of mister; and Jim’s eyes bugged out, and he was interested.
label: neutral

text:
He
says:
label: neutral

text: “I didn’ know dey was so many un um.
label: surprise

text:
I hain’t hearn ’bout none un um,
skasely, but ole King Sollermun, onless you counts dem kings dat’s in a
pack er k’yards.
label: neutral

text: How much do a king git?”
label: neutral

text:
“Get?” I says; “why, they get a thousand dollars a month if they want
it; they can have just as much as they want; everything belongs to
them.”
label: neutral

text: “_Ain’_ dat gay?
label: surprise

text: En what dey got to do, Huck?”
label: neutral

text: “_They_ don’t do nothing!
label: anger

text: Why, how you talk!
label: surprise

text: They just set around.”
label: neutral

text: “No; is dat so?”
label: surprise

text: “Of course it is.
label: neutral

text:
They just set around—except, maybe, when there’s a
war; then they go to the war.
label: neutral

text:
But other times they just lazy around; or
go hawking—just hawking and sp— Sh!—d’ you hear a noise?”
label: fear

text:
We skipped out and looked; but it warn’t nothing but the flutter of a
steamboat’s wheel away down, coming around the point; so we come back.
label: neutral

text:
“Yes,” says I, “and other times, when things is dull, they fuss with
the parlyment; and if everybody don’t go just so he whacks their heads
off.
label: disgust

text: But mostly they hang round the harem.”
label: neutral

text: “Roun’ de which?”
label: neutral

text: “Harem.”
label: neutral

text: “What’s de harem?”
label: surprise

text: “The place where he keeps his wives.
label: disgust

text: Don’t you know about the harem?
label: disgust

text: Solomon had one; he had about a million wives.”
label: neutral

text: “Why, yes, dat’s so; I—I’d done forgot it.
label: surprise

text:
A harem’s a bo’d’n-house, I
reck’n.
label: disgust

text: Mos’ likely dey has rackety times in de nussery.
label: neutral

text:
En I reck’n de
wives quarrels considable; en dat ’crease de racket.
label: anger

text:
Yit dey say
Sollermun de wises’ man dat ever live’.
label: neutral

text: I doan’ take no stock in dat.
label: neutral

text:
Bekase why: would a wise man want to live in de mids’ er sich a
blim-blammin’ all de time?
label: neutral

text: No—’deed he wouldn’t.
label: neutral

text:
A wise man ’ud take en
buil’ a biler-factry; en den he could shet _down_ de biler-factry when
he want to res’.”
label: neutral

text:
“Well, but he _was_ the wisest man, anyway; because the widow she told
me so, her own self.”
label: disgust

text: “I doan k’yer what de widder say, he _warn’t_ no wise man nuther.
label: neutral

text:
He
had some er de dad-fetchedes’ ways I ever see.
label: neutral

text:
Does you know ’bout dat
chile dat he ’uz gwyne to chop in two?”
label: neutral

text: “Yes, the widow told me all about it.”
label: neutral

text: “_Well_, den!
label: surprise

text: Warn’ dat de beatenes’ notion in de worl’?
label: neutral

text:
You jes’ take
en look at it a minute.
label: neutral
neutral

text: Bofe un you claims it.
label: neutral

text: What does I do?
label: fear

text:
Does I shin
aroun’ mongs’ de neighbors en fine out which un you de bill _do_ b’long
to, en han’ it over to de right one, all safe en soun’, de way dat
anybody dat had any gumption would?
label: neutral

text:
No; I take en whack de bill in
_two_, en give half un it to you, en de yuther half to de yuther woman.
label: anger

text: Dat’s de way Sollermun was gwyne to do wid de chile.
label: neutral

text:
Now I want to ast
you: what’s de use er dat half a bill?—can’t buy noth’n wid it.
label: neutral

text:
En what
use is a half a chile?
label: neutral

text: I wouldn’ give a dern for a million un um.”
label: neutral

text:
“But hang it, Jim, you’ve clean missed the point—blame it, you’ve
missed it a thousand mile.”
label: anger

text: “Who?
label: surprise

text: Me?
label: surprise

text: Go ’long.
label: neutral

text: Doan’ talk to _me_ ’bout yo’ pints.
label: neutral

text:
I reck’n I
knows sense when I sees it; en dey ain’ no sense in sich doin’s as dat.
label: neutral

text:
De ’spute warn’t ’bout a half a chile, de ’spute was ’bout a whole
chile; en de man dat think he kin settle a ’spute ’bout a whole chile
wid a half a chile doan’ know enough to come in out’n de rain.
label: neutral

text:
Doan’
talk to me ’bout Sollermun, Huck, I knows him by de back.”
label: neutral

text: “But I tell you you don’t get the point.”
label: anger

text: “Blame de point!
label: anger

text: I reck’n I knows what I knows.
label: anger

text:
En mine you, de _real_
pint is down furder—it’s down deeper.
label: neutral

text:
It lays in de way Sollermun was
raised.
label: neutral

text:
You take a man dat’s got on’y one or two chillen; is dat man
gwyne to be waseful o’ chillen?
label: neutral

text: No, he ain’t; he can’t ’ford it.
label: anger

text:
_He_
know how to value ’em.
label: neutral

text:
But you take a man dat’s got ’bout five million
chillen runnin’ roun’ de house, en it’s diffunt.
label: neutral

text:
_He_ as soon chop a
chile in two as a cat.
label: anger

text: Dey’s plenty mo’.
label: neutral

text:
A chile er two, mo’ er less,
warn’t no consekens to Sollermun, dad fatch him!”
label: neutral

text: I never see such a nigger.
label: disgust

text:
If he got a notion in his head once, there
warn’t no getting it out again.
label: neutral

text:
He was the most down on Solomon of any
nigger I ever see.
label: disgust

text:
So I went to talking about other kings, and let
Solomon slide.
label: neutral

text:
I told about Louis Sixteenth that got his head cut off
in France long time ago; and about his little boy the dolphin, that
would a been a king, but they took and shut him up in jail, and some
say he died there.
label: sadness

text: “Po’ little chap.”
label: neutral

text: “But some says he got out and got away, and come to America.”
label: neutral

text: “Dat’s good!
label: joy

text:
But he’ll be pooty lonesome—dey ain’ no kings here, is
dey, Huck?”
label: neutral

text: “No.”
label: neutral

text: “Den he cain’t git no situation.
label: neutral

text: What he gwyne to do?”
label: neutral

text: “Well, I don’t know.
label: neutral

text:
Some of them gets on the police, and some of them
learns people how to talk French.”
label: disgust

text: “Why, Huck, doan’ de French people talk de same way we does?”
label: surprise

text:
“_No_, Jim; you couldn’t understand a word they said—not a single
word.”
label: surprise

text: “Well, now, I be ding-busted!
label: disgust

text: How do dat come?”
label: surprise

text: “_I_ don’t know; but it’s so.
label: neutral

text: I got some of their jabber out of a book.
label: disgust

text:
S’pose a man was to come to you and say _Polly-voo-franzy_—what would
you think?”
label: surprise

text:
“I wouldn’ think nuff’n; I’d take en bust him over de head—dat is, if
he warn’t white.
label: anger

text: I wouldn’t ’low no nigger to call me dat.”
label: anger

text: “Shucks, it ain’t calling you anything.
label: anger

text:
It’s only saying, do you know
how to talk French?”
label: neutral

text: “Well, den, why couldn’t he _say_ it?”
label: anger

text: “Why, he _is_ a-saying it.
label: surprise

text: That’s a Frenchman’s _way_ of saying it.”
label: neutral

text:
“Well, it’s a blame ridicklous way, en I doan’ want to hear no mo’
’bout it.
label: neutral

text: Dey ain’ no sense in it.”
label: disgust

text: “Looky here, Jim; does a cat talk like we do?”
label: disgust

text: “No, a cat don’t.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, does a cow?”
label: disgust

text: “No, a cow don’t, nuther.”
label: neutral

text: “Does a cat talk like a cow, or a cow talk like a cat?”
label: disgust

text: “No, dey don’t.”
label: neutral

text:
“It’s natural and right for ’em to talk different from each other,
ain’t it?”
label: neutral

text: “’Course.”
label: neutral

text:
“And ain’t it natural and right for a cat and a cow to talk different
from _us?_”
label: neutral

text: “Why, mos’ sholy it is.”
label: disgust

text:
“Well, then, why ain’t it natural and right for a _Frenchman_ to talk
different from us?
label: neutral

text: You answer me that.”
label: neutral

text: “Is a cat a man, Huck?”
label: neutral

text: “No.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, den, dey ain’t no sense in a cat talkin’ like a man.
label: disgust

text:
Is a cow a
man?—er is a cow a cat?”
label: disgust

text: “No, she ain’t either of them.”
label: neutral

text:
“Well, den, she ain’t got no business to talk like either one er the
yuther of ’em.
label: neutral

text: Is a Frenchman a man?”
label: surprise

text: “Yes.”
label: neutral

text: “_Well_, den!
label: surprise

text: Dad blame it, why doan’ he _talk_ like a man?
label: anger

text:
You answer
me _dat!_”
label: anger

text: I see it warn’t no use wasting words—you can’t learn a nigger to argue.
label: neutral

text: So I quit.
label: sadness

text: CHAPTER XV.
label: neutral

text:
We judged that three nights more would fetch us to Cairo, at the bottom
of Illinois, where the Ohio River comes in, and that was what we was
after.
label: neutral

text:
We would sell the raft and get on a steamboat and go way up the
Ohio amongst the free States, and then be out of trouble.
label: fear

text:
Well, the second night a fog begun to come on, and we made for a
tow-head to tie to, for it wouldn’t do to try to run in a fog; but when
I paddled ahead in the canoe, with the line to make fast, there warn’t
anything but little saplings to tie to.
label: fear

text:
I passed the line around one of
them right on the edge of the cut bank, but there was a stiff current,
and the raft come booming down so lively she tore it out by the roots
and away she went.
label: neutral

text:
I see the fog closing down, and it made me so sick
and scared I couldn’t budge for most a half a minute it seemed to
me—and then there warn’t no raft in sight; you couldn’t see twenty
yards.
label: fear

text:
I jumped into the canoe and run back to the stern, and grabbed
the paddle and set her back a stroke.
label: fear

text: But she didn’t come.
label: anger

text:
I was in
such a hurry I hadn’t untied her.
label: neutral

text:
I got up and tried to untie her, but
I was so excited my hands shook so I couldn’t hardly do anything with
them.
label: fear

text:
As soon as I got started I took out after the raft, hot and heavy,
right down the tow-head.
label: fear

text:
That was all right as far as it went, but the
tow-head warn’t sixty yards long, and the minute I flew by the foot of
it I shot out into the solid white fog, and hadn’t no more idea which
way I was going than a dead man.
label: fear

text:
Thinks I, it won’t do to paddle; first I know I’ll run into the bank or
a tow-head or something; I got to set still and float, and yet it’s
mighty fidgety business to have to hold your hands still at such a
time.
label: neutral

text: I whooped and listened.
label: disgust

text:
Away down there somewheres I hears a
small whoop, and up comes my spirits.
label: surprise

text:
I went tearing after it,
listening sharp to hear it again.
label: anger

text:
The next time it come, I see I warn’t
heading for it, but heading away to the right of it.
label: neutral

text:
And the next time
I was heading away to the left of it—and not gaining on it much either,
for I was flying around, this way and that and t’other, but it was
going straight ahead all the time.
label: neutral

text:
I did wish the fool would think to beat a tin pan, and beat it all the
time, but he never did, and it was the still places between the whoops
that was making the trouble for me.
label: sadness

text:
Well, I fought along, and directly
I hears the whoop _behind_ me.
label: surprise

text: I was tangled good now.
label: neutral

text:
That was
somebody else’s whoop, or else I was turned around.
label: surprise

text: I throwed the paddle down.
label: neutral

text:
I heard the whoop again; it was behind me
yet, but in a different place; it kept coming, and kept changing its
place, and I kept answering, till by-and-by it was in front of me
again, and I knowed the current had swung the canoe’s head down-stream,
and I was all right if that was Jim and not some other raftsman
hollering.
label: neutral

text:
I couldn’t tell nothing about voices in a fog, for nothing
don’t look natural nor sound natural in a fog.
label: fear

text:
The whooping went on, and in about a minute I come a-booming down on a
cut bank with smoky ghosts of big trees on it, and the current throwed
me off to the left and shot by, amongst a lot of snags that fairly

text:
No,
says I, I’d feel bad—I’d feel just the same way I do now.
label: sadness

text:
Well, then,
says I, what’s the use you learning to do right when it’s troublesome
to do right and ain’t no trouble to do wrong, and the wages is just the
same?
label: neutral

text: I was stuck.
label: neutral

text: I couldn’t answer that.
label: surprise

text:
So I reckoned I wouldn’t
bother no more about it, but after this always do whichever come
handiest at the time.
label: neutral

text: I went into the wigwam; Jim warn’t there.
label: neutral

text:
I looked all around; he
warn’t anywhere.
label: fear

text: I says:
label: neutral

text: “Jim!”
label: surprise

text: “Here I is, Huck.
label: neutral

text: Is dey out o’ sight yit?
label: neutral

text: Don’t talk loud.”
label: fear

text: He was in the river under the stern oar, with just his nose out.
label: disgust

text:
I told
him they were out of sight, so he come aboard.
label: fear

text: He says:
label: neutral

text:
“I was a-listenin’ to all de talk, en I slips into de river en was
gwyne to shove for sho’ if dey come aboard.
label: fear

text:
Den I was gwyne to swim to
de raf’ agin when dey was gone.
label: fear

text: But lawsy, how you did fool ’em, Huck!
label: anger

text: Dat _wuz_ de smartes’ dodge!
label: anger

text:
I tell you, chile, I ’speck it save’ ole
Jim—ole Jim ain’t going to forgit you for dat, honey.”
label: neutral

text: Then we talked about the money.
label: neutral

text:
It was a pretty good raise—twenty
dollars apiece.
label: joy

text:
Jim said we could take deck passage on a steamboat now,
and the money would last us as far as we wanted to go in the free
States.
label: neutral

text:
He said twenty mile more warn’t far for the raft to go, but he
wished we was already there.
label: fear

text:
Towards daybreak we tied up, and Jim was mighty particular about hiding
the raft good.
label: neutral

text:
Then he worked all day fixing things in bundles, and
getting all ready to quit rafting.
label: neutral

text:
That night about ten we hove in sight of the lights of a town away down
in a left-hand bend.
label: fear

text: I went off in the canoe to ask about it.
label: fear

text:
Pretty soon I found a man out
in the river with a skiff, setting a trot-line.
label: fear

text: I ranged up and says:
label: neutral

text: “Mister, is that town Cairo?”
label: neutral

text: “Cairo?
label: surprise

text: no.
label: neutral

text: You must be a blame’ fool.”
label: anger

text: “What town is it, mister?”
label: neutral

text: “If you want to know, go and find out.
label: neutral

text:
If you stay here botherin’
around me for about a half a minute longer you’ll get something you
won’t want.”
label: neutral

text: I paddled to the raft.
label: fear

text:
Jim was awful disappointed, but I said never
mind, Cairo would be the next place, I reckoned.
label: disgust

text:
We passed another town before daylight, and I was going out again; but
it was high ground, so I didn’t go.
label: fear

text:
No high ground about Cairo, Jim
said.
label: neutral

text: I had forgot it.
label: surprise

text:
We laid up for the day on a tow-head tolerable
close to the left-hand bank.
label: neutral

text: I begun to suspicion something.
label: fear

text:
So did
Jim.
label: neutral

text: I says:
label: neutral

text: “Maybe we went by Cairo in the fog that night.”
label: fear

text: He says:
label: neutral

text: “Doan’ le’s talk about it, Huck.
label: neutral

text: Po’ niggers can’t have no luck.
label: sadness

text:
I
awluz ’spected dat rattlesnake-skin warn’t done wid its work.”
label: neutral

text:
“I wish I’d never seen that snake-skin, Jim—I do wish I’d never laid
eyes on it.”
label: neutral

text: “It ain’t yo’ fault, Huck; you didn’ know.
label: neutral

text:
Don’t you blame yo’self
’bout it.”
label: anger

text:
When it was daylight, here was the clear Ohio water inshore, sure
enough, and outside was the old regular Muddy!
label: neutral

text:
So it was all up with
Cairo.
label: neutral

text: We talked it all over.
label: neutral

text:
It wouldn’t do to take to the shore; we couldn’t
take the raft up the stream, of course.
label: neutral

text:
There warn’t no way but to wait
for dark, and start back in the canoe and take the chances.
label: fear

text:
So we slept
all day amongst the cottonwood thicket, so as to be fresh for the work,
and when we went back to the raft about dark the canoe was gone!
label: fear

text: We didn’t say a word for a good while.
label: neutral

text: There warn’t anything to say.
label: neutral
neutral

text:
It would only look like we was
finding fault, and that would be bound to fetch more bad luck—and keep
on fetching it, too, till we knowed enough to keep still.
label: neutral

text:
By-and-by we talked about what we better do, and found there warn’t no
way but just to go along down with the raft till we got a chance to buy
a canoe to go back in.
label: neutral

text:
We warn’t going to borrow it when there warn’t
anybody around, the way pap would do, for that might set people after
us.
label: fear

text: So we shoved out after dark on the raft.
label: fear

text:
Anybody that don’t believe yet that it’s foolishness to handle a
snake-skin, after all that that snake-skin done for us, will believe it
now if they read on and see what more it done for us.
label: neutral

text: The place to buy canoes is off of rafts laying up at shore.
label: neutral

text:
But we
didn’t see no rafts laying up; so we went along during three hours and
more.
label: neutral

text:
Well, the night got gray and ruther thick, which is the next
meanest thing to fog.
label: disgust

text:
You can’t tell the shape of the river, and you
can’t see no distance.
label: neutral

text:
It got to be very late and still, and then along
comes a steamboat up the river.
label: neutral

text:
We lit the lantern, and judged she
would see it.
label: neutral

text:
Up-stream boats didn’t generly come close to us; they go
out and follow the bars and hunt for easy water under the reefs; but
nights like this they bull right up the channel against the whole
river.
label: neutral

text:
We could hear her pounding along, but we didn’t see her good till she
was close.
label: neutral

text: She aimed right for us.
label: neutral

text:
Often they do that and try to see
how close they can come without touching; sometimes the wheel bites off
a sweep, and then the pilot sticks his head out and laughs, and thinks
he’s mighty smart.
label: neutral

text:
Well, here she comes, and we said she was going to
try and shave us; but she didn’t seem to be sheering off a bit.
label: neutral

text:
She was
a big one, and she was coming in a hurry, too, looking like a black
cloud with rows of glow-worms around it; but all of a sudden she bulged
out, big and scary, with a long row of wide-open furnace doors shining
like red-hot teeth, and her monstrous bows and guards hanging right
over us.
label: fear

text:
There was a yell at us, and a jingling of bells to stop the
engines, a powwow of cussing, and whistling of steam—and as Jim went
overboard on one side and I on the other, she come smashing straight
through the raft.
label: fear

text:
I dived—and I aimed to find the bottom, too, for a thirty-foot wheel
had got to go over me, and I wanted it to have plenty of room.
label: neutral

text:
I could
always stay under water a minute; this time I reckon I stayed under a
minute and a half.
label: neutral

text:
Then I bounced for the top in a hurry, for I was
nearly busting.
label: fear

text:
I popped out to my armpits and blowed the water out of
my nose, and puffed a bit.
label: disgust

text:
Of course there was a booming current; and
of course that boat started her engines again ten seconds after she
stopped them, for they never cared much for raftsmen; so now she was
churning along up the river, out of sight in the thick weather, though
I could hear her.
label: fear

text:
I sung out for Jim about a dozen times, but I didn’t get any answer; so
I grabbed a plank that touched me while I was “treading water,” and
struck out for shore, shoving it ahead of me.
label: fear

text:
But I made out to see
that the drift of the current was towards the left-hand shore, which
meant that I was in a crossing; so I changed off and went that way.
label: neutral

text:
It was one of these long, slanting, two-mile crossings; so I was a good
long time in getting over.
label: neutral

text:
I made a safe landing, and clumb up the
bank.
label: neutral

text:
I couldn’t see but a little ways, but I went poking along over
rough ground for a quarter of a mile or more, and then I run across a
big old-fashioned double log-house before I noticed it.
label: surprise

text:
I was going to
rush by and get away, but a lot of dogs jumped out and went to howling
and barking at me, and I knowed better than to move another peg.
label: fear

text: CHAPTER XVII.
label: neutral

text:
In about a minute somebody spoke out of a window without putting his
head out, and says:
label: surprise

text: “Be done, boys!
label: anger

text: Who’s there?”
label: surprise

text: I says:
label: neutral

text: “It’s me.”
label: neutral

text: “Who’s me?”
label: surprise

text: “George Jackson, sir.”
label: neutral

text: “What do you want?”
label: neutral

text: “I don’t want nothing, sir.
label: fear

text:
I only want to go along by, but the dogs
won’t let me.”
label: sadness

text: “What are you prowling around here this time of night for—hey?”
label: surprise

text: “I warn’t prowling around, sir, I fell overboard off of the steamboat.”
label: fear

text: “Oh, you did, did you?
label: surprise

text: Strike a light there, somebody.
label: fear

text:
What did you say
your name was?”
label: neutral

text: “George Jackson, sir.
label: neutral

text: I’m only a boy.”
label: neutral

text:
“Look here, if you’re telling the truth you needn’t be afraid—nobody’ll
hurt you.
label: fear

text: But don’t try to budge; stand right where you are.
label: fear

text:
Rouse out
Bob and Tom, some of you, and fetch the guns.
label: neutral

text:
George Jackson, is there
anybody with you?”
label: surprise

text: “No, sir, nobody.”
label: neutral

text: I heard the people stirring around in the house now, and see a light.
label: fear

text: The man sung out:
label: neutral

text: “Snatch that light away, Betsy, you old fool—ain’t you got any sense?
label: anger

text: Put it on the floor behind the front door.
label: neutral

text:
Bob, if you and Tom are
ready, take your places.”
label: neutral

text: “All ready.”
label: neutral

text: “Now, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?”
label: neutral

text: “No, sir; I never heard of them.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, that may be so, and it mayn’t.
label: neutral

text: Now, all ready.
label: neutral

text:
Step forward,
George Jackson.
label: neutral

text: And mind, don’t you hurry—come mighty slow.
label: fear

text:
If there’s
anybody with you, let him keep back—if he shows himself he’ll be shot.
label: fear

text: Come along now.
label: neutral

text:
Come slow; push the door open yourself—just enough to
squeeze in, d’ you hear?”
label: fear

text: I didn’t hurry; I couldn’t if I’d a wanted to.
label: neutral

text:
I took one slow step at
a time and there warn’t a sound, only I thought I could hear my heart.
label: fear

text:
The dogs were as still as the humans, but they followed a little behind
me.
label: neutral

text:
When I got to the three log doorsteps I heard them unlocking and
unbarring and unbolting.
label: disgust

text:
I put my hand on the door and pushed it a
little and a little more till somebody said, “There, that’s enough—put
your head in.” I done it, but I judged they would take it off.
label: neutral

text:
The candle was on the floor, and there they all was, looking at me, and
me at them, for about a quarter of a minute: Three big men with guns
pointed at me, which made me wince, I tell you; the oldest, gray and
about sixty, the other two thirty or more—all of them fine and
handsome—and the sweetest old gray-headed lady, and back of her two
young women which I couldn’t see right well.
label: fear

text: The old gentleman says:
label: neutral

text: “There; I reckon it’s all right.
label: neutral

text: Come in.”
label: neutral

text:
As soon as I was in the old gentleman he locked the door and barred it
and bolted it, and told the young men to come in with their guns, and
they all went in a big parlor that had a new rag carpet on the floor,
and got together in a corner that was out of the range of the front
windows—there warn’t none on the side.
label: neutral

text:
They held the candle, and took a
good look at me, and all said, “Why, _he_ ain’t a Shepherdson—no, there
ain’t any Shepherdson about him.” Then the old man said he hoped I
wouldn’t mind being searched for arms, because he didn’t mean no harm
by it—it was only to make sure.
label: neutral

text:
So he didn’t pry into my pockets, but
only felt outside with his hands, and said it was all right.
label: neutral

text:
He told me
to make myself easy and at home, and tell all about myself; but the old
lady says:
label: neutral

text:
“Why, bless you, Saul, the poor thing’s as wet as he can be; and don’t
you reckon it may be he’s hungry?”
label: neutral

text: “True for you, Rachel—I forgot.”
label: surprise

text: So the old lady says:
label: neutral

text:
“Betsy” (this was a nigger woman), “you fly around and get him
something to eat as quick as you can, poor thing; and one of you girls
go and wake up Buck and tell him—oh, here he is himself.
label: anger

text:
Buck, take
this little stranger and get the wet clothes off from him and dress him
up in some of yours that’s dry.”
label: disgust

text:
Buck looked about as old as me—thirteen or fourteen or along there,
though he was a little bigger than me.
label: disgust

text:
He hadn’t on anything but a
shirt, and he was very frowzy-headed.
label: anger

text:
He came in gaping and digging one
fist into his eyes, and he was dragging a gun along with the other one.
label: disgust

text: He says:
label: neutral

text: “Ain’t they no Shepherdsons around?”
label: surprise

text: They said, no, ’twas a false alarm.
label: fear

text: “Well,” he says, “if they’d a ben some, I reckon I’d a got one.”
label: neutral

text: They all laughed, and Bob says:
label: joy

text:
“Why, Buck, they might have scalped us all, you’ve been so slow in
coming.”
label: surprise

text:
“Well, nobody come after me, and it ain’t right I’m always kept down; I
don’t get no show.”
label: anger

text:
“Never mind, Buck, my boy,” says the old man, “you’ll have show enough,
all in good time, don’t you fret about that.
label: neutral

text:
Go ’long with you now, and
do as your mother told you.”
label: anger

text:
When we got up-stairs to his room he got me a coarse shirt and a
roundabout and pants of his, and I put them on.
label: disgust

text:
While I was at it he
asked me what my name was, but before I could tell him he started to
tell me about a bluejay and a young rabbit he had catched in the woods
day before yesterday, and he asked me where Moses was when the candle
went out.
label: fear

text: I said I didn’t know; I hadn’t heard about it before, no way.
label: surprise

text: “Well, guess,” he says.
label: neutral

text:
“How’m I going to guess,” says I, “when I never heard tell of it
before?”
label: neutral

text: “But you can guess, can’t you?
label: neutral

text: It’s just as easy.”
label: neutral

text: “_Which_ candle?” I says.
label: neutral

text: “Why, any candle,” he says.
label: surprise

text: “I don’t know where he was,” says I; “where was he?”
label: surprise

text: “Why, he was in the _dark!_ That’s where he was!”
label: surprise

text: “Well, if you knowed where he was, what did you ask me for?”
label: neutral

text: “Why, blame it, it’s a riddle, don’t you see?
label: anger

text:
Say, how long are you
going to stay here?
label: neutral

text: You got to stay always.
label: neutral

text:
We can just have booming
times—they don’t have no school now.
label: neutral

text: Do you own a dog?
label: surprise

text:
I’ve got a
dog—and he’ll go in the river and bring out chips that you throw in.
label: neutral

text:
Do
you like to comb up Sundays, and all that kind of foolishness?
label: neutral

text:
You bet
I don’t, but ma she makes me.
label: neutral

text: Confound these ole britches!
label: neutral

text:
I reckon I’d
better put ’em on, but I’d ruther not, it’s so warm.
label: neutral

text: Are you all ready?
label: neutral

text: All right.
label: neutral

text: Come along, old hoss.”
label: neutral

text:
Cold corn-pone, cold corn-beef, butter and buttermilk—that is what they
had for me down there, and there ain’t nothing better that ever I’ve
come across yet.
label: neutral

text:
Buck and his ma and all of them smoked cob pipes,
except the nigger woman, which was gone, and the two young women.
label: disgust

text:
They
all smoked and talked, and I eat and talked.
label: neutral

text:
The young women had quilts
around them, and their hair down their backs.
label: disgust

text:
They all asked me
questions, and I told them how pap and me and all the family was living
on a little farm down at the bottom of Arkansaw, and my sister Mary Ann
run off and got married and never was heard of no more, and Bill went
to hunt them and he warn’t heard of no more, and Tom and Mort died, and
then there warn’t nobody but just me and pap left, and he was just
trimmed down to nothing, on account of his troubles; so when he died I
took what there was left, because the farm didn’t belong to us, and
started up the river, deck passage, and fell overboard; and that was
how I come to be here.
label: neutral

text:
So they said I could have a home there as long
as I wanted it.
label: neutral

text:
Then it was most daylight and everybody went to bed,
and I went to bed with Buck, and when I waked up in the morning, drat
it all, I had forgot what my name was.
label: neutral

text:
So I laid there about an hour
trying to think, and when Buck waked up I says:
label: neutral

text: “Can you spell, Buck?”
label: neutral

text: “Yes,” he says.
label: neutral

text: “I bet you can’t spell my name,” says I.
label: neutral

text: “I bet you what you dare I can,” says he.
label: anger

text: “All right,” says I, “go ahead.”
label: neutral

text: “G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n—there now,” he says.
label: neutral

text: “Well,” says I, “you done it, but I didn’t think you could.
label: surprise

text:
It ain’t no
slouch of a name to spell—right off without studying.”
label: neutral

text:
I set it down, private, because somebody might want _me_ to spell it
next, and so I wanted to be handy with it and rattle it off like I was
used to it.
label: neutral

text: It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too.
label: joy

text:
I hadn’t
seen no house out in the country before that was so nice and had so
much style.
label: surprise

text:
It didn’t have an iron latch on the front door, nor a
wooden one with a buckskin string, but a brass knob to turn, the same
as houses in town.
label: neutral

text:
There warn’t no bed in the parlor, nor a sign of a
bed; but heaps of parlors in towns has beds in them.
label: neutral

text:
There was a big
fireplace that was bricked on the bottom, and the bricks was kept clean
and red by pouring water on them and scrubbing them with another brick;
sometimes they wash them over with red water-paint that they call
Spanish-brown, same as they do in town.
label: disgust

text:
They had big brass dog-irons
that could hold up a saw-log.
label: neutral

text:
There was a clock on the middle of the
mantelpiece, with a picture of a town painted on the bottom half of the
glass front, and a round place in the middle of it for the sun, and you
could see the pendulum swinging behind it.
label: neutral

text:
It was beautiful to hear
that clock tick; and sometimes when one of these peddlers had been
along and scoured her up and got her in good shape, she would start in
and strike a hundred and fifty before she got tuckered out.
label: neutral

text:
They
wouldn’t took any money for her.
label: anger

text:
Well, there was a big outlandish parrot on each side of the clock, made
out of something like chalk, and painted up gaudy.
label: neutral

text:
By one of the
parrots was a cat made of crockery, and a crockery dog by the other;
and when you pressed down on them they squeaked, but didn’t open their
mouths nor look different nor interested.
label: neutral

text:
They squeaked through
underneath.
label: fear

text:
There was a couple of big wild-turkey-wing fans spread out
behind those things.
label: neutral

text:
On the table in the middle of the room was a kind
of a lovely crockery basket that had apples and oranges and peaches and
grapes piled up in it, which was much redder and yellower and prettier
than real ones is, but they warn’t real because you could see where
pieces had got chipped off and showed the white chalk, or whatever it
was, underneath.
label: neutral

text:
This table had a cover made out of beautiful oilcloth, with a red and
blue spread-eagle painted on it, and a painted border all around.
label: neutral

text:
It
come all the way from Philadelphia, they said.
label: neutral

text:
There was some books,
too, piled up perfectly exact, on each corner of the table.
label: neutral

text:
One was a
big family Bible full of pictures.
label: neutral

text:
One was Pilgrim’s Progress, about a
man that left his family, it didn’t say why.
label: neutral

text:
I read considerable in it
now and then.
label: neutral

text: The statements was interesting, but tough.
label: surprise

text:
Another was
Friendship’s Offering, full of beautiful stuff and poetry; but I didn’t
read the poetry.
label: neutral

text:
Another was Henry Clay’s Speeches, and another was Dr.
Gunn’s Family Medicine, which told you all about what to do if a body
was sick or dead.
label: neutral

text: There was a hymn book, and a lot of other books.
label: neutral

text:
And
there was nice split-bottom chairs, and perfectly sound, too—not bagged
down in the middle and busted, like an old basket.
label: neutral

text:
They had pictures hung on the walls—mainly Washingtons and Lafayettes,
and battles, and Highland Marys, and one called “Signing the
Declaration.” There was some that they called crayons, which one of the
daughters which was dead made her own self when she was only fifteen
years old.
label: neutral

text:
They was different from any pictures I ever see
before—blacker, mostly, than is common.
label: neutral

text:
One was a woman in a slim black
dress, belted small under the armpits, with bulges like a cabbage in
the middle of the sleeves, and a large black scoop-shovel bonnet with a
black veil, and white slim ankles crossed about with black tape, and
very wee black slippers, like a chisel, and she was leaning pensive on
a tombstone on her right elbow, under a weeping willow, and her other
hand hanging down her side holding a white handkerchief and a reticule,
and underneath the picture it said “Shall I Never See Thee More Alas.”
Another one was a young lady with her hair all combed up straight to
the top of her head, and knotted there in front of a comb like a
chair-back, and she was crying into a handkerchief and had a dead bird
laying on its back in her other hand with its heels up, and underneath
the picture it said “I Shall Never Hear Thy Sweet Chirrup More Alas.”
There was one where a young lady was at a window looking up at the
moon, and tears running down her cheeks; and she had an open letter in
one hand with black sealing wax showing on one edge of it, and she was
mashing a locket with a chain to it against her mouth, and underneath
the picture it said “And Art Thou Gone Yes Thou Art Gone Alas.” These
was all nice pictures, I reckon, but I didn’t somehow seem to take to
them, because if ever I was down a little they always give me the
fan-tods.
label: disgust

text:
Everybody was sorry she died, because she had laid out a lot
more of these pictures to do, and a body could see by what she had done
what they had lost.
label: sadness

text:
But I reckoned that with her disposition she was
having a better time in the graveyard.
label: neutral

text:
She was at work on what they
said was her greatest picture when she took sick, and every day and
every night it was her prayer to be allowed to live till she got it
done, but she never got the chance.
label: sadness

text:
It was a picture of a young woman
in a long white gown, standing on the rail of a bridge all ready to
jump off, with her hair all down her back, and looking up to the moon,
with the tears running down her face, and she had two arms folded
across her breast, and two arms stretched out in front, and two more
reaching up towards the moon—and the idea was to see which pair would
look best, and then scratch out all the other arms; but, as I was
saying, she died before she got her mind made up, and now they kept
this picture over the head of the bed in her room, and every time her
birthday come they hung flowers on it.
label: neutral

text:
Other times it was hid with a
little curtain.
label: neutral

text:
The young woman in the picture had a kind of a nice
sweet face, but there was so many arms it made her look too spidery,
seemed to me.
label: disgust

text:
This young girl kept a scrap-book when she was alive, and used to paste
obituaries and accidents and cases of patient suffering in it out of
the _Presbyterian Observer_, and write poetry after them out of her own
head.
label: neutral

text: It was very good poetry.
label: joy

text:
This is what she wrote about a boy by
the name of Stephen Dowling Bots that fell down a well and was
drownded:
label: neutral

text: ODE TO STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS, DEC’D
label: neutral

text:
And did young Stephen sicken,
    And did young Stephen die?
label: sadness

text:
And did the sad hearts thicken,
    And did the mourners cry?
label: sadness

text:
No; such was not the fate of
    Young Stephen Dowling Bots;
Though sad hearts round him thickened,
    ’Twas not from sickness’ shots.
label: sadness

text:
No whooping-cough did rack his frame,
    Nor measles drear with spots;
Not these impaired the sacred name
    Of Stephen Dowling Bots.
label: sadness

text:
Despised love struck not with woe
    That head of curly knots,
Nor stomach troubles laid him low,
    Young Stephen Dowling Bots.
label: sadness

text: O no.
label: neutral

text:
Then list with tearful eye,
    Whilst I his fate do tell.
label: sadness

text:
His soul did from this cold world fly
    By falling down a well.
label: sadness
sadness

text:
If Emmeline Grangerford could make poetry like that before she was
fourteen, there ain’t no telling what she could a done by-and-by.
label: neutral

text:
Buck
said she could rattle off poetry like nothing.
label: disgust

text:
She didn’t ever have to
stop to think.
label: neutral

text:
He said she would slap down a line, and if she couldn’t
find anything to rhyme with it would just scratch it out and slap down
another one, and go ahead.
label: neutral

text:
She warn’t particular; she could write about
anything you choose to give her to write about just so it was sadful.
label: sadness

text:
Every time a man died, or a woman died, or a child died, she would be
on hand with her “tribute” before he was cold.
label: neutral

text:
She called them
tributes.
label: neutral

text:
The neighbors said it was the doctor first, then Emmeline,
then the undertaker—the undertaker never got in ahead of Emmeline but
once, and then she hung fire on a rhyme for the dead person’s name,
which was Whistler.
label: neutral

text:
She warn’t ever the same after that; she never
complained, but she kinder pined away and did not live long.
label: sadness

text:
Poor
thing, many’s the time I made myself go up to the little room that used
to be hers and get out her poor old scrap-book and read in it when her
pictures had been aggravating me and I had soured on her a little.
label: sadness

text:
I
liked all that family, dead ones and all, and warn’t going to let
anything come between us.
label: joy

text:
Poor Emmeline made poetry about all the dead
people when she was alive, and it didn’t seem right that there warn’t
nobody to make some about her now she was gone; so I tried to sweat out
a verse or two myself, but I couldn’t seem to make it go somehow.
label: sadness

text:
They
kept Emmeline’s room trim and nice, and all the things fixed in it just
the way she liked to have them when she was alive, and nobody ever
slept there.
label: neutral

text:
The old lady took care of the room herself, though there
was plenty of niggers, and she sewed there a good deal and read her
Bible there mostly.
label: neutral

text:
Well, as I was saying about the parlor, there was beautiful curtains on
the windows: white, with pictures painted on them of castles with vines
all down the walls, and cattle coming down to drink.
label: neutral

text:
There was a little
old piano, too, that had tin pans in it, I reckon, and nothing was ever
so lovely as to hear the young ladies sing “The Last Link is Broken”
and play “The Battle of Prague” on it.
label: neutral

text:
The walls of all the rooms was
plastered, and most had carpets on the floors, and the whole house was
whitewashed on the outside.
label: disgust

text:
It was a double house, and the big open place betwixt them was roofed
and floored, and sometimes the table was set there in the middle of the
day, and it was a cool, comfortable place.
label: joy

text: Nothing couldn’t be better.
label: neutral

text: And warn’t the cooking good, and just bushels of it too!
label: anger

text: CHAPTER XVIII.
label: neutral

text: Col. Grangerford was a gentleman, you see.
label: neutral

text:
He was a gentleman all over;
and so was his family.
label: neutral

text:
He was well born, as the saying is, and that’s
worth as much in a man as it is in a horse, so the Widow Douglas said,
and nobody ever denied that she was of the first aristocracy in our
town; and pap he always said it, too, though he warn’t no more quality
than a mudcat himself.
label: neutral

text:
Col. Grangerford was very tall and very slim,
and had a darkish-paly complexion, not a sign of red in it anywheres;
he was clean shaved every morning all over his thin face, and he had
the thinnest kind of lips, and the thinnest kind of nostrils, and a
high nose, and heavy eyebrows, and the blackest kind of eyes, sunk so
deep back that they seemed like they was looking out of caverns at you,
as you may say.
label: disgust

text:
His forehead was high, and his hair was black and
straight and hung to his shoulders.
label: disgust

text:
His hands was long and thin, and
every day of his life he put on a clean shirt and a full suit from head
to foot made out of linen so white it hurt your eyes to look at it; and
on Sundays he wore a blue tail-coat with brass buttons on it.
label: disgust

text:
He
carried a mahogany cane with a silver head to it.
label: disgust

text:
There warn’t no
frivolishness about him, not a bit, and he warn’t ever loud.
label: neutral

text:
He was as
kind as he could be—you could feel that, you know, and so you had
confidence.
label: joy

text:
Sometimes he smiled, and it was good to see; but when he
straightened himself up like a liberty-pole, and the lightning begun to
flicker out from under his eyebrows, you wanted to climb a tree first,
