text: _You_ don’t like trouble and danger.
label: fear

text:
But if only _half_ a
man—like Buck Harkness, there—shouts ‘Lynch him!
label: neutral

text:
lynch him!’ you’re
afraid to back down—afraid you’ll be found out to be what you
are—_cowards_—and so you raise a yell, and hang yourselves on to that
half-a-man’s coat-tail, and come raging up here, swearing what big
things you’re going to do.
label: anger

text:
The pitifulest thing out is a mob; that’s
what an army is—a mob; they don’t fight with courage that’s born in
them, but with courage that’s borrowed from their mass, and from their
officers.
label: neutral

text:
But a mob without any _man_ at the head of it is _beneath_
pitifulness.
label: disgust

text:
Now the thing for _you_ to do is to droop your tails and
go home and crawl in a hole.
label: neutral

text:
If any real lynching’s going to be done, it
will be done in the dark, Southern fashion; and when they come they’ll
bring their masks, and fetch a _man_ along.
label: neutral

text:
Now _leave_—and take your
half-a-man with you”—tossing his gun up across his left arm and cocking
it when he says this.
label: anger

text:
The crowd washed back sudden, and then broke all apart, and went
tearing off every which way, and Buck Harkness he heeled it after them,
looking tolerable cheap.
label: joy

text:
I could a staid if I wanted to, but I didn’t
want to.
label: sadness

text:
I went to the circus and loafed around the back side till the watchman
went by, and then dived in under the tent.
label: fear

text:
I had my twenty-dollar gold
piece and some other money, but I reckoned I better save it, because
there ain’t no telling how soon you are going to need it, away from
home and amongst strangers that way.
label: neutral

text: You can’t be too careful.
label: neutral

text:
I ain’t
opposed to spending money on circuses when there ain’t no other way,
but there ain’t no use in _wasting_ it on them.
label: neutral

text: It was a real bully circus.
label: disgust

text:
It was the splendidest sight that ever was
when they all come riding in, two and two, a gentleman and lady, side
by side, the men just in their drawers and undershirts, and no shoes
nor stirrups, and resting their hands on their thighs easy and
comfortable—there must a been twenty of them—and every lady with a
lovely complexion, and perfectly beautiful, and looking just like a
gang of real sure-enough queens, and dressed in clothes that cost
millions of dollars, and just littered with diamonds.
label: neutral

text:
It was a powerful
fine sight; I never see anything so lovely.
label: joy

text:
And then one by one they
got up and stood, and went a-weaving around the ring so gentle and wavy
and graceful, the men looking ever so tall and airy and straight, with
their heads bobbing and skimming along, away up there under the
tent-roof, and every lady’s rose-leafy dress flapping soft and silky
around her hips, and she looking like the most loveliest parasol.
label: neutral

text:
And then faster and faster they went, all of them dancing, first one
foot out in the air and then the other, the horses leaning more and
more, and the ring-master going round and round the center-pole,
cracking his whip and shouting “Hi!—hi!” and the clown cracking jokes
behind him; and by-and-by all hands dropped the reins, and every lady
put her knuckles on her hips and every gentleman folded his arms, and
then how the horses did lean over and hump themselves!
label: surprise

text:
And so one after
the other they all skipped off into the ring, and made the sweetest bow
I ever see, and then scampered out, and everybody clapped their hands
and went just about wild.
label: neutral

text:
Well, all through the circus they done the most astonishing things; and
all the time that clown carried on so it most killed the people.
label: surprise

text:
The
ring-master couldn’t ever say a word to him but he was back at him quick
as a wink with the funniest things a body ever said; and how he ever
_could_ think of so many of them, and so sudden and so pat, was what I
couldn’t noway understand.
label: surprise

text: Why, I couldn’t a thought of them in a year.
label: surprise

text:
And by-and-by a drunk man tried to get into the ring—said he wanted to
ride; said he could ride as well as anybody that ever was.
label: anger

text:
They argued
and tried to keep him out, but he wouldn’t listen, and the whole show
come to a standstill.
label: anger

text:
Then the people begun to holler at him and make
fun of him, and that made him mad, and he begun to rip and tear; so
that stirred up the people, and a lot of men begun to pile down off of
the benches and swarm towards the ring, saying, “Knock him down!
label: anger

text:
throw
him out!” and one or two women begun to scream.
label: anger

text:
So, then, the
ring-master he made a little speech, and said he hoped there wouldn’t be
no disturbance, and if the man would promise he wouldn’t make no more
trouble he would let him ride if he thought he could stay on the horse.
label: neutral

text: So everybody laughed and said all right, and the man got on.
label: joy

text:
The minute
he was on, the horse begun to rip and tear and jump and cavort around,
with two circus men hanging on to his bridle trying to hold him, and
the drunk man hanging on to his neck, and his heels flying in the air
every jump, and the whole crowd of people standing up shouting and
laughing till tears rolled down.
label: disgust

text:
And at last, sure enough, all the
circus men could do, the horse broke loose, and away he went like the
very nation, round and round the ring, with that sot laying down on him
and hanging to his neck, with first one leg hanging most to the ground
on one side, and then t’other one on t’other side, and the people just
crazy.
label: neutral

text:
It warn’t funny to me, though; I was all of a tremble to see his
danger.
label: fear

text:
But pretty soon he struggled up astraddle and grabbed the
bridle, a-reeling this way and that; and the next minute he sprung up
and dropped the bridle and stood!
label: surprise

text:
and the horse a-going like a house
afire too.
label: neutral

text:
He just stood up there, a-sailing around as easy and
comfortable as if he warn’t ever drunk in his life—and then he begun to
pull off his clothes and sling them.
label: neutral

text:
He shed them so thick they kind of
clogged up the air, and altogether he shed seventeen suits.
label: disgust

text:
And, then,
there he was, slim and handsome, and dressed the gaudiest and prettiest
you ever saw, and he lit into that horse with his whip and made him
fairly hum—and finally skipped off, and made his bow and danced off to
the dressing-room, and everybody just a-howling with pleasure and
astonishment.
label: joy

text:
Then the ring-master he see how he had been fooled, and he _was_ the
sickest ring-master you ever see, I reckon.
label: sadness

text:
Why, it was one of his own
men!
label: surprise

text:
He had got up that joke all out of his own head, and never let on
to nobody.
label: neutral

text:
Well, I felt sheepish enough to be took in so, but I
wouldn’t a been in that ring-master’s place, not for a thousand dollars.
label: fear

text:
I don’t know; there may be bullier circuses than what that one was, but
I never struck them yet.
label: neutral

text:
Anyways, it was plenty good enough for _me;_
and wherever I run across it, it can have all of _my_ custom every
time.
label: neutral

text:
Well, that night we had _our_ show; but there warn’t only about twelve
people there—just enough to pay expenses.
label: neutral

text:
And they laughed all the
time, and that made the duke mad; and everybody left, anyway, before
the show was over, but one boy which was asleep.
label: neutral

text:
So the duke said these
Arkansaw lunkheads couldn’t come up to Shakespeare; what they wanted
was low comedy—and maybe something ruther worse than low comedy, he
reckoned.
label: disgust

text: He said he could size their style.
label: neutral

text:
So next morning he got
some big sheets of wrapping paper and some black paint, and drawed off
some handbills, and stuck them up all over the village.
label: neutral

text: The bills said:
label: neutral

text: AT THE COURT HOUSE!
label: surprise

text: FOR 3 NIGHTS ONLY!
label: neutral

text:
_The World-Renowned Tragedians_
DAVID GARRICK THE YOUNGER!
label: neutral

text:
AND
EDMUND KEAN THE ELDER!
label: surprise

text:
_Of the London and Continental
Theatres_,
In their Thrilling Tragedy of
THE KING’S CAMELOPARD
OR
THE ROYAL NONESUCH!!!
label: surprise

text: _Admission 50 cents_.
label: neutral

text: Then at the bottom was the biggest line of all—which said:
label: surprise

text: LADIES AND CHILDREN NOT ADMITTED.
label: neutral

text:
“There,” says he, “if that line don’t fetch them, I dont know
Arkansaw!”
label: neutral

text: CHAPTER XXIII.
label: neutral

text:
Well, all day him and the king was hard at it, rigging up a stage and a
curtain and a row of candles for footlights; and that night the house
was jam full of men in no time.
label: surprise

text:
When the place couldn’t hold no more,
the duke he quit tending door and went around the back way and come on
to the stage and stood up before the curtain and made a little speech,
and praised up this tragedy, and said it was the most thrillingest one
that ever was; and so he went on a-bragging about the tragedy, and
about Edmund Kean the Elder, which was to play the main principal part
in it; and at last when he’d got everybody’s expectations up high
enough, he rolled up the curtain, and the next minute the king come
a-prancing out on all fours, naked; and he was painted all over,
ring-streaked-and-striped, all sorts of colors, as splendid as a
rainbow.
label: joy

text:
And—but never mind the rest of his outfit; it was just wild,
but it was awful funny.
label: disgust

text:
The people most killed themselves laughing; and
when the king got done capering and capered off behind the scenes, they
roared and clapped and stormed and haw-hawed till he come back and done
it over again, and after that they made him do it another time.
label: anger

text:
Well,
it would make a cow laugh to see the shines that old idiot cut.
label: joy

text:
Then the duke he lets the curtain down, and bows to the people, and
says the great tragedy will be performed only two nights more, on
accounts of pressing London engagements, where the seats is all sold
already for it in Drury Lane; and then he makes them another bow, and
says if he has succeeded in pleasing them and instructing them, he will
be deeply obleeged if they will mention it to their friends and get
them to come and see it.
label: neutral

text: Twenty people sings out:
label: neutral

text: “What, is it over?
label: surprise

text: Is that _all?_”
label: neutral

text: The duke says yes.
label: neutral

text: Then there was a fine time.
label: neutral

text:
Everybody sings out,
“Sold!” and rose up mad, and was a-going for that stage and them
tragedians.
label: anger

text: But a big, fine looking man jumps up on a bench and shouts:
label: disgust

text: “Hold on!
label: anger

text: Just a word, gentlemen.” They stopped to listen.
label: disgust

text:
“We are
sold—mighty badly sold.
label: sadness

text:
But we don’t want to be the laughing stock of
this whole town, I reckon, and never hear the last of this thing as
long as we live.
label: neutral

text: _No_.
label: neutral

text:
What we want is to go out of here quiet, and
talk this show up, and sell the _rest_ of the town!
label: anger

text:
Then we’ll all be
in the same boat.
label: neutral

text:
Ain’t that sensible?” (“You bet it is!—the jedge is
right!” everybody sings out.)
label: anger

text:
“All right, then—not a word about any
sell.
label: neutral

text: Go along home, and advise everybody to come and see the tragedy.”
label: neutral

text:
Next day you couldn’t hear nothing around that town but how splendid
that show was.
label: joy

text:
House was jammed again that night, and we sold this
crowd the same way.
label: neutral

text:
When me and the king and the duke got home to the
raft we all had a supper; and by-and-by, about midnight, they made Jim
and me back her out and float her down the middle of the river, and
fetch her in and hide her about two mile below town.
label: neutral

text:
The third night the house was crammed again—and they warn’t new-comers
this time, but people that was at the show the other two nights.
label: surprise

text:
I
stood by the duke at the door, and I see that every man that went in
had his pockets bulging, or something muffled up under his coat—and I
see it warn’t no perfumery, neither, not by a long sight.
label: fear

text:
I smelt
sickly eggs by the barrel, and rotten cabbages, and such things; and if
I know the signs of a dead cat being around, and I bet I do, there was
sixty-four of them went in.
label: disgust

text:
I shoved in there for a minute, but it was
too various for me; I couldn’t stand it.
label: disgust

text:
Well, when the place couldn’t
hold no more people the duke he give a fellow a quarter and told him to
tend door for him a minute, and then he started around for the stage
door, I after him; but the minute we turned the corner and was in the
dark he says:
label: anger

text:
“Walk fast now till you get away from the houses, and then shin for the
raft like the dickens was after you!”
label: fear

text: I done it, and he done the same.
label: neutral

text:
We struck the raft at the same time,
and in less than two seconds we was gliding down stream, all dark and
still, and edging towards the middle of the river, nobody saying a
word.
label: fear

text:
I reckoned the poor king was in for a gaudy time of it with the
audience, but nothing of the sort; pretty soon he crawls out from under
the wigwam, and says:
label: neutral

text: “Well, how’d the old thing pan out this time, duke?”
label: neutral

text: He hadn’t been up town at all.
label: neutral

text: We never showed a light till we was about ten mile below the village.
label: fear

text:
Then we lit up and had a supper, and the king and the duke fairly
laughed their bones loose over the way they’d served them people.
label: disgust

text:
The
duke says:
label: neutral

text: “Greenhorns, flatheads!
label: surprise

text:
_I_ knew the first house would keep mum and let
the rest of the town get roped in; and I knew they’d lay for us the
third night, and consider it was _their_ turn now.
label: neutral

text:
Well, it _is_ their
turn, and I’d give something to know how much they’d take for it.
label: neutral

text:
I
_would_ just like to know how they’re putting in their opportunity.
label: neutral

text:
They can turn it into a picnic if they want to—they brought plenty
provisions.”
label: neutral

text:
Them rapscallions took in four hundred and sixty-five dollars in that
three nights.
label: neutral

text:
I never see money hauled in by the wagon-load like that
before.
label: surprise

text: By-and-by, when they was asleep and snoring, Jim says:
label: neutral

text: “Don’t it s’prise you de way dem kings carries on, Huck?”
label: neutral

text: “No,” I says, “it don’t.”
label: neutral

text: “Why don’t it, Huck?”
label: anger

text: “Well, it don’t, because it’s in the breed.
label: neutral

text:
I reckon they’re all
alike.”
label: neutral

text:
“But, Huck, dese kings o’ ourn is reglar rapscallions; dat’s jist what
dey is; dey’s reglar rapscallions.”
label: neutral

text:
“Well, that’s what I’m a-saying; all kings is mostly rapscallions, as
fur as I can make out.”
label: neutral

text: “Is dat so?”
label: surprise

text: “You read about them once—you’ll see.
label: neutral

text:
Look at Henry the Eight; this’n
’s a Sunday-school Superintendent to _him_.
label: surprise

text:
And look at Charles Second,
and Louis Fourteen, and Louis Fifteen, and James Second, and Edward
Second, and Richard Third, and forty more; besides all them Saxon
heptarchies that used to rip around so in old times and raise Cain.
label: neutral

text:
My,
you ought to seen old Henry the Eight when he was in bloom.
label: surprise

text:
He _was_ a
blossom.
label: neutral

text:
He used to marry a new wife every day, and chop off her head
next morning.
label: disgust

text:
And he would do it just as indifferent as if he was
ordering up eggs.
label: disgust

text: ‘Fetch up Nell Gwynn,’ he says.
label: neutral

text: They fetch her up.
label: neutral

text: Next morning, ‘Chop off her head!’ And they chop it off.
label: anger

text:
‘Fetch up Jane
Shore,’ he says; and up she comes.
label: neutral

text:
Next morning, ‘Chop off her
head’—and they chop it off.
label: neutral

text:
‘Ring up Fair Rosamun.’ Fair Rosamun
answers the bell.
label: neutral

text:
Next morning, ‘Chop off her head.’ And he made every
one of them tell him a tale every night; and he kept that up till he
had hogged a thousand and one tales that way, and then he put them all
in a book, and called it Domesday Book—which was a good name and stated
the case.
label: neutral

text:
You don’t know kings, Jim, but I know them; and this old rip
of ourn is one of the cleanest I’ve struck in history.
label: neutral

text:
Well, Henry he
takes a notion he wants to get up some trouble with this country.
label: neutral

text:
How
does he go at it—give notice?—give the country a show?
label: anger

text: No.
label: neutral

text:
All of a
sudden he heaves all the tea in Boston Harbor overboard, and whacks out
a declaration of independence, and dares them to come on.
label: neutral

text:
That was
_his_ style—he never give anybody a chance.
label: anger

text:
He had suspicions of his
father, the Duke of Wellington.
label: fear

text: Well, what did he do?
label: surprise

text:
Ask him to show
up?
label: surprise

text: No—drownded him in a butt of mamsey, like a cat.
label: disgust

text:
S’pose people left
money laying around where he was—what did he do?
label: surprise

text: He collared it.
label: disgust

text:
S’pose
he contracted to do a thing, and you paid him, and didn’t set down
there and see that he done it—what did he do?
label: anger

text:
He always done the other
thing.
label: neutral

text: S’pose he opened his mouth—what then?
label: surprise

text:
If he didn’t shut it up
powerful quick he’d lose a lie every time.
label: neutral

text:
That’s the kind of a bug
Henry was; and if we’d a had him along ’stead of our kings he’d a
fooled that town a heap worse than ourn done.
label: disgust
neutral

text:
All I say is, kings
is kings, and you got to make allowances.
label: neutral

text:
Take them all around, they’re
a mighty ornery lot.
label: neutral

text: It’s the way they’re raised.”
label: neutral

text: “But dis one do _smell_ so like de nation, Huck.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, they all do, Jim.
label: neutral

text:
_We_ can’t help the way a king smells; history
don’t tell no way.”
label: neutral

text: “Now de duke, he’s a tolerble likely man in some ways.”
label: neutral

text: “Yes, a duke’s different.
label: neutral

text: But not very different.
label: neutral

text:
This one’s a middling
hard lot for a duke.
label: neutral

text:
When he’s drunk, there ain’t no near-sighted man
could tell him from a king.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, anyways, I doan’ hanker for no mo’ un um, Huck.
label: fear

text:
Dese is all I
kin stan’.”
label: neutral

text: “It’s the way I feel, too, Jim.
label: neutral

text:
But we’ve got them on our hands, and we
got to remember what they are, and make allowances.
label: neutral

text:
Sometimes I wish we
could hear of a country that’s out of kings.”
label: surprise

text: What was the use to tell Jim these warn’t real kings and dukes?
label: neutral

text:
It
wouldn’t a done no good; and, besides, it was just as I said: you
couldn’t tell them from the real kind.
label: neutral

text: I went to sleep, and Jim didn’t call me when it was my turn.
label: sadness

text:
He often
done that.
label: neutral

text:
When I waked up just at daybreak, he was sitting there with
his head down betwixt his knees, moaning and mourning to himself.
label: sadness

text:
I
didn’t take notice nor let on.
label: anger

text: I knowed what it was about.
label: neutral

text:
He was
thinking about his wife and his children, away up yonder, and he was
low and homesick; because he hadn’t ever been away from home before in
his life; and I do believe he cared just as much for his people as
white folks does for their’n.
label: sadness

text:
It don’t seem natural, but I reckon it’s
so.
label: neutral

text:
He was often moaning and mourning that way nights, when he judged I
was asleep, and saying, “Po’ little ’Lizabeth!
label: sadness

text: po’ little Johnny!
label: surprise

text:
it’s
mighty hard; I spec’ I ain’t ever gwyne to see you no mo’, no mo’!” He
was a mighty good nigger, Jim was.
label: disgust

text:
But this time I somehow got to talking to him about his wife and young
ones; and by-and-by he says:
label: surprise

text:
“What makes me feel so bad dis time ’uz bekase I hear sumpn over yonder
on de bank like a whack, er a slam, while ago, en it mine me er de time
I treat my little ’Lizabeth so ornery.
label: sadness

text:
She warn’t on’y ’bout fo’ year
ole, en she tuck de sk’yarlet fever, en had a powful rough spell; but
she got well, en one day she was a-stannin’ aroun’, en I says to her, I
says:
label: sadness

text: “‘Shet de do’.’
label: neutral

text: “She never done it; jis’ stood dah, kiner smilin’ up at me.
label: neutral

text:
It make me
mad; en I says agin, mighty loud, I says:
label: anger

text: “‘Doan’ you hear me?—shet de do’!’
label: anger

text: “She jis stood de same way, kiner smilin’ up.
label: neutral

text: I was a-bilin’!
label: surprise

text: I says:
label: neutral

text: “‘I lay I _make_ you mine!’
label: anger

text: “En wid dat I fetch’ her a slap side de head dat sont her a-sprawlin’.
label: anger

text:
Den I went into de yuther room, en ’uz gone ’bout ten minutes; en when
I come back dah was dat do’ a-stannin’ open _yit_, en dat chile
stannin’ mos’ right in it, a-lookin’ down and mournin’, en de tears
runnin’ down.
label: sadness

text: My, but I _wuz_ mad!
label: anger

text:
I was a-gwyne for de chile, but jis’
den—it was a do’ dat open innerds—jis’ den, ’long come de wind en slam
it to, behine de chile, ker-_blam!_—en my lan’, de chile never move’!
label: neutral

text: My breff mos’ hop outer me; en I feel so—so—I doan’ know _how_ I feel.
label: sadness

text:
I crope out, all a-tremblin’, en crope aroun’ en open de do’ easy en
slow, en poke my head in behine de chile, sof’ en still, en all uv a
sudden I says _pow!_ jis’ as loud as I could yell.
label: neutral

text:
_She never budge!_
Oh, Huck, I bust out a-cryin’ en grab her up in my arms, en say, ‘Oh,
de po’ little thing!
label: anger

text:
De Lord God Amighty fogive po’ ole Jim, kaze he
never gwyne to fogive hisself as long’s he live!’ Oh, she was plumb
deef en dumb, Huck, plumb deef en dumb—en I’d ben a-treat’n her so!”
label: anger

text: CHAPTER XXIV.
label: neutral

text:
Next day, towards night, we laid up under a little willow tow-head out
in the middle, where there was a village on each side of the river, and
the duke and the king begun to lay out a plan for working them towns.
label: fear

text:
Jim he spoke to the duke, and said he hoped it wouldn’t take but a few
hours, because it got mighty heavy and tiresome to him when he had to
lay all day in the wigwam tied with the rope.
label: neutral

text:
You see, when we left him
all alone we had to tie him, because if anybody happened on to him all
by himself and not tied it wouldn’t look much like he was a runaway
nigger, you know.
label: disgust

text:
So the duke said it _was_ kind of hard to have to lay
roped all day, and he’d cipher out some way to get around it.
label: neutral

text: He was uncommon bright, the duke was, and he soon struck it.
label: neutral

text:
He dressed
Jim up in King Lear’s outfit—it was a long curtain-calico gown, and a
white horse-hair wig and whiskers; and then he took his theater paint
and painted Jim’s face and hands and ears and neck all over a dead,
dull, solid blue, like a man that’s been drownded nine days.
label: neutral

text:
Blamed if
he warn’t the horriblest looking outrage I ever see.
label: anger

text:
Then the duke took
and wrote out a sign on a shingle so:
label: neutral

text: _Sick Arab—but harmless when not out of his head._
label: sadness

text:
And he nailed that shingle to a lath, and stood the lath up four or
five foot in front of the wigwam.
label: neutral

text: Jim was satisfied.
label: neutral

text:
He said it was a
sight better than lying tied a couple of years every day, and trembling
all over every time there was a sound.
label: fear

text:
The duke told him to make
himself free and easy, and if anybody ever come meddling around, he
must hop out of the wigwam, and carry on a little, and fetch a howl or
two like a wild beast, and he reckoned they would light out and leave
him alone.
label: anger

text:
Which was sound enough judgment; but you take the average
man, and he wouldn’t wait for him to howl.
label: anger

text:
Why, he didn’t only look
like he was dead, he looked considerable more than that.
label: surprise

text:
These rapscallions wanted to try the Nonesuch again, because there was
so much money in it, but they judged it wouldn’t be safe, because maybe
the news might a worked along down by this time.
label: neutral

text:
They couldn’t hit no
project that suited exactly; so at last the duke said he reckoned he’d
lay off and work his brains an hour or two and see if he couldn’t put
up something on the Arkansaw village; and the king he allowed he would
drop over to t’other village without any plan, but just trust in
Providence to lead him the profitable way—meaning the devil, I reckon.
label: neutral

text:
We had all bought store clothes where we stopped last; and now the king
put his’n on, and he told me to put mine on.
label: neutral

text: I done it, of course.
label: neutral

text:
The
king’s duds was all black, and he did look real swell and starchy.
label: disgust

text:
I
never knowed how clothes could change a body before.
label: surprise

text:
Why, before, he
looked like the orneriest old rip that ever was; but now, when he’d
take off his new white beaver and make a bow and do a smile, he looked
that grand and good and pious that you’d say he had walked right out of
the ark, and maybe was old Leviticus himself.
label: neutral

text:
Jim cleaned up the canoe,
and I got my paddle ready.
label: neutral

text:
There was a big steamboat laying at the
shore away up under the point, about three mile above the town—been
there a couple of hours, taking on freight.
label: fear

text: Says the king:
label: neutral

text:
“Seein’ how I’m dressed, I reckon maybe I better arrive down from St.
Louis or Cincinnati, or some other big place.
label: neutral

text:
Go for the steamboat,
Huckleberry; we’ll come down to the village on her.”
label: neutral

text: I didn’t have to be ordered twice to go and take a steamboat ride.
label: neutral

text:
I
fetched the shore a half a mile above the village, and then went
scooting along the bluff bank in the easy water.
label: fear

text:
Pretty soon we come to
a nice innocent-looking young country jake setting on a log swabbing
the sweat off of his face, for it was powerful warm weather; and he had
a couple of big carpet-bags by him.
label: neutral

text: “Run her nose in shore,” says the king.
label: disgust

text: I done it.
label: neutral

text:
“Wher’ you bound
for, young man?”
label: neutral

text: “For the steamboat; going to Orleans.”
label: neutral

text: “Git aboard,” says the king.
label: disgust

text:
“Hold on a minute, my servant ’ll he’p you
with them bags.
label: neutral

text:
Jump out and he’p the gentleman, Adolphus”—meaning me,
I see.
label: neutral

text: I done so, and then we all three started on again.
label: neutral

text:
The young chap was
mighty thankful; said it was tough work toting his baggage such
weather.
label: neutral

text:
He asked the king where he was going, and the king told him
he’d come down the river and landed at the other village this morning,
and now he was going up a few mile to see an old friend on a farm up
there.
label: surprise

text: The young fellow says:
label: neutral

text:
“When I first see you I says to myself, ‘It’s Mr. Wilks, sure, and he
come mighty near getting here in time.’ But then I says again, ‘No, I
reckon it ain’t him, or else he wouldn’t be paddling up the river.’ You
_ain’t_ him, are you?”
label: neutral

text:
“No, my name’s Blodgett—Elexander Blodgett—_Reverend_ Elexander
Blodgett, I s’pose I must say, as I’m one o’ the Lord’s poor servants.
label: neutral

text:
But still I’m jist as able to be sorry for Mr. Wilks for not arriving
in time, all the same, if he’s missed anything by it—which I hope he
hasn’t.”
label: neutral

text:
“Well, he don’t miss any property by it, because he’ll get that all
right; but he’s missed seeing his brother Peter die—which he mayn’t
mind, nobody can tell as to that—but his brother would a give anything
in this world to see _him_ before he died; never talked about nothing
else all these three weeks; hadn’t seen him since they was boys
together—and hadn’t ever seen his brother William at all—that’s the
deef and dumb one—William ain’t more than thirty or thirty-five.
label: neutral

text:
Peter
and George were the only ones that come out here; George was the
married brother; him and his wife both died last year.
label: sadness

text:
Harvey and
William’s the only ones that’s left now; and, as I was saying, they
haven’t got here in time.”
label: neutral

text: “Did anybody send ’em word?”
label: surprise

text:
“Oh, yes; a month or two ago, when Peter was first took; because Peter
said then that he sorter felt like he warn’t going to get well this
time.
label: neutral

text:
You see, he was pretty old, and George’s g’yirls was too young to
be much company for him, except Mary Jane, the red-headed one; and so
he was kinder lonesome after George and his wife died, and didn’t seem
to care much to live.
label: neutral

text:
He most desperately wanted to see Harvey—and
William, too, for that matter—because he was one of them kind that
can’t bear to make a will.
label: neutral

text:
He left a letter behind for Harvey, and said
he’d told in it where his money was hid, and how he wanted the rest of
the property divided up so George’s g’yirls would be all right—for
George didn’t leave nothing.
label: neutral

text:
And that letter was all they could get him
to put a pen to.”
label: neutral

text: “Why do you reckon Harvey don’t come?
label: surprise

text: Wher’ does he live?”
label: neutral

text:
“Oh, he lives in England—Sheffield—preaches there—hasn’t ever been in
this country.
label: surprise

text:
He hasn’t had any too much time—and besides he mightn’t a
got the letter at all, you know.”
label: neutral

text: “Too bad, too bad he couldn’t a lived to see his brothers, poor soul.
label: disgust

text: You going to Orleans, you say?”
label: surprise

text: “Yes, but that ain’t only a part of it.
label: neutral

text:
I’m going in a ship, next
Wednesday, for Ryo Janeero, where my uncle lives.”
label: neutral

text: “It’s a pretty long journey.
label: neutral

text: But it’ll be lovely; wisht I was a-going.
label: joy

text: Is Mary Jane the oldest?
label: neutral

text: How old is the others?”
label: neutral

text:
“Mary Jane’s nineteen, Susan’s fifteen, and Joanna’s about
fourteen—that’s the one that gives herself to good works and has a
hare-lip.”
label: neutral

text: “Poor things!
label: sadness

text: to be left alone in the cold world so.”
label: sadness

text: “Well, they could be worse off.
label: disgust

text:
Old Peter had friends, and they ain’t
going to let them come to no harm.
label: neutral

text:
There’s Hobson, the Babtis’
preacher; and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford,
and Levi Bell, the lawyer; and Dr. Robinson, and their wives, and the
widow Bartley, and—well, there’s a lot of them; but these are the ones
that Peter was thickest with, and used to write about sometimes, when
he wrote home; so Harvey ’ll know where to look for friends when he
gets here.”
label: neutral

text:
Well, the old man went on asking questions till he just fairly emptied
that young fellow.
label: disgust

text:
Blamed if he didn’t inquire about everybody and
everything in that blessed town, and all about the Wilkses; and about
Peter’s business—which was a tanner; and about George’s—which was a
carpenter; and about Harvey’s—which was a dissentering minister; and so
on, and so on.
label: neutral

text: Then he says:
label: neutral

text: “What did you want to walk all the way up to the steamboat for?”
label: surprise

text:
“Because she’s a big Orleans boat, and I was afeard she mightn’t stop
there.
label: neutral

text: When they’re deep they won’t stop for a hail.
label: neutral

text:
A Cincinnati boat
will, but this is a St. Louis one.”
label: neutral

text: “Was Peter Wilks well off?”
label: neutral

text: “Oh, yes, pretty well off.
label: neutral

text:
He had houses and land, and it’s reckoned he
left three or four thousand in cash hid up som’ers.”
label: neutral

text: “When did you say he died?”
label: surprise

text: “I didn’t say, but it was last night.”
label: neutral

text: “Funeral to-morrow, likely?”
label: neutral

text: “Yes, ’bout the middle of the day.”
label: neutral

text:
“Well, it’s all terrible sad; but we’ve all got to go, one time or
another.
label: sadness

text:
So what we want to do is to be prepared; then we’re all
right.”
label: neutral

text: “Yes, sir, it’s the best way.
label: neutral

text: Ma used to always say that.”
label: neutral

text:
When we struck the boat she was about done loading, and pretty soon she
got off.
label: fear

text:
The king never said nothing about going aboard, so I lost my
ride, after all.
label: sadness

text:
When the boat was gone the king made me paddle up
another mile to a lonesome place, and then he got ashore and says:
label: sadness

text:
“Now hustle back, right off, and fetch the duke up here, and the new
carpet-bags.
label: neutral

text:
And if he’s gone over to t’other side, go over there and
git him.
label: neutral

text: And tell him to git himself up regardless.
label: neutral

text: Shove along, now.”
label: neutral

text: I see what _he_ was up to; but I never said nothing, of course.
label: surprise

text:
When I
got back with the duke we hid the canoe, and then they set down on a
log, and the king told him everything, just like the young fellow had
said it—every last word of it.
label: anger

text:
And all the time he was a-doing it he
tried to talk like an Englishman; and he done it pretty well, too, for
a slouch.
label: neutral

text:
I can’t imitate him, and so I ain’t a-going to try to; but he
really done it pretty good.
label: joy

text: Then he says:
label: neutral

text: “How are you on the deef and dumb, Bilgewater?”
label: anger

text:
The duke said, leave him alone for that; said he had played a deef and
dumb person on the histronic boards.
label: disgust

text:
So then they waited for a
steamboat.
label: neutral

text:
About the middle of the afternoon a couple of little boats come along,
but they didn’t come from high enough up the river; but at last there
was a big one, and they hailed her.
label: joy

text:
She sent out her yawl, and we went
aboard, and she was from Cincinnati; and when they found we only wanted
to go four or five mile they was booming mad, and gave us a cussing,
and said they wouldn’t land us.
label: anger

text: But the king was ca’m.
label: neutral

text: He says:
label: neutral

text:
“If gentlemen kin afford to pay a dollar a mile apiece to be took on
and put off in a yawl, a steamboat kin afford to carry ’em, can’t it?”
label: neutral

text:
So they softened down and said it was all right; and when we got to the
village they yawled us ashore.
label: neutral

text:
About two dozen men flocked down when
they see the yawl a-coming, and when the king says:
label: fear

text:
“Kin any of you gentlemen tell me wher’ Mr. Peter Wilks lives?” they
give a glance at one another, and nodded their heads, as much as to
say, “What d’ I tell you?” Then one of them says, kind of soft and
gentle:
label: neutral

text:
“I’m sorry sir, but the best we can do is to tell you where he _did_
live yesterday evening.”
label: sadness

text:
Sudden as winking the ornery old cretur went all to smash, and fell up
against the man, and put his chin on his shoulder, and cried down his
back, and says:
label: neutral

text:
“Alas, alas, our poor brother—gone, and we never got to see him; oh,
it’s too, _too_ hard!”
label: sadness

text:
Then he turns around, blubbering, and makes a lot of idiotic signs to
the duke on his hands, and blamed if _he_ didn’t drop a carpet-bag and
bust out a-crying.
label: anger

text:
If they warn’t the beatenest lot, them two frauds,
that ever I struck.
label: neutral

text:
Well, the men gathered around and sympathized with them, and said all
sorts of kind things to them, and carried their carpet-bags up the hill
for them, and let them lean on them and cry, and told the king all
about his brother’s last moments, and the king he told it all over
again on his hands to the duke, and both of them took on about that
dead tanner like they’d lost the twelve disciples.
label: neutral

text:
Well, if ever I
struck anything like it, I’m a nigger.
label: fear

text:
It was enough to make a body
ashamed of the human race.
label: disgust

text: CHAPTER XXV.
label: neutral

text:
The news was all over town in two minutes, and you could see the people
tearing down on the run from every which way, some of them putting on
their coats as they come.
label: neutral

text:
Pretty soon we was in the middle of a crowd,
and the noise of the tramping was like a soldier march.
label: fear

text:
The windows and
dooryards was full; and every minute somebody would say, over a fence:
label: disgust

text: “Is it _them?_”
label: neutral

text: And somebody trotting along with the gang would answer back and say:
label: neutral

text: “You bet it is.”
label: neutral

text:
When we got to the house the street in front of it was packed, and the
three girls was standing in the door.
label: fear

text:
Mary Jane _was_ red-headed, but
that don’t make no difference, she was most awful beautiful, and her
face and her eyes was all lit up like glory, she was so glad her uncles
was come.
label: joy

text:
The king he spread his arms, and Mary Jane she jumped for
them, and the hare-lip jumped for the duke, and there they _had_ it!
label: surprise

text:
Everybody most, leastways women, cried for joy to see them meet again
at last and have such good times.
label: joy

text:
Then the king he hunched the duke private—I see him do it—and then he
looked around and see the coffin, over in the corner on two chairs; so
then him and the duke, with a hand across each other’s shoulder, and
t’other hand to their eyes, walked slow and solemn over there,
everybody dropping back to give them room, and all the talk and noise
stopping, people saying “Sh!” and all the men taking their hats off and
drooping their heads, so you could a heard a pin fall.
label: surprise

text:
And when they
got there they bent over and looked in the coffin, and took one sight,
and then they bust out a-crying so you could a heard them to Orleans,
most; and then they put their arms around each other’s necks, and hung
their chins over each other’s shoulders; and then for three minutes, or
maybe four, I never see two men leak the way they done.
label: neutral

text:
And, mind you,
everybody was doing the same; and the place was that damp I never see
anything like it.
label: disgust

text:
Then one of them got on one side of the coffin, and
t’other on t’other side, and they kneeled down and rested their
foreheads on the coffin, and let on to pray all to themselves.
label: neutral

text:
Well,
when it come to that it worked the crowd like you never see anything
like it, and everybody broke down and went to sobbing right out
loud—the poor girls, too; and every woman, nearly, went up to the
girls, without saying a word, and kissed them, solemn, on the forehead,
and then put their hand on their head, and looked up towards the sky,
with the tears running down, and then busted out and went off sobbing
and swabbing, and give the next woman a show.
label: sadness

text:
I never see anything so
disgusting.
label: disgust

text:
Well, by-and-by the king he gets up and comes forward a little, and
works himself up and slobbers out a speech, all full of tears and
flapdoodle about its being a sore trial for him and his poor brother to
lose the diseased, and to miss seeing diseased alive after the long
journey of four thousand mile, but it’s a trial that’s sweetened and
sanctified to us by this dear sympathy and these holy tears, and so he
thanks them out of his heart and out of his brother’s heart, because
out of their mouths they can’t, words being too weak and cold, and all
that kind of rot and slush, till it was just sickening; and then he
blubbers out a pious goody-goody Amen, and turns himself loose and goes
to crying fit to bust.
label: sadness

text:
And the minute the words were out of his mouth somebody over in the
crowd struck up the doxolojer, and everybody joined in with all their
might, and it just warmed you up and made you feel as good as church
letting out.
label: neutral

text:
Music _is_ a good thing; and after all that soul-butter
and hogwash I never see it freshen up things so, and sound so honest
and bully.
label: joy

text:
Then the king begins to work his jaw again, and says how him and his
nieces would be glad if a few of the main principal friends of the
family would take supper here with them this evening, and help set up
with the ashes of the diseased; and says if his poor brother laying
yonder could speak he knows who he would name, for they was names that
was very dear to him, and mentioned often in his letters; and so he
will name the same, to wit, as follows, vizz.:—Rev.
label: neutral

text:
Mr. Hobson, and
Deacon Lot Hovey, and Mr. Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford, and Levi
Bell, and Dr. Robinson, and their wives, and the widow Bartley.
label: neutral

text: Rev.
label: neutral

text:
Hobson and Dr. Robinson was down to the end of the town a-hunting
together—that is, I mean the doctor was shipping a sick man to t’other
world, and the preacher was pinting him right.
label: disgust

text:
Lawyer Bell was away up
to Louisville on business.
label: neutral

text:
But the rest was on hand, and so they all
come and shook hands with the king and thanked him and talked to him;
and then they shook hands with the duke and didn’t say nothing, but
just kept a-smiling and bobbing their heads like a passel of sapheads
whilst he made all sorts of signs with his hands and said
“Goo-goo—goo-goo-goo” all the time, like a baby that can’t talk.
label: neutral

text:
So the king he blattered along, and managed to inquire about pretty
much everybody and dog in town, by his name, and mentioned all sorts of
little things that happened one time or another in the town, or to
George’s family, or to Peter.
label: neutral

text:
And he always let on that Peter wrote him
the things; but that was a lie: he got every blessed one of them out of
that young flathead that we canoed up to the steamboat.
label: neutral

text:
Then Mary Jane she fetched the letter her father left behind, and the
king he read it out loud and cried over it.
label: neutral

text:
It give the dwelling-house
and three thousand dollars, gold, to the girls; and it give the tanyard
(which was doing a good business), along with some other houses and
land (worth about seven thousand), and three thousand dollars in gold
to Harvey and William, and told where the six thousand cash was hid
down cellar.
label: neutral

text:
So these two frauds said they’d go and fetch it up, and
have everything square and above-board; and told me to come with a
candle.
label: neutral

text:
We shut the cellar door behind us, and when they found the bag
they spilt it out on the floor, and it was a lovely sight, all them
yaller-boys.
label: joy

text: My, the way the king’s eyes did shine!
label: surprise

text:
He slaps the duke
on the shoulder and says:
label: neutral

text: “Oh, _this_ ain’t bully nor noth’n!
label: anger

text: Oh, no, I reckon not!
label: surprise

text:
Why, Bilji,
it beats the Nonesuch, _don’t_ it?”
label: surprise

text: The duke allowed it did.
label: neutral

text:
They pawed the yaller-boys, and sifted them
through their fingers and let them jingle down on the floor; and the
king says:
label: neutral

text:
“It ain’t no use talkin’; bein’ brothers to a rich dead man and
representatives of furrin heirs that’s got left is the line for you and
me, Bilge.
label: neutral

text: Thish yer comes of trust’n to Providence.
label: neutral

text:
It’s the best way,
in the long run.
label: neutral

text: I’ve tried ’em all, and ther’ ain’t no better way.”
label: neutral

text:
Most everybody would a been satisfied with the pile, and took it on
trust; but no, they must count it.
label: neutral

text:
So they counts it, and it comes out
four hundred and fifteen dollars short.
label: neutral

text: Says the king:
label: neutral

text:
“Dern him, I wonder what he done with that four hundred and fifteen
dollars?”
label: surprise

text: They worried over that awhile, and ransacked all around for it.
label: neutral

text:
Then
the duke says:
label: neutral

text:
“Well, he was a pretty sick man, and likely he made a mistake—I reckon
that’s the way of it.
label: neutral

text:
The best way’s to let it go, and keep still about
it.
label: neutral

text: We can spare it.”
label: neutral

text: “Oh, shucks, yes, we can _spare_ it.
label: disgust

text:
I don’t k’yer noth’n ’bout
that—it’s the _count_ I’m thinkin’ about.
label: neutral

text:
We want to be awful square
and open and above-board here, you know.
label: disgust

text:
We want to lug this h-yer
money up stairs and count it before everybody—then ther’ ain’t noth’n
suspicious.
label: fear

text:
But when the dead man says ther’s six thous’n dollars, you
know, we don’t want to—”
label: disgust

text: “Hold on,” says the duke.
label: anger

text:
“Le’s make up the deffisit,” and he begun to
haul out yaller-boys out of his pocket.
label: neutral

text:
“It’s a most amaz’n’ good idea, duke—you _have_ got a rattlin’ clever
head on you,” says the king.
label: neutral

text:
“Blest if the old Nonesuch ain’t a heppin’
us out agin,” and _he_ begun to haul out yaller-jackets and stack them
up.
label: neutral

text: It most busted them, but they made up the six thousand clean and clear.
label: neutral

text: “Say,” says the duke, “I got another idea.
label: neutral

text:
Le’s go up stairs and count
this money, and then take and _give it to the girls_.”
label: neutral

text: “Good land, duke, lemme hug you!
label: joy

text:
It’s the most dazzling idea ’at ever a
man struck.
label: joy

text: You have cert’nly got the most astonishin’ head I ever see.
label: surprise

text: Oh, this is the boss dodge, ther’ ain’t no mistake ’bout it.
label: disgust

text:
Let ’em
fetch along their suspicions now if they want to—this’ll lay ’em out.”
label: neutral

text:
When we got up-stairs everybody gethered around the table, and the king
he counted it and stacked it up, three hundred dollars in a pile—twenty
elegant little piles.
label: disgust

text:
Everybody looked hungry at it, and licked their
chops.
label: disgust

text:
Then they raked it into the bag again, and I see the king begin
to swell himself up for another speech.
label: neutral

text: He says:
label: neutral

text:
“Friends all, my poor brother that lays yonder has done generous by
them that’s left behind in the vale of sorrers.
label: sadness

text:
He has done generous by
these yer poor little lambs that he loved and sheltered, and that’s
left fatherless and motherless.
label: sadness

text:
Yes, and we that knowed him knows that
he would a done _more_ generous by ’em if he hadn’t ben afeard o’
woundin’ his dear William and me.
label: neutral

text: Now, _wouldn’t_ he?
label: anger

text:
Ther’ ain’t no
question ’bout it in _my_ mind.
label: neutral

text:
Well, then, what kind o’ brothers would
it be that ’d stand in his way at sech a time?
label: disgust

text:
And what kind o’ uncles
would it be that ’d rob—yes, _rob_—sech poor sweet lambs as these ’at
he loved so at sech a time?
label: surprise

text:
If I know William—and I _think_ I
do—he—well, I’ll jest ask him.” He turns around and begins to make a
lot of signs to the duke with his hands, and the duke he looks at him
stupid and leather-headed a while; then all of a sudden he seems to
catch his meaning, and jumps for the king, goo-gooing with all his
might for joy, and hugs him about fifteen times before he lets up.
label: neutral

text:
Then
the king says, “I knowed it; I reckon _that_’ll convince anybody the
way _he_ feels about it.
label: neutral

text:
Here, Mary Jane, Susan, Joanner, take the
money—take it _all_.
label: neutral

text:
It’s the gift of him that lays yonder, cold but
joyful.”
label: joy

text:
Mary Jane she went for him, Susan and the hare-lip went for the duke,
and then such another hugging and kissing I never see yet.
label: neutral

text:
And
everybody crowded up with the tears in their eyes, and most shook the
hands off of them frauds, saying all the time:
label: fear

text: “You _dear_ good souls!—how _lovely!_—how _could_ you!”
label: sadness

text:
Well, then, pretty soon all hands got to talking about the diseased
again, and how good he was, and what a loss he was, and all that; and
before long a big iron-jawed man worked himself in there from outside,
and stood a-listening and looking, and not saying anything; and nobody
saying anything to him either, because the king was talking and they
was all busy listening.
label: neutral

text:
The king was saying—in the middle of something
he’d started in on—

text: “—they bein’ partickler friends o’ the diseased.

text:
That’s why they’re
invited here this evenin’; but tomorrow we want _all_ to

label: neutral

text:
And so he went a-mooning on and on, liking to hear himself talk, and
every little while he fetched in his funeral orgies again, till the
duke he couldn’t stand it no more; so he writes on a little scrap of

goo-gooing and reaching it over people’s heads to him.
label: neutral

text:
The king he
reads it and puts it in his pocket, and says:
label: neutral

text: “Poor William, afflicted as he is, his _heart’s_ aluz right.

text:
Asks me to
invite everybody to come to the funeral—wants me to make ’em all

label: neutral

text: But he needn’t a worried—it was jest what I was at.”
label: neutral

text:
Then he weaves along again, perfectly ca’m, and goes to dropping in his

label: neutral

text:
And
when he done it the third time he says:
label: neutral

text:
“I say orgies, not because it’s the common term, because it

label: neutral

text: Obsequies ain’t used in England no more now—it’s gone out.
label: neutral

text:
We say
orgies now in England.
label: neutral

text:
Orgies is better, because it means the thing
you’re after more exact.
label: neutral

text:
It’s a word that’s made up out’n the Greek
_orgo_, outside, open, abroad; and the Hebrew _jeesum_, to plant, cover

funeral.”
label: neutral

text: He was the _worst_ I ever struck.

text:
Well, the iron-jawed man he laughed
right in his face.

text: This is Harvey Wilks.”

text: The king he smiled eager, and shoved out his flapper, and says:

text:

text:
They crowded around the doctor and tried to

showed in forty ways that he _was_ Harvey, and knowed everybody by

text:
But it warn’t no use; he stormed right along, and said any man that

text:
The poor girls was hanging to
the king and crying; and all of a sudden the doctor ups and turns on

label: surprise

text: He says:
label: neutral

text:
“I was your father’s friend, and I’m your friend; and I warn you _as_ a
friend, and an honest one that wants to protect you and keep you out of
harm and trouble, to turn your backs on that scoundrel and have nothing
to do with him, the ignorant tramp, with his idiotic Greek and Hebrew,
as he calls it.
label: neutral

text:
He is the thinnest kind of an impostor—has come here
with a lot of empty names and facts which he picked up somewheres, and
you take them for _proofs_, and are helped to fool yourselves by these

label: neutral

text:
Mary Jane Wilks, you
know me for your friend, and for your unselfish friend, too.

text:
Now listen
to me; turn this pitiful rascal out—I _beg_ you to do it.

text: Will you?”
label: surprise

text: Mary Jane straightened herself up, and my, but she was handsome!
label: surprise

text:
She
says:
label: neutral

text:
“_Here_ is my answer.” She hove up the bag of money and put it in the
king’s hands, and says, “Take this six thousand dollars, and invest for

it.”
label: neutral

text:
Then she put her arm around the king on one side, and Susan and the
hare-lip done the same on the other.
label: neutral

text:
Everybody clapped their hands and
stomped on the floor like a perfect storm, whilst the king held up his

text: The doctor says:
label: neutral

But I warn you all that a
time ’s coming when you’re going to feel sick whenever you think of

text:
“All right, doctor,” says the king, kinder mocking him; “we’ll try and

text: CHAPTER XXVI.
label: neutral

text:
Well, when they was all gone the king he asks Mary Jane how they was
off for spare rooms, and she said she had one spare room, which would
do for Uncle William, and she’d give her own room to Uncle Harvey,
which was a little bigger, and she would turn into the room with her
sisters and sleep on a cot; and up garret was a little cubby, with a
pallet in it.
label: neutral

text:
The king said the cubby would do for his valley—meaning
me.
label: neutral

text:
So Mary Jane took us up, and she showed them their rooms, which was
plain but nice.
label: neutral

text:
She said she’d have her frocks and a lot of other traps
took out of her room if they was in Uncle Harvey’s way, but he said
they warn’t.
label: neutral

text:
The frocks was hung along the wall, and before them was a
curtain made out of calico that hung down to the floor.
label: disgust

text:
There was an
old hair trunk in one corner, and a guitar-box in another, and all
sorts of little knickknacks and jimcracks around, like girls brisken up
a room with.
label: neutral

text:
The king said it was all the more homely and more
pleasanter for these fixings, and so don’t disturb them.
label: neutral

text:
The duke’s
room was pretty small, but plenty good enough, and so was my cubby.
label: neutral

text:
That night they had a big supper, and all them men and women was there,
and I stood behind the king and the duke’s chairs and waited on them,
and the niggers waited on the rest.
label: neutral

text:
Mary Jane she set at the head of
the table, with Susan alongside of her, and said how bad the biscuits
was, and how mean the preserves was, and how ornery and tough the fried
chickens was—and all that kind of rot, the way women always do for to
force out compliments; and the people all knowed everything was tiptop,
and said so—said “How _do_ you get biscuits to brown so nice?” and
“Where, for the land’s sake, _did_ you get these amaz’n pickles?” and
all that kind of humbug talky-talk, just the way people always does at
a supper, you know.
label: neutral

text:
And when it was all done me and the hare-lip had supper in the kitchen
off of the leavings, whilst the others was helping the niggers clean up
the things.
label: disgust

text:
The hare-lip she got to pumping me about England, and blest
if I didn’t think the ice was getting mighty thin sometimes.

label: surprise

Well, I bet I have—he goes to our church.” I

text: “Yes—regular.

His pew’s right over opposite ourn—on t’other side the

text: “Well, he does.

label: neutral

I had to let on to get choked with a chicken

That’s

text: “Why, you did.”

label: neutral

label: neutral

label: neutral

label: surprise

text:

label: neutral

label: neutral

You might a said that in the first place and saved

When she said that I see I was out of the woods again, and so I was

label: neutral

text: “Yes—regular.”

label: neutral

label: neutral

I see I was up a stump again, so I

text: “Seventeen!

text: My land!

label: neutral

How is

Do they treat ’em better ’n we treat our

label: neutral

Why, Hare-l—why, Joanna, they never see a holiday from year’s

label: neutral

text: “Nor church?”
label: surprise

text: “Nor church.”
label: neutral

label: neutral

text: Well, I was gone up again.
label: neutral

label: surprise

text:
But
next minute I whirled in on a kind of an explanation how a valley was

label: neutral

text:
But I didn’t do it pretty good, and when I got done I see she

label: neutral

label: neutral

label: anger

label: surprise

text: “None of it at all.
label: disgust

text: Not a lie in it,” says I.
label: neutral

label: neutral

text:
I see it warn’t nothing but a dictionary, so I laid my hand on it and

label: neutral

text: So then she looked a little better satisfied, and says:
label: neutral

text:
“Well, then, I’ll believe some of it; but I hope to gracious if I’ll

label: neutral

text:
“What is it you won’t believe, Joe?” says Mary Jane, stepping in with
Susan behind her.
label: surprise

text:
“It ain’t right nor kind for you to talk so to him,
and him a stranger and so far from his people.
label: disgust

text:
How would you like to be
treated so?”
label: neutral

text:
“That’s always your way, Maim—always sailing in to help somebody before

label: neutral

text: I hain’t done nothing to him.
label: neutral

text:
He’s told some stretchers,
I reckon, and I said I wouldn’t swallow it all; and that’s every bit

label: neutral

text:
I reckon he can stand a little thing like that,
can’t he?”
label: disgust

text:
“I don’t care whether ’twas little or whether ’twas big; he’s here in

text:
If you

label: neutral

text: “Why, Mam, he said—”
label: surprise

text: “It don’t make no difference what he _said_—that ain’t the thing.

text:
The

text:
I says to myself, _this_ is a girl that I’m letting that old reptile

label: anger

text:
Then Susan _she_ waltzed in; and if you’ll believe me, she did give
Hare-lip hark from the tomb!
label: surprise

text:
Says I to myself, and this is _another_ one that I’m letting him rob

label: anger

text:
Then Mary Jane she took another inning, and went in sweet and lovely
again—which was her way; but when she got done there warn’t hardly

text: So she hollered.
label: neutral

text: “All right, then,” says the other girls; “you just ask his pardon.”

text: She done it, too; and she done it beautiful.
label: neutral

text:
She done it so beautiful

text:
I says to myself, this is _another_ one that I’m letting him rob her of

text:
And when she got through they all jest laid theirselves out

disgust

text:
When I

label: fear

text:
I says to myself,
shall I go to that doctor, private, and blow on these frauds?

text:
No—that
won’t do.
label: anger

text:
He might tell who told him; then the king and the duke would

label: neutral

text: Shall I go, private, and tell Mary Jane?
label: neutral

text:
No—I
dasn’t do it.
label: anger

text:
Her face would give them a hint, sure; they’ve got the

text:
If she was to

label: neutral

text: No; there ain’t no good way but one.
label: sadness

text:
I got to steal that
money, somehow; and I got to steal it some way that they won’t

label: anger

text:
They’ve got a good thing here, and they ain’t
a-going to leave till they’ve played this family and this town for all

label: neutral

text:
I’ll steal it and
hide it; and by-and-by, when I’m away down the river, I’ll write a

label: neutral

text:
But I better hive it tonight
if I can, because the doctor maybe hasn’t let up as much as he lets on

text: So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms.
label: neutral

text:
Upstairs the hall was
dark, but I found the duke’s room, and started to paw around it with my
hands; but I recollected it wouldn’t be much like the king to let
anybody else take care of that money but his own self; so then I went
to his room and begun to paw around there.
label: fear

text:
But I see I couldn’t do
nothing without a candle, and I dasn’t light one, of course.
label: neutral

text:
So I
judged I’d got to do the other thing—lay for them and eavesdrop.
label: neutral

text:
About
that time I hears their footsteps coming, and was going to skip under

label: neutral

text:
They come in and shut the door; and the first thing the duke done was

label: fear

text:
Then I was glad I hadn’t found the
bed when I wanted it.

text:
And yet, you know, it’s kind of natural to hide

label: neutral

text:
They sets down then,
and the king says:
label: neutral

text: “Well, what is it?
label: surprise

text:
And cut it middlin’ short, because it’s better for

label: joy

text: “Well, this is it, Capet.
label: neutral

text: I ain’t easy; I ain’t comfortable.
label: sadness

text:
That
doctor lays on my mind.
label: neutral

label: neutral

text:
I’ve got a notion,

label: neutral

text:

I’m for knocking off and

About an hour or two ago it would a been

text:
The

But the king he got the bag

text:

I groped along up to my cubby, and hid it there till I

text:
